universalQuickWins.title: 3 Immediate Actions for Every Organization
universalQuickWins.subtitle: These measures can be implemented right away, regardless of your analysis:

mfa.title: Enable Multi-Factor Authentication
mfa.desc: Set up MFA for all business-critical accounts — the single most important step for IT security.

backup.title: Review Backup Strategy
backup.desc: Ensure regular data backups with documented recovery testing.

policy.title: Create IT Security Policy
policy.desc: A foundational document with IT security rules for the organization — required by virtually all regulations.

overlaps.nis2Kritis: NIS2 and KRITIS are both based on the BSI Act. Most technical and organizational measures apply to both regulations.
overlaps.nis2Dora: NIS2 and DORA share requirements for ICT risk management, incident reporting, and resilience testing in the financial sector.
overlaps.nis2Dsgvo: The technical and organizational measures (TOMs) of GDPR strongly overlap with NIS2 requirements for access control and encryption.
overlaps.nis2Bsi: BSI IT-Grundschutz can serve as an implementation framework for NIS2. Grundschutz modules cover most NIS2 measures.
overlaps.doraDsgvo: DORA and GDPR share requirements for incident reporting, third-party risk management, and access control.
overlaps.kritisBsi: BSI IT-Grundschutz is the recommended evidence framework for KRITIS operators. The modules cover all KRITIS requirements.
overlaps.tisaxNis2: TISAX and NIS2 share requirements for access control, encryption, and supplier management.
overlaps.craNis2: CRA and NIS2 share requirements for vulnerability management, incident reporting, and security-by-design.
overlaps.cisIso27001: CIS Controls and ISO 27001 complement each other — CIS provides technical implementation for ISO controls
overlaps.cisNis2: CIS Controls cover many technical NIS2 requirements
overlaps.cisBsi: CIS Controls and BSI IT-Grundschutz share many technical security measures
overlaps.cisNist: CIS Controls and NIST CSF are complementary US frameworks with high overlap
overlaps.bcmIso27001: ISO 22301 BCM deepens the Annex A.5.29-30 chapter of ISO 27001
overlaps.bcmNis2: NIS2 requires business continuity — ISO 22301 provides the framework
overlaps.bcmKritis: Critical infrastructure operators need robust BCM — ISO 22301 is the reference
overlaps.nistIso27001: NIST CSF and ISO 27001 have ~70% overlapping controls
overlaps.nistNis2: NIST CSF covers most NIS2 security requirements
overlaps.owaspCis: OWASP ASVS and CIS Controls complement each other for application security
overlaps.owaspIso27001: OWASP ASVS deepens application security from ISO 27001 Annex A.8

meldepflichten.title: Reporting Obligations under §32 BSIG
meldepflichten.subtitle: Three-stage reporting process for significant security incidents
meldepflichten.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act requires affected entities to report significant security incidents to the BSI without undue delay. The reporting process comprises three stages with fixed deadlines.

stage1.title: Initial Notification (24 hours)
stage1.description: Immediate initial notification to the BSI with basic information about the incident.
stage1.content: Initial assessment: nature and severity of the incident, suspected cross-border impact, initial suspicions regarding the cause.

stage2.title: Follow-up Report (72 hours)
stage2.description: Update of the initial notification with more detailed information.
stage2.content: Updated assessment: severity and impact, indicators of compromise (IoCs), countermeasures taken and planned.

stage3.title: Final Report (1 month)
stage3.deadline: No later than one month after the initial notification
stage3.description: Comprehensive final report on the incident and measures taken.
stage3.content: Detailed description: root cause analysis, type of threat, remedial measures taken, cross-border impact, lessons learned.

criteria.title: When is a Security Incident Considered Significant?
criteria.subtitle: A security incident is considered significant under §32 para. 4 BSIG if at least one of the following criteria is met:

items.disruption: Severe operational disruption of services or financial losses for the entity
items.damage: Considerable material or immaterial damage to other natural or legal persons

dsgvoComparison.title: Comparison: NIS2 vs. GDPR Reporting Obligations
dsgvoComparison.parallel: Note: If an incident falls under both NIS2 and GDPR, both reporting channels must be used in parallel.

meldepflichten.legalBasis: Legal basis: §32 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 23 NIS2 Directive

geschaeftsleitung.title: Management Accountability under §38 BSIG
geschaeftsleitung.subtitle: Personal duties and liability risks for management
geschaeftsleitung.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act establishes personal responsibility for management under §38 BSIG. These duties are non-delegable and encompass approval, monitoring, and training.

implement.title: Approve Risk Management Measures
implement.description: Management must approve the risk management measures required under §30 BSIG.

monitor.title: Monitor Implementation
monitor.description: Management must monitor the implementation of approved measures and can be held responsible for violations.

train.title: Regular Training
train.description: Management must regularly participate in training to acquire sufficient knowledge and skills for identifying and assessing risks.

personalLiability.title: Personal Liability
personalLiability.description: Management members are liable to the entity for damages caused by breach of their duties under §38 BSIG, according to the rules applicable to the legal form.

noWaiver.title: No Waiver Possible
noWaiver.description: A waiver of the entity's claims for damages against management is void. Settlements are only permitted if the entity is insolvent.

training.title: Training Obligation
training.description: Management must regularly participate in training. This cannot be fully delegated to third parties.

items.riskApproval: Risk management measures formally approved per §30 BSIG
items.responsibility: IT security responsibilities documented and communicated
items.budget: Adequate budget allocated for IT security

items.schedule: Annual training plan for management created

items.review: At least quarterly management reviews conducted

items.insurance: D&O insurance reviewed for NIS2 coverage

geschaeftsleitung.legalBasis: Legal basis: §38 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 20 NIS2 Directive

registrierung.title: Registration Guide under §§33-34 BSIG
registrierung.subtitle: Step-by-step guide for BSI registration
registrierung.intro: Affected entities must register with the BSI within three months of the NIS2 Implementation Act taking effect. Registration is done via the BSI portal.

deadline.title: Deadlines
deadline.note: The registration obligation applies from the time the entity first falls under the regulations.

step1.title: 1. Check Affected Status
step1.description: Use the affected check to determine whether your company falls under NIS2 and which category it is assigned to.

step2.title: 2. Create Business Account
step2.description: Create a business account on the federal Mein Unternehmenskonto (MUK) portal if you haven't already.

step3.title: 3. Access BSI Portal
step3.description: Navigate to the BSI registration portal and sign in with your business account.

step4.title: 4. Enter Details
step4.description: Enter all required data about your company (see checklist below).

step5.title: 5. Submit Registration
step5.description: Review all entries and submit the registration.

step6.title: 6. Await Confirmation
step6.description: The BSI will confirm the registration. You will receive access credentials for the reporting portal.

items.address: Address of headquarters and any other EU establishments
items.sector: Sector and sub-sector per Annex 1/2 BSIG
items.responsiblePerson: Name and contact of the responsible person

registrierung.legalBasis: Legal basis: §§33-34 BSIG in conjunction with Art. 3(3), Art. 27 NIS2 Directive

bussgeld.title: Penalty Calculator
bussgeld.subtitle: Estimated maximum penalty risk under §65 BSIG
bussgeld.intro: The NIS2 Implementation Act provides for significant penalties. The amount depends on the entity's classification and annual revenue.

explanation.besondersWichtig: For essential entities, the maximum penalty is up to EUR 10,000,000 or 2% of global annual revenue — whichever is higher.
explanation.wichtig: For important entities, the maximum penalty is up to EUR 7,000,000 or 1.4% of global annual revenue — whichever is higher.

bussgeld.note: Note: The actual penalty amount is determined by the competent authority on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the severity of the violation, possible recurrence, and countermeasures taken.

dsgvoOverlap.title: GDPR Overlap Analysis
dsgvoOverlap.subtitle: Leveraging synergies between NIS2 and GDPR compliance
dsgvoOverlap.intro: Approximately 60% of NIS2 requirements overlap with existing GDPR measures. Companies with existing GDPR compliance have a head start on NIS2 implementation.

riskAssessment.gap: NIS2 requires formal risk analysis per state of the art, not just 'appropriate' measures

incidentHandling.gap: NIS2: 24h deadline (vs. 72h GDPR), BSI as reporting authority (vs. DPA)

businessContinuity.gap: NIS2 requires comprehensive BCM including crisis management, not just recovery

supplyChain.gap: NIS2 requires IT security assessment of all suppliers, not just processors

securityMeasures.gap: NIS2 requires vulnerability management and secure procurement

effectiveness.gap: NIS2 requires demonstrable effectiveness testing (audits, pentests)

training.gap: NIS2 mandates management training (§38 BSIG) — not just general awareness

encryption.gap: NIS2 requires documented crypto concept with key management

accessControl.gap: NIS2 requires MFA, PAM, and regular access recertification

documentation.gap: NIS2 requires comprehensive documentation of all security measures

iso27001.name: ISO 27001
iso27001.description: International standard for systematic information security management

contextLeadership.name: Context & Leadership
contextLeadership.description: Determining the organizational context, requirements of interested parties, and leadership commitment for the ISMS (Clause 4 & 5).

planningRisk.name: Planning & Risk Assessment
planningRisk.description: Risk assessment, risk treatment, and establishing information security objectives (Clause 6).

supportAwareness.name: Support & Awareness
supportAwareness.description: Resources, competence, awareness, communication, and documented information for the ISMS (Clause 7).

operations.name: Operations & Change Management
operations.description: Operational planning and control, risk assessment execution, and management of suppliers and changes (Clause 8).

accessControl.name: Access Control
accessControl.description: Access control policies, identity management, authentication, and authorization management (Annex A.5.15-5.18, A.8.2-8.5).

cryptographyNetwork.name: Cryptography & Network Security
cryptographyNetwork.description: Use of cryptographic measures, network security, network segmentation, and web filtering (Annex A.8.20-8.26).

physicalSecurity.name: Physical Security
physicalSecurity.description: Security perimeters, physical access controls, equipment security, and protection against environmental threats (Annex A.7).

incidentContinuity.name: Incident Management & Continuity
incidentContinuity.description: Detecting, reporting, and handling security incidents, ensuring business continuity, and evaluating ISMS effectiveness (Clause 9, 10, Annex A.5.24-5.30).

clQ1.title: Have you determined the context of your organization and the requirements of interested parties for information security?
clQ1.tooltip: Clauses 4.1 and 4.2 require that internal/external issues and expectations of relevant stakeholders are systematically identified.
clQ1.help: This includes regulatory requirements, customer expectations, market environment, technological developments, and internal structures.

maturity.level0: No analysis of organizational context or stakeholder requirements exists.
maturity.level1: Some factors are informally known but not documented.
maturity.level2: Context and stakeholder requirements are documented and considered in ISMS planning.
maturity.level3: Context analysis and stakeholder requirements are regularly updated and systematically feed into all ISMS decisions.

clQ2.title: Has top management established and communicated an information security policy?
clQ2.tooltip: Clauses 5.1 and 5.2 require leadership commitment and a documented IS policy.
clQ2.help: The policy must be appropriate for the organization, include information security objectives, and be communicated to all employees.

maturity.level0: No information security policy exists.
maturity.level1: A basic policy exists but is outdated or not known to all employees.
maturity.level2: A current policy signed by top management is documented and communicated.
maturity.level3: The policy is regularly reviewed, integrated into business strategy, and top management actively demonstrates its commitment.

clQ3.title: Are roles, responsibilities, and authorities for information security clearly assigned?
clQ3.tooltip: Clause 5.3 requires the assignment and communication of ISMS roles and responsibilities.
clQ3.help: At minimum, an Information Security Officer (ISO/CISO) should be appointed. Responsibilities must be documented in job descriptions or organizational charts.

maturity.level0: No defined roles or responsibilities for information security.
maturity.level1: An ISO is informally appointed but responsibilities are not clearly documented.
maturity.level2: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities are documented and known to those involved.
maturity.level3: ISMS roles are embedded in the organizational structure with clear escalation paths, regular review, and adequate resources.

clQ4.title: Is the scope of your ISMS clearly defined and documented?
clQ4.tooltip: Clause 4.3 requires a clear definition of the ISMS scope considering internal/external issues and interfaces.
clQ4.help: The scope defines which locations, processes, systems, and organizational units are covered by the ISMS. It must be documented and available.

maturity.level0: No ISMS scope defined.
maturity.level1: The scope is roughly known but not formally documented or incomplete.
maturity.level2: A documented scope exists describing the boundaries and applicability of the ISMS.
maturity.level3: The scope is reviewed with every significant change and considers all relevant interfaces, dependencies, and outsourced processes.

prQ1.title: Do you conduct a systematic information security risk assessment?
prQ1.tooltip: Clause 6.1.2 requires a documented risk assessment process with defined criteria for acceptance, evaluation, and prioritization.
prQ1.help: The risk assessment must consider confidentiality, integrity, and availability, designate risk owners, and produce reproducible results.

maturity.level0: No systematic risk assessment in place.
maturity.level1: Risks are occasionally discussed ad-hoc without a structured methodology.
maturity.level2: A documented risk assessment process exists and is regularly conducted.
maturity.level3: The risk assessment is standardized, updated at least annually, uses quantitative/qualitative methods, and is integrated into business decisions.

prQ2.title: Do you have a risk treatment plan with a Statement of Applicability (SoA)?
prQ2.tooltip: Clause 6.1.3 requires the selection of appropriate controls and a Statement of Applicability (SoA).
prQ2.help: The SoA lists all controls from Annex A and justifies for each whether it is applicable or not. The treatment plan describes the planned measures.

maturity.level0: Neither a risk treatment plan nor an SoA exists.
maturity.level1: Individual measures are known but no complete plan or SoA has been created.
maturity.level2: A risk treatment plan and SoA are documented and approved by management.
maturity.level3: Plan and SoA are regularly reviewed, implementation status is tracked, and effectiveness of measures is measured.

prQ3.title: Have you established measurable information security objectives?
prQ3.tooltip: Clause 6.2 requires the establishment of information security objectives at relevant levels and functions.
prQ3.help: Objectives must be measurable (or at least evaluable), consistent with the IS policy, communicated, and regularly updated.

maturity.level0: No information security objectives defined.
maturity.level1: General objectives exist but are not measurable or communicated.
maturity.level2: Documented, measurable objectives with responsibilities and timeframes.
maturity.level3: Objectives are regularly reviewed, measured with KPIs, and results feed into the management review.

prQ4.title: Does your risk assessment consider threat intelligence and the current threat landscape?
prQ4.tooltip: Controls A.5.5 and A.5.7 require the integration of current threat information into the risk assessment.
prQ4.help: This includes BSI advisories, CERT notifications, industry-specific threat reports, and analysis of current attack patterns.

maturity.level0: Current threat information is not considered.
maturity.level1: Security advisories are occasionally read but not systematically integrated into risk assessment.
maturity.level2: Relevant threat sources are identified and regularly evaluated.
maturity.level3: Threat intelligence is integrated into the risk management process with automated feeds and regular reassessment of the risk landscape.

saQ1.title: Is there a training and awareness program for information security?
saQ1.tooltip: Clauses 7.2 and 7.3 require that all employees are competent and aware of the IS policy.
saQ1.help: Training should be role-based and regularly repeated. Awareness also includes knowledge of consequences for policy violations.

maturity.level0: No training or awareness activities for information security.
maturity.level1: Occasional, event-driven reminders without a structured program.
maturity.level2: A documented training program exists with regular execution and attendance records.
maturity.level3: Role-based training with effectiveness testing, phishing simulations, and continuous program improvement.

saQ2.title: Is there a document management system for ISMS documentation?
saQ2.tooltip: Clause 7.5 requires the control of documented information regarding creation, updating, distribution, and retention.
saQ2.help: Policies, procedures, records, and evidence must be versioned, accessible, and protected against unauthorized modification.

maturity.level0: No structured document control. Documents are scattered without versioning.
maturity.level1: Some documents are centrally stored but without consistent approval and versioning procedures.
maturity.level2: A document management system with versioning, approval process, and defined retention periods is implemented.
maturity.level3: Complete document control with automated workflows, access logs, and regular review of currency.

saQ3.title: Are sufficient resources provided for the operation and improvement of the ISMS?
saQ3.tooltip: Clause 7.1 requires the organization to determine and provide the resources needed for the ISMS.
saQ3.help: Resources include personnel, budget, tools, training, and time. Without adequate resources, an effective ISMS is not possible.

maturity.level0: No dedicated resources for information security.
maturity.level1: Information security is managed as a side task without its own budget or dedicated personnel.
maturity.level2: A dedicated IS budget and dedicated personnel resources are allocated.
maturity.level3: Resource planning is integrated into business planning with regular needs analysis and adjustment to new requirements.

saQ4.title: Is internal and external communication regarding information security regulated?
saQ4.tooltip: Clause 7.4 requires determining what, when, with whom, and how to communicate about information security.
saQ4.help: This includes reporting channels for security incidents, communication with authorities, customers, and suppliers, as well as internal awareness communication.

maturity.level0: No regulated communication channels for information security.
maturity.level1: Some communication channels exist informally but without a structured plan.
maturity.level2: A communication plan for IS-relevant topics is documented and implemented.
maturity.level3: Communication processes are fully integrated with defined contacts, escalation rules, and regular review.

opQ1.title: Are your operational IT processes documented and managed in a planned manner?
opQ1.tooltip: Clause 8.1 requires the planning, implementation, and control of processes needed to meet IS requirements.
opQ1.help: This includes change management, configuration management, patch management, and the control of outsourced processes.

maturity.level0: Operational IT processes are not documented and run unplanned.
maturity.level1: Some core processes are documented but not uniformly managed.
maturity.level2: Essential operational processes are documented with defined responsibilities and controls.
maturity.level3: All relevant processes are standardized, measured, and continuously improved.

opQ2.title: Do you conduct information security risk assessments at planned intervals?
opQ2.tooltip: Clauses 8.2 and 8.3 require conducting risk assessments at planned intervals and implementing the risk treatment plan.
opQ2.help: Risk assessment must not only be initial but recurring — especially when there are significant changes to systems, processes, or threat landscape.

maturity.level0: No regular risk assessment.
maturity.level1: Risk assessment was conducted once but is not regularly repeated.
maturity.level2: Risk assessment is repeated at defined intervals and updated when significant changes occur.
maturity.level3: Continuous risk assessment process with integration into change management and automatic trigger-based reassessment.

opQ3.title: How do you manage information security with suppliers and service providers?
opQ3.tooltip: Controls A.5.19-A.5.22 require supplier management with IS requirements in contracts and regular monitoring.
opQ3.help: For all suppliers with access to information or IT systems, IS requirements must be contractually regulated and compliance monitored.

maturity.level0: No IS requirements imposed on suppliers.
maturity.level1: Some contractual clauses exist but no systematic monitoring.
maturity.level2: IS requirements are included in contracts by default and there is a procedure for supplier assessment.
maturity.level3: Complete supplier risk management with regular audits, SLA monitoring, and escalation procedures.

opQ4.title: Is there a structured change management process for IT systems?
opQ4.tooltip: Controls A.8.9 and A.8.32 require the management of configuration changes and changes.
opQ4.help: All changes to IT systems, networks, and applications should be subject to a defined approval process with risk consideration.

maturity.level0: Changes are made without a formal process or documentation.
maturity.level1: An informal change process exists but is not consistently followed.
maturity.level2: A documented change management process with approval, testing, and documentation is implemented.
maturity.level3: Change management is fully integrated with automated workflows, risk classification, and post-implementation review.

acQ1.title: Is there a documented access control policy?
acQ1.tooltip: Control A.5.15 requires the establishment and implementation of rules for logical and physical access to information.
acQ1.help: The policy should implement the need-to-know and least-privilege principles and apply to all systems and data classifications.

maturity.level0: No access control policy exists.
maturity.level1: Informal rules for individual systems but no overarching policy.
maturity.level2: A documented access control policy with need-to-know principle and role-based access is implemented.
maturity.level3: The policy is regularly reviewed with automated enforcement and regular recertification of all access rights.

acQ2.title: How is authentication for access to systems and applications managed?
acQ2.tooltip: Controls A.5.17 and A.8.5 require secure authentication procedures appropriate to the sensitivity of information.
acQ2.help: This includes password policies, multi-factor authentication (MFA), privileged access, and protection of authentication information.

maturity.level0: No unified authentication policy. Default or weak passwords in use.
maturity.level1: Basic password policy exists but no MFA and no enforcement.
maturity.level2: Password policy is technically enforced, MFA is implemented for critical systems.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive authentication strategy with MFA for all systems, Privileged Access Management, and regular review.

acQ3.title: How are privileged access rights (admin rights) managed?
acQ3.tooltip: Controls A.8.2, A.8.3, and A.8.4 require restricted access to source code, privileged rights, and information.
acQ3.help: Privileged accounts pose a high risk and must be specially protected, monitored, and granted only when needed.

maturity.level0: No control over privileged access. Admin rights widely distributed.
maturity.level1: Admin rights are partially restricted but without systematic management or logging.
maturity.level2: Privileged access is granted based on least-privilege, logged, and regularly reviewed.
maturity.level3: Privileged Access Management with just-in-time access, session recording, and automated anomaly detection.

acQ4.title: Is there a process for regular review of access rights?
acQ4.tooltip: Control A.5.18 requires that access rights are reviewed at defined intervals and upon changes.
acQ4.help: Access rights must be adjusted upon role changes, transfers, and departures. Regular recertification prevents rights accumulation.

maturity.level0: No review of access rights. Rights are only granted, never revoked.
maturity.level1: Rights are revoked upon departure but no regular review of existing rights.
maturity.level2: Regular recertification of access rights with a documented procedure.
maturity.level3: Automated recertification processes with Identity Governance, role-change triggers, and complete traceability.

cnQ1.title: Do you use encryption to protect data?
cnQ1.tooltip: Control A.8.24 requires the use of cryptography according to a defined policy.
cnQ1.help: Encryption should be used for data in transit (TLS) and data at rest (disk encryption). A cryptography policy defines standards and algorithms.

maturity.level0: No or only minimal encryption in use.
maturity.level1: Encryption is used for email or individual systems without an overarching policy.
maturity.level2: A cryptography policy exists. TLS is active for all external connections, endpoints are encrypted.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive cryptography strategy with key management, regular algorithm review, and end-to-end encryption for sensitive data.

cnQ2.title: How is your network security and segmentation set up?
cnQ2.tooltip: Controls A.8.20, A.8.21, and A.8.22 require network security, network services security, and network segmentation.
cnQ2.help: Networks must be segmented, monitored, and secured. Critical systems should operate in separate network zones.

maturity.level0: Flat network without segmentation. No firewalls between zones.
maturity.level1: Basic firewall in place but no systematic segmentation or network monitoring.
maturity.level2: Network segmentation by zone concept, firewall rules documented, network monitoring implemented.
maturity.level3: Zero-trust network architecture, micro-segmentation, automated threat detection, and regular penetration tests.

cnQ3.title: Are web applications and web services adequately protected?
cnQ3.tooltip: Controls A.8.23 and A.8.26 require web filtering and securing of application services.
cnQ3.help: Web applications must be protected against common attacks (OWASP Top 10), regularly tested, and kept up to date.

maturity.level0: No specific security measures for web applications.
maturity.level1: Basic measures like HTTPS but no regular security testing.
maturity.level2: WAF in use, regular vulnerability scans, secure development practices.
maturity.level3: DevSecOps pipeline with automated security testing, bug bounty program, and continuous monitoring.

cnQ4.title: Are development environments securely configured and separated from production systems?
cnQ4.tooltip: Control A.8.25 requires a secure development lifecycle with separated environments.
cnQ4.help: Development, test, and production environments must be separated. Production data may only be used in anonymized form in test environments.

maturity.level0: No separation between development and production.
maturity.level1: Basic separation but occasionally production data in test environments.
maturity.level2: Clear separation of environments, documented deployment processes, and no production data in tests.
maturity.level3: Fully automated CI/CD pipeline with security gates, infrastructure-as-code, and regular security reviews.

psQ1.title: Are your premises and IT infrastructure physically secured?
psQ1.tooltip: Controls A.7.1-A.7.4 require physical security perimeters, entry controls, office protection, and monitoring.
psQ1.help: Server rooms, data centers, and sensitive areas must be protected by access control systems, monitoring, and alarm systems.

maturity.level0: No physical access protection. Server rooms are freely accessible.
maturity.level1: Simple locking systems in place but no systematic access control or logging.
maturity.level2: Access control systems for sensitive areas, visitor management, and documented security zones.
maturity.level3: Multi-layer access control, video surveillance, alarm systems, regular physical security audits, and penetration tests.

psQ2.title: How do you protect IT equipment and storage media from theft and environmental damage?
psQ2.tooltip: Controls A.7.8, A.7.9, and A.7.10 require the protection of equipment and storage media inside and outside the organization.
psQ2.help: Laptops, mobile devices, and storage media must be protected against theft, loss, and environmental impacts (water, fire, temperature).

maturity.level0: No protection of equipment and storage media. No inventory.
maturity.level1: Basic inventory but no specific protection measures for mobile devices or storage media.
maturity.level2: Equipment inventory, encryption of mobile devices, secure disposal of storage media documented.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive asset management with MDM, automated inventory, remote wipe capability, and certified media destruction.

psQ3.title: Are there protective measures against environmental and infrastructure threats for your IT?
psQ3.tooltip: Controls A.7.5, A.7.11-A.7.13 require protection against physical and environmental threats and securing of utility infrastructure.
psQ3.help: This includes UPS systems, air conditioning, fire protection, water detectors, and redundant power supply for critical IT systems.

maturity.level0: No protective measures against environmental threats or infrastructure failures.
maturity.level1: Basic UPS for servers but no systematic protective measures.
maturity.level2: UPS, air conditioning, fire detectors, and water detectors for server rooms. Redundant internet connection.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive infrastructure resilience with redundant power supply, suppression systems, environmental monitoring, and regular testing.

icQ1.title: Is there a documented process for detecting and handling security incidents?
icQ1.tooltip: Controls A.5.24-A.5.26 require the planning, detection, reporting, and assessment of information security events and incidents.
icQ1.help: An incident response plan must define roles, escalation paths, communication rules, and recovery procedures.

maturity.level0: No process for detecting or handling security incidents.
maturity.level1: Incidents are handled ad-hoc without a documented process or clear responsibilities.
maturity.level2: A documented incident response plan exists with defined roles, escalation levels, and communication channels.
maturity.level3: Mature IR process with SIEM integration, automated playbooks, regular exercises, and lessons-learned process.

icQ2.title: Do you have a business continuity plan for IT outages?
icQ2.tooltip: Controls A.5.29 and A.5.30 require ensuring business continuity during IT disruptions and ICT readiness for business continuity.
icQ2.help: The BCP must include recovery objectives (RTO/RPO), restart priorities, fallback procedures, and communication plans.

maturity.level0: No business continuity plan exists.
maturity.level1: Basic data backups exist but no structured BCP.
maturity.level2: A documented BCP with defined RTOs/RPOs, restart plans, and emergency contacts.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive, regularly tested BCP with DR site, automated failover mechanisms, and annual exercises.

icQ3.title: Do you conduct regular internal audits and management reviews of the ISMS?
icQ3.tooltip: Clauses 9.1-9.3 require monitoring, measurement, analysis, evaluation, internal audits, and management review of the ISMS.
icQ3.help: Internal audits verify the conformity and effectiveness of the ISMS. The management review ensures that leadership regularly evaluates ISMS performance.

maturity.level0: No internal audits or management reviews of the ISMS.
maturity.level1: Occasional informal reviews without a structured audit program.
maturity.level2: An audit program is implemented with annual internal audits and documented management review.
maturity.level3: Mature audit program with risk-based planning, qualified auditors, action tracking, and continual improvement (Clause 10).

cl1.title: Create and approve an information security policy
cl1.description: Create an information security policy signed by top management and communicated to all employees. The policy forms the foundation of your ISMS.
cl1.firstStep: Download an ISO 27001-compliant policy template and adapt it to your organization. Present the policy to top management for signature.

cl2.title: Conduct context analysis and define ISMS scope
cl2.description: Systematically analyze the context of your organization (internal/external), the requirements of interested parties, and define the scope of your ISMS.
cl2.firstStep: Create a stakeholder matrix and list all internal and external factors affecting your information security. Define the ISMS scope based on this analysis.

cl3.title: Build ISMS organizational structure with clear roles
cl3.description: Establish an ISMS organizational structure with an appointed Information Security Officer (ISO), defined roles, and an IS steering committee.
cl3.firstStep: Appoint an ISO with a direct reporting line to top management. Create a RACI diagram for all ISMS processes.
cl3.checklist:
Appoint ISO and create job description
Establish IS steering committee (quarterly)
Create RACI matrix for ISMS processes
Document escalation paths
Define budget and resources for ISMS
Set up reporting to top management

pr1.title: Establish risk assessment methodology
pr1.description: Define and implement a systematic risk assessment process with clear criteria for risk acceptance, assessment scales, and risk ownership.
pr1.firstStep: Choose a risk assessment methodology (e.g., BSI Standard 200-3 or ISO 27005). Create a risk register with the first 10 identified risks.

pr2.title: Create a Statement of Applicability (SoA)
pr2.description: Create a Statement of Applicability (SoA) listing all 93 Annex A controls and justifying for each whether it is applicable or not.
pr2.firstStep: Download an SoA template with all 93 Annex A controls. Review each control with the ISO and relevant departments, documenting the decision.

pr3.title: Define information security objectives and KPIs
pr3.description: Define measurable information security objectives at company and department level with KPIs, responsibilities, and timeframes.
pr3.firstStep: Derive 3-5 measurable objectives from the IS policy (e.g., 'All employees complete annual IS training'). Define a KPI and a responsible person for each objective.
pr3.checklist:
Define 3-5 measurable IS objectives
Establish KPIs with target values
Assign responsible persons
Determine measurement intervals (monthly/quarterly)
Integrate reporting into management review
Plan annual objective review and adjustment

sa1.title: Set up an information security awareness program
sa1.description: Establish a role-based training and awareness program that regularly educates all employees about current threats, policies, and their behavior.
sa1.firstStep: Conduct an initial awareness training for all employees (e.g., as a 60-minute webinar). Topics: recognizing phishing, password security, incident reporting channels.

sa2.title: Implement a document management system for the ISMS
sa2.description: Implement a structured system for creating, approving, distributing, versioning, and archiving all ISMS documents.
sa2.firstStep: Define a uniform document structure (e.g., Policies > Procedures > Work Instructions > Records). Set up a central repository with versioning.
sa2.checklist:
Define document hierarchy (Policy > Procedure > Work Instruction > Record)
Set up central repository (SharePoint/Wiki/DMS)
Create template with versioning, approval, and validity date
Assign responsible document owners
Define retention periods
Configure access rights for documents

op1.title: Introduce a change management process
op1.description: Introduce a structured change management process that captures, assesses, approves, and documents all changes to IT systems.
op1.firstStep: Create a change request form with fields for description, risk assessment, fallback plan, and approval. Define who may approve changes.

op2.title: Build an asset inventory and configuration management
op2.description: Create a complete inventory of all information assets (hardware, software, data, services) and implement configuration management for critical systems.
op2.firstStep: Create an asset list of all IT systems with ownership, classification, and location. Start with the 20 most critical systems.

op3.title: Implement supplier security management
op3.description: Implement a systematic process for assessing, contractually securing, and continuously monitoring information security with suppliers and service providers.
op3.firstStep: Create a list of all suppliers with access to your information or IT systems. Classify them by risk and prioritize the top 5 for a security assessment.

ac1.title: Create and implement an access control policy
ac1.description: Create a comprehensive access control policy based on need-to-know and least-privilege principles. Define role-based access profiles for all critical systems.
ac1.firstStep: Document current access rights for your 5 most critical systems. Identify excessive rights and create role-based standard profiles.

ac2.title: Implement multi-factor authentication and password policy
ac2.description: Implement a strong authentication strategy with MFA for all critical systems and external access, supported by a technically enforced password policy.
ac2.firstStep: Enable MFA for all external access (VPN, email, cloud services) and administrative accounts. Implement a password policy with minimum length and complexity requirements.

cn1.title: Introduce a cryptography policy and encryption standards
cn1.description: Create a cryptography policy that defines permitted algorithms, key lengths, and the use of encryption for data in transit and data at rest.
cn1.firstStep: Check the current encryption status: Are all external connections TLS-encrypted? Are laptops and mobile devices encrypted? Document the current state.

cn2.title: Implement network segmentation and monitoring
cn2.description: Implement network segmentation by zones (e.g., DMZ, internal, management, guest) with firewall rules, network monitoring, and documented network diagrams.
cn2.firstStep: Create a network diagram with all zones and transition points. Identify critical systems and check whether they operate in separate network segments.

ps1.title: Introduce physical access controls for sensitive areas
ps1.description: Implement physical access controls for server rooms, data centers, and other sensitive areas with electronic locking systems, visitor registers, and access logging.
ps1.firstStep: Identify all sensitive areas (server room, network cabinets, archive). Check the current access protection and create an action plan for improvements.

ps2.title: Build a comprehensive physical security architecture
ps2.description: Build a multi-layered physical security architecture covering environmental protection (UPS, HVAC, fire, water), equipment security, and infrastructure resilience.
ps2.firstStep: Conduct a walkthrough of all IT rooms. Document existing protective measures and gaps (UPS capacity, fire detectors, air conditioning, water detectors).
ps2.checklist:
Check/install UPS for server room (min. 15 min bridge time)
Air conditioning for server room with temperature monitoring
Check fire detection system and fire extinguishers
Install water detectors in server room
Redundant power supply for critical systems
Equipment inventory with location and classification
Regulate secure disposal of storage media
Access logging for all sensitive areas

ic1.title: Create an incident response plan and define reporting channels
ic1.description: Create a comprehensive incident response plan with classification, roles, escalation levels, communication channels, and recovery procedures.
ic1.firstStep: Define an incident classification (low/medium/high/critical) with examples. Appoint an incident response team and create an emergency contact list.

ic2.title: Create a business continuity plan with IT disaster recovery
ic2.description: Create and test a business continuity plan (BCP) including IT disaster recovery (DR) with defined recovery objectives, restart plans, and regular exercises.
ic2.firstStep: Conduct a Business Impact Analysis (BIA): Which business processes are critical? What is the maximum tolerable downtime (RTO)? How much data loss is acceptable (RPO)?
ic2.checklist:
Conduct Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
Define RTO/RPO for all critical systems
Establish restart priorities
Create DR plan with step-by-step instructions
Create emergency communication plan
Conduct annual BCP/DR exercise
Verify backup strategy against RTO/RPO targets
Evaluate DR site or cloud DR

ic3.title: Establish an internal audit program and management review
ic3.description: Establish a systematic internal audit program and conduct regular management reviews to ensure the effectiveness and conformity of the ISMS.
ic3.firstStep: Create an annual audit plan covering all ISMS areas. Identify qualified internal auditors or commission external auditors for the first round.

q1.title: Does your organization have an information security policy approved by top management?
q1.description: An IS policy is the foundation of the ISMS. It must be approved by top management, communicated, and regularly reviewed (Clause 5.2).

q2.title: Do you conduct a systematic risk assessment for information security?
q2.description: A documented risk assessment process identifies threats, evaluates impacts and likelihoods, and prioritizes countermeasures (Clause 6.1.2).

q3.title: Are there regular training and awareness activities on information security for all employees?
q3.description: All employees must be informed and trained about the IS policy, their responsibilities, and current threats (Clause 7.2, 7.3).

q4.title: Are your IT operational processes documented and are changes performed in a controlled manner?
q4.description: Change management, patch processes, and operational procedures must be documented and controlled to prevent unmanaged changes (Clause 8.1).

q5.title: Is there an access control policy with least-privilege principle and regular review?
q5.description: Access rights must be granted on a need-to-know basis, technically enforced, and regularly recertified (A.5.15-A.5.18).

q6.title: Do you use encryption for data in transit and on endpoints?
q6.description: Cryptography protects confidential data during transmission (TLS) and on devices (disk encryption). A cryptography policy sets standards (A.8.24).

q7.title: Are your server rooms and IT infrastructure physically secured?
q7.description: Physical access protection, environmental protection (UPS, HVAC, fire), and equipment security are prerequisites for information security (A.7.1-A.7.14).

q8.title: Do you have a documented process for detecting and handling security incidents?
q8.description: An incident response plan with reporting channels, escalation levels, and recovery procedures is essential for response capability (A.5.24-A.5.26).

q9.title: Is there a Statement of Applicability (SoA) for all Annex A controls?
q9.description: The SoA is a core component of the ISMS and documents which of the 93 controls are applicable and why (Clause 6.1.3).

q10.title: Do you conduct internal ISMS audits and regular management reviews?
q10.description: Internal audits verify the conformity and effectiveness of the ISMS. The management review ensures that leadership is actively involved (Clause 9.2, 9.3).

bnetza.name: BNetzA IT Security Catalog
bnetza.description: Mandatory IT security catalog from the Federal Network Agency for electricity and gas network operators

energy.challenges: Energy suppliers must address both OT and IT security equally. Industrial control systems (SCADA/ICS) require special protective measures.
energy.recommendations: Implement strict network segmentation between IT and OT. Consider the IEC 62443 standard series for industrial automation.

sgbv.name: §75c SGB V
sgbv.description: IT security requirements in healthcare — appropriate measures according to the state of the art

patientdata.name: Patient Data Protection
patientdata.description: Special protection of health data under Art. 9 GDPR and §22 BDSG

health.challenges: In healthcare, the availability of critical systems is vital. Medical devices often have long lifecycles and cannot be easily patched.
health.recommendations: Prioritize network segmentation of medical devices. Create a separate inventory for medical IT systems with specific protective measures.

cir.name: CIR (EU) 2024/2690
cir.description: Implementing regulation with technical and methodological requirements for digital infrastructure providers

tkg.name: Telecommunications Act (TKG)
tkg.description: Security requirements for telecommunications providers under §§165-169 TKG

digital.challenges: Digital infrastructure providers are often targeted by sophisticated attacks and must simultaneously ensure high availability.
digital.recommendations: Implement DDoS protection, automated anomaly detection, and a multi-tier incident response procedure.

cer.name: KRITIS Framework Act (CER Implementation)
cer.description: Implementation of the CER Directive (EU 2022/2557) for resilience of critical entities in the transport sector

transport.challenges: Transport companies have widely distributed IT infrastructures (telematics units, on-board computers, fleet tracking systems, workshop software) and must secure real-time systems. An attack on these systems can paralyze the fleet — every truck that doesn't roll costs direct revenue.
transport.recommendations: Focus on securing real-time communications (dispatching, telematics) and ensure offline backup processes exist. Check whether your workshop and fleet software is regularly updated and whether remote access to vehicle telematics is secured.

ics.name: IEC 62443 (Industrial Cybersecurity)
ics.description: International standard series for IT security of industrial automation and control systems

manufacturing.challenges: Manufacturing companies often have legacy OT systems that cannot be easily updated and have high availability requirements.
manufacturing.recommendations: Prioritize inventorying all OT systems and implement strict IT/OT network segmentation following the Purdue model.

dora.name: DORA (EU) 2022/2554
dora.description: Digital Operational Resilience Act — EU regulation for digital operational resilience in the financial sector

bait.name: BAIT (BaFin)
bait.description: Supervisory Requirements for IT in Financial Institutions — binding requirements from BaFin

finance.challenges: Financial companies are already subject to strict regulatory requirements (BAIT, DORA). NIS2 adds an additional layer.
finance.recommendations: Use existing DORA/BAIT compliance as a foundation. Identify the delta requirements of NIS2 compared to your existing measures.

trinkwv.name: Drinking Water Ordinance (TrinkwV)
trinkwv.description: Requirements for the safety of drinking water supply

water.challenges: Water suppliers often operate widely distributed infrastructures with remote control technology that needs special protection.
water.recommendations: Focus on securing remote control technology (SCADA) and ensure that physical and digital security are considered holistically.

iris2.name: EU Regulation 2023/588 (IRIS²)
iris2.description: EU Secure Connectivity Programme with cybersecurity requirements for satellite infrastructure, including risk and threat analyses for ground and space segments

space.challenges: The space sector faces unique challenges: satellite systems are difficult to patch and operate over long periods. Ground infrastructures are the centre of compliance requirements. Signal integrity for remote satellite management and securing space surveillance systems require specialised security concepts.
space.recommendations: Implement a comprehensive security concept following the secure-by-design approach covering both ground and space segments. Prioritize securing ground infrastructure and supply chain security. Consider ENISA guidance on cybersecurity for commercial satellite operations.

postg.name: Postal Act 2024 (PostG)
postg.description: Modernised postal law with registration requirement at the Federal Network Agency. Postal and courier services fall under NIS2 as important entities.

postal.challenges: Postal and courier services operate highly distributed IT infrastructures with tracking and shipment monitoring systems, mobile devices, and sorting facilities. The convergence of physical and digital security presents a particular challenge. Even smaller courier companies may be indirectly affected through supply chain requirements.
postal.recommendations: Secure tracking and shipment monitoring systems through encryption and access controls. Implement centralised security monitoring covering all distributed locations and mobile devices. Ensure that subcontractors in the delivery chain also comply with cybersecurity requirements.

krwg.name: Circular Economy Act (KrWG)
krwg.description: Central federal law of German waste law. Municipal waste disposal has been classified as a critical service under the KRITIS framework since 2024.

waste.challenges: Waste management operations increasingly rely on OT systems (SCADA/ICS) for controlling waste incineration plants, sorting facilities, and environmental monitoring systems. These systems often have lifecycles of 10-25 years and frequently lack modern authentication or encryption. The convergence of waste logistics, environmental monitoring, and digital control technology requires integrated security concepts.
waste.recommendations: Prioritize complete inventorying of all OT/SCADA systems and implement strict network segmentation between IT and OT networks following the Purdue model. Introduce dedicated OT risk management and develop contingency plans that enable minimum operations even in case of digital control system failure.

seveso.name: Major Accident Hazards Ordinance (12. BImSchV) / Seveso III Directive
seveso.description: Governs prevention of major accidents involving dangerous substances. Section 2 includes protection against unauthorised interference with IT and OT systems. The KAS-44 guidance specifies IT security requirements for facilities subject to the ordinance.

chemicals.challenges: Chemical plants face the challenge of ensuring cybersecurity and plant safety simultaneously. Cyberattacks on ICS/SCADA can trigger hazardous reactions, environmental damage, or major accidents. The overlap between Seveso III, IEC 62443, and NIS2 creates complex multi-regulatory compliance demands.
chemicals.recommendations: Create a complete inventory of all IT and OT assets in accordance with KAS-44 and implement strict network segmentation between corporate IT and process control technology. Use the IEC 62443 standard series as a technical framework. Integrate your major accident emergency planning with the cyber incident response plan.

foodlaw.name: EU General Food Law Regulation / LFGB
foodlaw.description: Regulation (EC) 178/2002 requires complete traceability at all stages of production and distribution. With increasing digitalisation of traceability systems, their cybersecurity gains significant importance in the NIS2 context.

food.challenges: Food companies must secure digitally connected traceability systems, cold chain IT, and HACCP documentation systems against cyberattacks. An attack on temperature monitoring systems can directly endanger food safety. A cybersecurity incident can simultaneously trigger food law and NIS2 reporting obligations.
food.recommendations: Use existing HACCP and IFS/BRC documentation structures as a foundation for NIS2 risk management ('Cyber-HACCP'). Secure cold chain monitoring systems and traceability databases through access controls and offline backups. Ensure your incident response plan addresses both NIS2 and food law reporting obligations.

dsa.name: Digital Services Act (DSA)
dsa.description: EU-wide rules for platform operators, online marketplaces, and search engines. DSA obligations regarding user safety and platform integrity overlap with NIS2 cybersecurity requirements.

tdddg.name: TDDDG (formerly TTDSG)
tdddg.description: Governs data protection and privacy in digital services in Germany, including cookie consent requirements and confidentiality. Overlaps with NIS2 in technical protective measures for user data.

digitalServices.challenges: Digital service providers are subject to a light-touch supervisory regime but must still fulfill all risk management and reporting obligations. Key challenges include DDoS protection while ensuring high availability, protecting user data across multiple regulatory frameworks (DSA, GDPR, TDDDG, NIS2), and safeguarding the integrity of content delivery systems and recommender algorithms.
digitalServices.recommendations: Implement an integrated compliance framework covering NIS2, DSA, and TDDDG requirements. Establish robust DDoS protection, automated anomaly detection, and a multi-tier incident response procedure with 24-hour reporting capability. Conduct regular security audits of platform architecture including API security.

dualuse.name: Dual-Use Regulation
dualuse.description: Regulation (EU) 2021/821 governs export controls for dual-use goods. Research outputs with dual-use potential are subject to special security requirements that overlap with NIS2 obligations.

gdprResearch.name: GDPR Research Privilege
gdprResearch.description: Art. 89 GDPR grants research institutions special privileges for data processing but requires appropriate technical safeguards (pseudonymisation, data minimisation) that overlap with NIS2 requirements.

research.challenges: Research institutions must protect intellectual property and confidential research data while maintaining scientific openness and collaboration capability. Dual-use research outputs are subject to special export control and security requirements. International research partnerships and data exchange platforms must be secured against industrial espionage and state-sponsored cyber attacks.
research.recommendations: Implement systematic data classification distinguishing between open, confidential, and export-controlled (dual-use) data. Establish a dedicated ISMS for research IT and contractually obligate international cooperation partners to appropriate security standards. Regularly train scientific staff on IT security and secure handling of sensitive research data.

it-sicherheitspolicy.name: IT Security Policy
it-sicherheitspolicy.scenario:
A mid-size machinery manufacturer falls victim to a ransomware attack. Investigation reveals: there was no documented IT security policy. Employees used personal USB drives, passwords were shared, and nobody knew who was responsible in an emergency. The damage: 3 weeks of production downtime, €180,000 in direct costs.

Without a binding IT security policy, there's no foundation for any further measures — and nothing to show in an audit.
it-sicherheitspolicy.solution:
1. Download template and adapt to your organization (2-3 pages suffice)
2. Define key points: scope, responsibilities, password rules, media handling, reporting channels
3. Have management sign it (legally required under NIS2)
4. Communicate to all employees (email + intranet + bulletin board)
5. Schedule annual review and update
it-sicherheitspolicy.benefit: A documented IT security policy is the foundation for every audit and certification. It significantly reduces management liability and creates clear guidelines for all employees. Insurers offer up to 10% discount on cyber policies.
it-sicherheitspolicy.nextStep: Create your IT security policy with our 2-page template. Customize it and have management sign it.
