schulungskonzept.name: Training Concept
schulungskonzept.scenario:
An accountant opens a perfectly forged email from the supposed CEO and transfers €45,000 to a foreign account (CEO fraud). The reason: not a single employee had ever been trained in IT security. Phishing emails, social engineering, and secure passwords were never a topic.

92% of all cyberattacks start with the human factor. Without training, your employees are the weakest link.
schulungskonzept.solution:
1. Schedule annual basic training (2h) for all employees
2. Content: recognizing phishing, secure passwords, reporting channels, social engineering
3. Quarterly phishing simulation (free tools: GoPhish, KnowBe4 Free)
4. New employees: IT security briefing on day one
5. Document results (attendance lists, test scores)
schulungskonzept.benefit: Trained employees detect 70% more phishing emails. The 2-hour annual investment saves an average of €50,000 in prevented incidents. Mandatory documentation for NIS2 and GDPR audits.
schulungskonzept.nextStep: Plan your first IT security training. Use our training template with agenda, slide suggestions, and attendance documentation.

legal.nis2: Obligation for regular cybersecurity training for all employees
legal.dsgvo: Awareness and training of employees involved in processing operations
legal.bsi: Information security awareness and training

risikomanagement.name: Risk Management Process
risikomanagement.scenario:
A logistics company invests €200,000 in a next-gen firewall while the biggest threat is an unpatched legacy server in the basement running the entire order processing. Without systematic risk management, budgets are misallocated and real vulnerabilities are overlooked.

Risk management means: knowing where the real dangers lie — and investing there first.
risikomanagement.solution:
1. Create asset inventory: list all critical systems, data, and processes
2. Identify threats: what can go wrong? (Ransomware, outage, data loss)
3. Assess risks: probability × impact (simple matrix)
4. Prioritize measures: address highest risks first
5. Monthly 30-minute workshop: status review and add new risks
risikomanagement.benefit: Systematic risk management saves an average of 40% of IT security budget through better prioritization. It's the core requirement of NIS2, DORA, and BSI IT-Grundschutz — without risk management, no audit passes.
risikomanagement.nextStep: Start with our risk assessment template (Excel). Capture your top 10 risks and prioritize your next measures in 60 minutes.

legal.nis2: Risk analysis concept and information systems security
legal.dsgvo: Regular review and evaluation of the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures
legal.dora: Comprehensive ICT risk management framework as part of overall risk management
legal.tisax: Information security risk management per VDA ISA Assessment Level 1.3
legal.bsi: Systematic risk management process per BSI Standard 200-3

2.name: Access & Identities
2.description: Multi-factor authentication, role-based access control, password hygiene, and identity management for your organization.

mfa.name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
mfa.scenario:
An IT service provider loses access to 200 customer servers because an admin password appears in a data breach. The attacker logs in at night and encrypts all systems. With MFA enabled, the password alone would have been worthless.

81% of all data breaches exploit stolen or weak passwords. MFA stops 99.9% of these attacks.
mfa.solution:
1. Identify critical systems: email, VPN, cloud services, admin access
2. Choose MFA method: authenticator app (recommended), hardware token (high security), SMS (minimum)
3. Plan rollout: admins first, then management, then all employees
4. Define recovery process: what happens with a lost token?
5. Enforcement: configure MFA as mandatory, not optional
mfa.benefit: MFA reduces account compromises by 99.9%. Setup takes 15 minutes per employee and costs nothing with authenticator apps. Mandatory for NIS2-regulated companies.
mfa.nextStep: Enable MFA for your admin accounts today. Start with Microsoft Authenticator or Google Authenticator — both are free.

legal.nis2: Multi-factor authentication as part of access control
legal.dsgvo: Appropriate security of processing including access control
legal.dora: Strong authentication mechanisms for ICT systems
legal.bsi: Securing authentication for system access

rbac.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
rbac.scenario:
A working student in marketing accidentally has access to all financial data because the permissions of a departed controller were simply copied during onboarding. When his laptop is stolen, all salary data is compromised.

The principle of 'everyone has access to everything' is the most common mistake in SMEs — and the most expensive in an incident.
rbac.solution:
1. Define roles: management, department heads, staff, IT admin, external
2. Per role: which systems and data are actually needed?
3. Create role matrix (use Excel template)
4. Adjust permissions in all systems (AD, cloud, ERP)
5. Quarterly review: are permissions still appropriate?
rbac.benefit: RBAC reduces the attack surface in data breaches by 60%. In an incident, only the data of the respective role is affected, not everything. Mandatory requirement in all IT security standards.
rbac.nextStep: Create your role matrix with our Excel template. Define 5-7 roles and map your systems.

legal.nis2: Access control and asset management concepts
legal.dsgvo: Access regulations for personal data on a need-to-know basis
legal.tisax: Access control regulations for information assets
legal.bsi: Regulation of access rights according to the principle of least privilege

passwort-hygiene.name: Password Hygiene & Policy
passwort-hygiene.scenario: A tax consultant uses 'Summer2024!' for all client portals. When one portal is hacked, the attacker tries the same password on DATEV, Elster, and the firm's cloud — it works everywhere. Result: tax data of 300 clients compromised, notification to the data protection authority, existential reputational damage.
passwort-hygiene.solution:
1. Set password policy: minimum 14 characters, no dictionary words
2. Deploy password manager (Bitwarden Business, from €3/user/month)
3. Enable automatic checking against leaked password databases
4. Password rotation: only on suspected compromise (no longer time-based)
5. Admin passwords: 20+ characters, separate password vaults
passwort-hygiene.benefit: A password manager eliminates password reuse 100%. Employees only need to remember one master password. Reduces helpdesk password reset requests by 50%.
passwort-hygiene.nextStep: Deploy a password manager and create a password policy. Our template contains ready-made rules for your business.

legal.nis2: System security including access protection during acquisition, development, and maintenance
legal.dsgvo: Technical measures for protecting personal data during processing
legal.bsi: Regulated password assignment and appropriate password quality

3.name: Data & Storage
3.description: Backup strategies, encryption, data classification, and secure data storage for confidential business information.

backup-3-2-1.name: 3-2-1 Backup Strategy
backup-3-2-1.scenario:
A print shop is hit by ransomware. All files encrypted, including the backup on the network share. The only remaining backup set is 8 months old. Result: €45,000 ransom payment and still 3 months of data reconstruction.

The 3-2-1 rule prevents exactly this scenario: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 copy offsite.
backup-3-2-1.solution:
1. Automatic daily backup to local storage (NAS or server)
2. Second copy on different medium (external hard drive or tape)
3. Third copy offsite: cloud backup or off-site rotation
4. Monthly restore test: can you actually recover?
5. Enable backup encryption and securely store keys
backup-3-2-1.benefit: The 3-2-1 strategy makes you immune to ransomware extortion. Recovery time drops from weeks to hours. Cyber insurers require this strategy as a minimum standard.
backup-3-2-1.nextStep: Check your current backup situation with our checklist and implement the missing elements of the 3-2-1 rule.

legal.nis2: Backup management and recovery concepts as part of risk measures
legal.dsgvo: Ability to restore availability and access to personal data promptly
legal.dora: Guidelines and procedures for data backup and recovery
legal.bsi: Data backup concept with regular testing

verschluesselung.name: Encryption
verschluesselung.scenario:
A field sales representative has their laptop stolen from their car. On it: customer lists, quotes, contracts. Without disk encryption, the thief can simply read all data. Result: mandatory GDPR Art. 33 notification, notification of all affected customers, €15,000 fine.

With BitLocker (Windows) or FileVault (Mac), the laptop would have been worthless.
verschluesselung.solution:
1. Enable disk encryption on all endpoints (BitLocker/FileVault)
2. Encrypt USB drives and external media (BitLocker To Go)
3. Email encryption for sensitive communications (S/MIME or PGP)
4. Database encryption for personal data (TDE)
5. Store recovery keys centrally and securely
verschluesselung.benefit: Encryption turns device loss from catastrophe to inconvenience. With encrypted data, GDPR notification requirements may not apply. Reduces potential fines by up to 90%.
verschluesselung.nextStep: Enable BitLocker on all Windows devices. Your first laptop is protected in 15 minutes.

legal.nis2: Use of cryptography and encryption as a security measure
legal.dsgvo: Encryption of personal data as a technical protection measure
legal.dora: Protection of ICT systems and data through encryption
legal.tisax: Cryptographic protection of information assets per VDA ISA Assessment Level 5.1
legal.bsi: Crypto concept and use of cryptographic procedures

datenklassifizierung.name: Data Classification
datenklassifizierung.scenario:
An intern shares an internal price list on LinkedIn because it wasn't marked as confidential. A competitor uses the information to poach customers. Without data classification, employees don't know which information needs what level of protection.

Every company has data at different protection levels — but few make this transparent.
datenklassifizierung.solution:
1. Define four protection levels: Public, Internal, Confidential, Strictly Confidential
2. Implement labeling system (document footers, email tags)
3. Per level: who may access? How is it stored? How is it shared?
4. Classify existing data (involve department heads)
5. New documents: classification becomes mandatory field
datenklassifizierung.benefit: Data classification prevents accidental data leaks and enables targeted protection measures. Reduces data protection effort by 30% because not everything needs the highest protection level.
datenklassifizierung.nextStep: Create your classification scheme with our template. Start with the three most important departments.

legal.nis2: Inventory and protection of critical information assets
legal.dsgvo: Classification of personal data by risk and protection needs
legal.tisax: Classification and protection of information assets
legal.bsi: Protection needs assessment and classification of information

4.name: Systems & Operations
4.description: Patch management, logging and SIEM, shadow IT management, and secure system administration for ongoing IT operations.

patch-management.name: Patch Management
patch-management.scenario:
December 2021: The Log4Shell vulnerability is disclosed. Companies with functioning patch management had the fix deployed within 72 hours. A mid-size retail company without a process took 4 weeks — during which their systems were compromised and customer data stolen.

60% of all successful attacks exploit known vulnerabilities for which patches already exist.
patch-management.solution:
1. Create inventory of all systems and software (automated with WSUS, Intune, or open source)
2. Critical patches: deploy within 72h of release
3. Regular patches: monthly patch cycle (e.g., first Tuesday)
4. Test environment: briefly test patches before production rollout
5. Legacy systems: isolate if patching impossible (network segmentation)
patch-management.benefit: Regular patching prevents 60% of all cyberattacks. Automated patch management saves 10h/week of admin effort. Mandatory requirement for NIS2 and CRA.
patch-management.nextStep: Create your software inventory and define your patch cycle. Start with the most critical systems.

legal.nis2: System security during acquisition, development, and maintenance including vulnerability management
legal.cra: Obligation to provide security updates throughout the product lifecycle
legal.dora: Management and documentation of changes to ICT systems
legal.bsi: Regular updating and patch management for all IT systems

logging-siem.name: Logging & SIEM
logging-siem.scenario:
A company discovers after 6 months that an attacker had access to the mail server. The forensics team asks: 'Show us the logs.' Answer: 'Logs are overwritten after 7 days.' Without logging, it's impossible to determine what was stolen, how the attacker got in, and whether they're still there.

No logs, no evidence. No evidence, no forensics. No forensics, no insurance payout.
logging-siem.solution:
1. Set up central log collection (syslog server, ELK Stack, or Graylog)
2. Minimum logging: logins, errors, changes, network access
3. Log retention: minimum 6 months (NIS2 recommendation: 12 months)
4. Alerting: automatic notification on suspicious patterns
5. Regular log review: check the most important alerts weekly
logging-siem.benefit: Central logging halves the time to detect security incidents (from 207 to ~100 days). Logs are the foundation for forensics, insurance claims, and regulatory reporting.
logging-siem.nextStep: Set up central log collection. Start with login logs from your most critical systems.

legal.nis2: Ability to detect and manage security incidents
legal.dora: Logging and monitoring of ICT operations
legal.kritis: Deployment of intrusion detection systems per BSIG Section 8a Para. 1
legal.bsi: Logging of security-relevant events and analysis

schatten-it.name: Shadow IT Management
schatten-it.scenario:
The marketing director installs an AI translator from the internet to create product texts for the French market. The service stores all entered texts on US servers — including unreleased product names and prices. Three months later, the data appears at a competitor.

Meanwhile: a team leader uses a free project management tool. Customer data is uploaded — GDPR violation. The supervisory authority imposes a €20,000 fine.

Shadow IT: software used without IT's knowledge. On average, every company has 5× more apps than officially known.
schatten-it.solution:
1. Inventory: network scan + employee survey — which tools are actually being used?
2. Implement approval process: simple form (name, purpose, data requirements, costs)
3. Management approval for new software installations
4. Security check: VirusTotal scan, privacy review, license check
5. Quarterly review: what new shadow IT has appeared?
6. Maintain whitelist: communicate approved tools for each use case
schatten-it.benefit: Shadow IT management reduces unknown risks by 90%. You save license costs through consolidation (often 20-30% savings). Audit evidence: controlled software usage. Cyber insurers grant up to 15% discount.
schatten-it.nextStep: Conduct a shadow IT inventory. Use our application form and review checklist as templates.

legal.nis2: Supply chain security including assessment of deployed software and services
legal.dsgvo: Data processing: only verified and approved services for personal data
legal.cra: Assessment and documentation of deployed software components and their risks
legal.tisax: Control and approval of deployed information processing systems
legal.bsi: Regulations for handling unapproved software per BSI OPS.1.2.5

5.name: Networks & Perimeter
5.description: Firewall configuration, network segmentation, VPN security, and protection of your organization's network boundaries.

next-gen-firewall.name: Next-Generation Firewall
next-gen-firewall.scenario:
A craft business uses an 8-year-old consumer router as its only firewall. An attacker exploits a known vulnerability and enters the network. From there, they spread laterally — file server, accounting, email server: everything compromised.

A modern NGFW recognizes not just ports but applications and threat patterns. It's the bouncer who doesn't just check IDs but also watches behavior.
next-gen-firewall.solution:
1. Choose NGFW: OPNsense (free), Sophos XGS, FortiGate (SME models from €500)
2. Basic rules: deny-all as default, only explicitly allowed connections
3. Enable IDS/IPS: intrusion detection and prevention
4. Geo-blocking: block countries with no business relationships
5. Regular rule review: remove outdated rules quarterly
next-gen-firewall.benefit: An NGFW blocks 95% of automated attacks. IDS/IPS detects anomalies in real time. OPNsense as open-source costs only hardware (~€300). Mandatory for NIS2-regulated companies.
next-gen-firewall.nextStep: Evaluate your current firewall solution. Check if IDS/IPS is enabled and if rules are up to date.

legal.nis2: Network security and protection of communication infrastructure
legal.dora: Protection mechanisms for networks and communication channels
legal.bsi: Securing network transitions and firewalling
legal.kritis: Protection of critical infrastructure components from network attacks

segmentierung.name: Network Segmentation
segmentierung.scenario:
A manufacturing plant has IT and OT in the same network. An employee opens an infected email — the trojan spreads not only to office PCs but also to machine controls. Production standstill for 2 weeks, damage: €500,000.

Network segmentation is like fire doors: a fire in the kitchen doesn't have to destroy the whole building.
segmentierung.solution:
1. Define network zones: office, server, production/OT, guest WiFi, IoT
2. Set up VLANs: each zone gets its own VLAN
3. Firewall rules between zones: allow only necessary communication
4. Separate management network: admin access only from dedicated networks
5. Document network plan and keep it up to date
segmentierung.benefit: Segmentation limits the spread of attacks to one zone. Reduces damage in incidents by an average of 70%. Mandatory for KRITIS operators and NIS2.
segmentierung.nextStep: Draw your current network plan and identify missing segmentation. Start with separating guest WiFi and production network.

legal.nis2: Network segmentation as part of risk measures
legal.kritis: Separation of IT and OT networks in critical infrastructure
legal.dora: Segmentation of ICT networks for damage limitation
legal.tisax: Network segmentation for automotive data protection per VDA ISA Assessment Level 5.2
legal.bsi: Network segmentation and controlled network transitions

vpn.name: VPN & Remote Access
vpn.scenario:
A sales rep uses hotel WiFi to access webmail without VPN. An attacker on the same network intercepts login credentials (man-in-the-middle). With these credentials, they log into the CRM system and export 5,000 customer records.

Every remote access without VPN is like a postcard: everyone along the way can read it.
vpn.solution:
1. Choose VPN solution: WireGuard (modern, fast), OpenVPN (proven), or IPsec
2. VPN mandatory for every remote access to company resources
3. Disable split tunneling: route all traffic through VPN
4. Certificate-based authentication + MFA
5. Regularly patch VPN gateway (frequent attack target!)
vpn.benefit: VPN encrypts all data traffic and protects against eavesdropping. WireGuard is easy to set up and free. Remote work becomes securely possible without productivity loss.
vpn.nextStep: Set up WireGuard on your router or a VM. You'll have secure remote access in 30 minutes.

legal.nis2: Communication security and encrypted data transmission
legal.dsgvo: Secure transmission of personal data over public networks
legal.dora: Secure communication channels for ICT systems
legal.bsi: Securing remote access and VPN connections

6.name: Applications & Cloud
6.description: Shared responsibility, Software Bill of Materials (SBOM), API security, and cloud auditing for secure application landscapes.

shared-responsibility.name: Shared Responsibility & Cloud Audit
shared-responsibility.scenario:
An online shop migrates to the cloud. The CEO assumes: 'Amazon takes care of security.' Six months later: customer data leaked because S3 buckets were publicly accessible. AWS is not liable — responsibility for data access lies with the customer.

'The provider secures the hardware, you secure your data.' 70% of SMEs don't understand this sentence — until it's too late.
shared-responsibility.solution:
1. Understand the shared responsibility model (see interactive diagram above)
2. Document per cloud service: what does the provider secure, what do we?
3. Review IAM rights: who has access to cloud resources? Least privilege!
4. Enable logging: CloudTrail (AWS), Activity Log (Azure), Cloud Audit (GCP)
5. Quarterly cloud audit: open ports, public resources, unused accounts
shared-responsibility.benefit: A clear responsibility model prevents the most common cloud misconfigurations (cause of 80% of cloud data breaches). The quarterly audit finds vulnerabilities before attackers do.
shared-responsibility.nextStep: Use the interactive diagram above to understand your responsibility model. Then: work through the cloud audit checklist.

legal.nis2: Supply chain security and assessment of third-party providers
legal.dsgvo: Data processing in the cloud with documented responsibility boundaries
legal.dora: Monitoring of ICT third-party service providers and their security measures
legal.cra: Security requirements for deployed cloud services and platforms
legal.bsi: Use of cloud services with defined responsibility model per BSI OPS.2.2

sbom.name: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
sbom.scenario:
Log4Shell (2021) affected millions of systems. The first question: 'Do we use Log4j?' Companies without SBOM needed weeks to clarify. With SBOM: one look at the inventory, instant clarity.

An SBOM is the ingredient list of your software — you know exactly which libraries are in your products and whether any are vulnerable.
sbom.solution:
1. Deploy SBOM generator: CycloneDX, Syft, or GitHub Dependency Graph
2. Create an SBOM for each product/application
3. Automatic vulnerability check: match SBOM against CVE databases
4. Integrate into CI/CD pipeline: generate new SBOM with each build
5. Document SBOMs and keep available for audits
sbom.benefit: SBOMs reduce response time to new vulnerabilities from weeks to minutes. Mandatory for all products with digital elements from 2027 (CRA). Early adoption provides competitive advantage.
sbom.nextStep: Generate your first SBOM with Syft or GitHub Dependency Graph. Check it against the CVE database.

legal.nis2: Vulnerability management and knowledge of deployed software components
legal.cra: Obligation to create and maintain an SBOM for products with digital elements
legal.dora: Documentation of deployed ICT systems and their dependencies
legal.bsi: Inventory and documentation of deployed software

api-sicherheit.name: API Security
api-sicherheit.scenario:
A fintech startup offers a payment API. A security researcher discovers: by manipulating API parameters, account balances of other users can be queried. The API had no rate limiting, no input validation, and no authentication for sensitive endpoints.

APIs are the backdoor of modern applications — and often wide open.
api-sicherheit.solution:
1. Authentication: OAuth 2.0 for all API endpoints
2. Rate limiting: limit max requests per minute per client
3. Input validation: validate all parameters (type, length, format)
4. Use OWASP API Security Top 10 as checklist
5. Deploy API gateway: central monitoring and access control
api-sicherheit.benefit: Secure APIs prevent data leaks and abuse. Rate limiting stops automated attacks. OWASP-compliant APIs pass penetration tests and reduce the attack surface by 80%.
api-sicherheit.nextStep: Check your APIs against the OWASP API Security Top 10. Implement OAuth 2.0 and rate limiting as first steps.

legal.nis2: Security in development and maintenance of information systems
legal.dsgvo: Data protection by design and by default
legal.dora: Security requirements for ICT interfaces and data flows
legal.cra: Security requirements for interfaces of products with digital elements per CRA Annex I Part I No. 2
legal.bsi: Secure development and operation of web applications and APIs

7.name: Endpoints & Mobile
7.description: Mobile device management, endpoint detection & response, BYOD policies, and protection of all enterprise endpoints.

mdm.name: Mobile Device Management (MDM)
mdm.scenario:
An employee's company phone with all emails, contacts, and access credentials is stolen. Without MDM, there's no way to remotely wipe the device. Three days later, phishing emails are sent to customers via the email account.

MDM = remote control for company devices. Wipe, lock, locate — in seconds.
mdm.solution:
1. Choose MDM solution: Microsoft Intune (included in M365 Business), Jamf, or MobileIron
2. Register all company devices: laptops, smartphones, tablets
3. Configure policies: screen lock, encryption, app whitelist
4. Set up remote wipe: make device remotely erasable
5. Automatic compliance checks: devices without updates = no access
mdm.benefit: MDM enables remote wipe in under 60 seconds. Lost devices become non-events instead of disasters. Intune is included in many Microsoft 365 Business plans.
mdm.nextStep: Enable Microsoft Intune or a comparable MDM solution. Start with management devices.

legal.nis2: Security management for mobile devices and remote access
legal.dsgvo: Protection of personal data on mobile devices
legal.tisax: Securing mobile devices and their management
legal.bsi: Regulations for mobile devices and telework

endpoint-detection.name: Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR)
endpoint-detection.scenario:
A classic antivirus reports: 'No threat found.' Meanwhile, fileless ransomware encrypts the server in the background — the scanner doesn't detect it because no classic virus is involved.

EDR goes beyond traditional antivirus: it detects suspicious behavior instead of just known signatures. Like a security camera that doesn't just look for known faces but reports suspicious behavior.
endpoint-detection.solution:
1. Evaluate EDR solution: CrowdStrike, SentinelOne, or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint
2. Deploy on all endpoints and servers
3. Configure alerting: who gets notified? Define escalation path
4. Response playbooks: what to do for different alert types?
5. Regular tuning: reduce false positives, add new threat patterns
endpoint-detection.benefit: EDR detects 99% of modern threats that classic scanners miss. Automatic isolation of compromised endpoints in seconds. Microsoft Defender for Endpoint is included in M365 E5.
endpoint-detection.nextStep: Evaluate Microsoft Defender for Endpoint or CrowdStrike Falcon Go. Start with a pilot rollout on 10 devices.

legal.nis2: Attack detection and defense systems on endpoints
legal.dora: Detection of anomalous activities on ICT systems
legal.bsi: Protection against malware on all IT systems

byod.name: BYOD Separation
byod.scenario:
Employees use personal smartphones for business email. A child downloads an infected game — the trojan accesses business emails and exfiltrates customer data. Or the reverse: upon termination, IT wipes the entire device — including personal photos.

BYOD without container solution = personal and business mixed. Risk for both sides.
byod.solution:
1. Deploy container solution: Microsoft Intune App Protection, Samsung Knox, or Workspace ONE
2. Business apps in separate container: email, calendar, files
3. Clear policy: what can the company do on personal devices? What not?
4. On departure: only delete container, personal data stays
5. Minimum requirements: current OS, screen lock, no root/jailbreak
byod.benefit: Container solutions enable secure BYOD without privacy intrusion. Saves device costs (€200-500 per employee). Clear separation protects both sides upon termination.
byod.nextStep: Define your BYOD policy and choose a container solution. Intune App Protection is included in many M365 plans.

legal.nis2: Security policies for the use of personal devices
legal.dsgvo: Protection of personal data on employees' personal devices
legal.tisax: Regulations for the use of personal devices (BYOD)
legal.bsi: Use of personal IT devices for business purposes

8.name: Resilience & Crisis
8.description: Incident response plan, reporting timer, business continuity, penetration testing, and crisis management for emergencies.

incident-response.name: Incident Response Plan & Reporting Timer
incident-response.scenario:
Friday evening, 10:00 PM: the admin discovers encrypted files on the server. Ransomware. What now?

Without a plan: panic, frantic calls, wrong decisions. Servers are shut down instead of isolated, evidence is destroyed, the authority notification arrives too late. Fine: €100,000.

With a plan: calm execution of the checklist. Isolate systems, secure forensics, notify authority within 24h. Restore from backup on Monday.

The difference: a tested plan.
incident-response.solution:
1. Define incident response team: who gets called? (IT lead, CEO, DPO, external if needed)
2. Communication plan: phone numbers (not just email!), escalation paths
3. First aid measures: isolate (don't shut down!), screenshots, secure logs
4. Know and comply with reporting deadlines (see reporting timer above)
5. Prepare templates: initial report, detailed report, final report
6. Annual exercise: tabletop exercise with simulated incident
incident-response.benefit: A tested IRP reduces damage by an average of 60% and recovery time by 70%. Reporting deadlines are met — no fines. Insurers require an IRP as minimum standard.
incident-response.nextStep: Create your incident response plan with our template. Define your team and test the plan with a tabletop exercise.

legal.nis2: Incident handling with initial notification within 24h
legal.dsgvo: Notification of data breaches to the supervisory authority within 72h
legal.dora: ICT-related incident management with initial notification within 4h
legal.kritis: Reporting obligation for significant disruptions to BSI
legal.bsi: Security incident handling per BSI DER.2.1

business-continuity.name: Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
business-continuity.scenario:
A flood inundates a logistics company's data center. All servers underwater. Without BCP: 3 weeks total outage, customers switch to competitors, €2 million revenue loss.

With BCP: cloud failover kicks in, employees work from home, customer communication runs through prepared channels. Productivity at 80% after 4 hours.

The BCP is your answer to: 'What if everything fails?'
business-continuity.solution:
1. Identify critical business processes: what must run again in 4h/24h/72h?
2. Set RTO: Recovery Time Objective per system (maximum downtime)
3. Set RPO: Recovery Point Objective (maximum data loss in hours)
4. Document recovery plans per critical system
5. Prepare alternative workplaces and communication channels
6. Semi-annual BCP test: do RTO/RPO match reality?
business-continuity.benefit: A BCP reduces downtime by 60-80%. Companies with BCP survive crisis events at 90%, without only at 50%. Mandatory for NIS2, KRITIS, and DORA.
business-continuity.nextStep: Identify your 5 most critical business processes and define RTO/RPO for each. Use our BCP template.

legal.nis2: Business continuity and crisis management
legal.dora: Business continuity policy and ICT emergency plans
legal.bsi: Emergency management and business continuity per BSI Standard 200-4

pentests.name: Penetration Testing
pentests.scenario:
An online retailer commissions a penetration test for the first time. Result: within 2 hours, the tester has admin access to the shop and customer database. SQL injection, default passwords, missing updates — all obvious but never checked internally.

Penetration tests are the most honest mirror of your IT security: an ethical hacker shows you what a criminal would find.
pentests.solution:
1. Define scope: what gets tested? (External, internal, web apps, social engineering)
2. Choose provider: prefer BSI-certified or CREST-accredited
3. Timeline: external test 3-5 days, internal test 5-10 days
4. Prioritize results: critical → high → medium → low
5. Retest: 3 months after fixing critical findings, test again
6. Budget: from €5,000 for external test, from €10,000 for comprehensive internal + external
pentests.benefit: Pentests find vulnerabilities before attackers exploit them. The ROI: one prevented incident saves on average 50-100× the test cost. DORA requires threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) for financial companies.
pentests.nextStep: Get quotes from 2-3 pentesting providers. Start with an external test of your web presence.

legal.dora: Threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) for critical financial companies
legal.bsi: Regular review of security measures through audits and tests

security.description: Protection of information and systems against unauthorized access through logical and physical access controls (CC1–CC9).

availability.name: Availability
availability.description: Ensuring that systems and services are available and operational as committed in service-level agreements (A1.1–A1.3).

processingIntegrity.name: Processing Integrity
processingIntegrity.description: Ensuring that system processing is complete, accurate, timely, and authorized (PI1.1–PI1.5).

confidentiality.name: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: Protection of confidential information in accordance with the organization's commitments and business requirements (C1.1–C1.2).

privacy.name: Privacy
privacy.description: Collection, use, retention, disclosure, and disposal of personal information in conformity with privacy principles (P1–P8).

monitoring.name: Monitoring & Logging
monitoring.description: Continuous monitoring, detection, and analysis of security-relevant events and incidents (CC7–CC8).

riskManagement.name: Risk Management & Governance
riskManagement.description: Organizational governance, risk identification, assessment, and treatment as the foundation for all control activities (CC1–CC3).

secQ1.title: How is logical access control to your systems and data implemented?
secQ1.tooltip: Relates to CC6.1: Logical access controls to restrict access to authorized users.
secQ1.help: Assess whether your organization has implemented authentication and authorization mechanisms that restrict access to systems, applications, and data to authorized individuals.

maturity.level0: No formal access controls. Users have largely unrestricted access to systems and data.
maturity.level1: Basic password authentication in place, but no unified access management or regular reviews.
maturity.level2: Centralized Identity & Access Management with role-based access control (RBAC), regular access reviews, and documented processes.
maturity.level3: Zero-trust architecture with MFA, continuous access validation, automated provisioning/deprovisioning, and real-time anomaly detection.

secQ2.title: How do you manage user registration, authorization, and deprovisioning?
secQ2.tooltip: Relates to CC6.2, CC6.3: Registration and authorization of new users and removal of access.
secQ2.help: Assess the lifecycle of user accounts — from creation through modifications to deactivation upon departure.

maturity.level0: No defined processes for user creation or removal. Accounts remain active after departure.
maturity.level1: Manual processes exist but without standardized approval workflows. Deprovisioning is delayed.
maturity.level2: Standardized joiner-mover-leaver process with approval workflows, SLA for deprovisioning, and regular recertifications.
maturity.level3: Fully automated identity lifecycle management with HR integration, real-time deprovisioning, and compliance reporting.

secQ3.title: How do you protect data in transit and at rest (encryption)?
secQ3.tooltip: Relates to CC6.6, CC6.7: Protection of confidential data during transmission and storage.
secQ3.help: Assess your encryption strategy for data-in-transit and data-at-rest including key management.

maturity.level0: No systematic encryption. Data is transmitted and stored in plaintext.
maturity.level1: TLS/HTTPS for external connections, but no comprehensive encryption of internal data flows or stored data.
maturity.level2: End-to-end TLS 1.2+ encryption for transit, AES-256 for storage, documented key management with rotation.
maturity.level3: End-to-end encryption with HSM-backed key management, automatic key rotation, crypto-agility strategy, and regular cryptographic assessments.

secQ4.title: How do you handle physical security of your IT infrastructure?
secQ4.tooltip: Relates to CC6.8: Protection of physical facilities and infrastructure.
secQ4.help: Assess physical access controls to data centers, server rooms, and other critical locations.

maturity.level0: No physical access controls. Server rooms are freely accessible.
maturity.level1: Basic key-based protection in place, but no logging or visitor policies.
maturity.level2: Electronic access control with badge systems, video surveillance, visitor management, and documented access logs.
maturity.level3: Multi-factor physical access control (badge + biometrics), 24/7 surveillance, environmental sensors, automated alarm systems, and regular physical security penetration tests.

avlQ1.title: How do you ensure the availability of your critical systems?
avlQ1.tooltip: Relates to A1.1: Capacity management and availability planning.
avlQ1.help: Assess your measures to ensure system availability including capacity planning and redundancy concepts.

maturity.level0: No availability planning. System outages are only addressed when they occur.
maturity.level1: Basic redundancy for individual components, but no comprehensive availability concept.
maturity.level2: Documented SLAs with defined availability targets, capacity planning, redundancy for critical systems, and regular performance monitoring.
maturity.level3: High-availability architecture with automatic failover, predictive capacity planning, SLA compliance >99.9%, and continuous optimization.

avlQ2.title: Do you have backup and recovery procedures in place?
avlQ2.tooltip: Relates to A1.2: Backup, recovery, and data retention.
avlQ2.help: Assess your data backup and disaster recovery strategies.

maturity.level0: No regular backups. No documented recovery plan.
maturity.level1: Daily backups in place, but no regular recovery tests or documented recovery times.
maturity.level2: Automated backup strategy (3-2-1 rule) with defined RPO/RTO targets, regular restore tests, and offsite copies.
maturity.level3: Continuous data protection with geo-redundant backups, automated restore tests, documented RTO <1h/RPO <15min, and regular DR exercises.

avlQ3.title: How is your disaster recovery plan structured?
avlQ3.tooltip: Relates to A1.3: Recovery planning and testing.
avlQ3.help: Assess whether a documented and tested disaster recovery plan exists.

maturity.level0: No disaster recovery plan in place.
maturity.level1: Basic DR plan exists but has not been tested or is outdated.
maturity.level2: Documented DR plan with defined recovery priorities, annual tests, and clear responsibilities.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive BCP/DR plan with automated failover, semi-annual tabletop exercises, measured recovery times, and continuous improvement.

avlQ4.title: How do you monitor service levels and system performance?
avlQ4.tooltip: Relates to A1.2, A1.3: Ongoing performance monitoring and SLA compliance.
avlQ4.help: Assess your monitoring for system availability, performance, and SLA compliance.

maturity.level0: No systematic monitoring of system performance or availability.
maturity.level1: Basic monitoring (ping/uptime) but no SLA measurement or proactive alerting.
maturity.level2: Comprehensive application performance monitoring with SLA dashboards, automated alerts, and monthly reporting.
maturity.level3: AIOps-powered monitoring with predictive analytics, automatic scaling, real-time SLA tracking, and capacity forecasting.

piQ1.title: How do you ensure the accuracy and completeness of data processing?
piQ1.tooltip: Relates to PI1.1: Validation of input data and processing results.
piQ1.help: Assess your controls to ensure that data is processed accurately, completely, and in an authorized manner.

maturity.level0: No systematic input validations or processing controls.
maturity.level1: Basic validations in individual applications, but no overarching concept.
maturity.level2: Standardized input validation, processing controls, and output reconciliation with documented validation rules.
maturity.level3: Automated end-to-end data integrity checks with real-time anomaly detection, automatic error handling, and comprehensive audit trail.

piQ2.title: How do you handle errors and exceptions in data processing?
piQ2.tooltip: Relates to PI1.2, PI1.3: Error handling and exception management.
piQ2.help: Assess your processes for dealing with processing errors, exceptions, and corrections.

maturity.level0: No defined processes for error handling. Errors are corrected on an ad-hoc basis.
maturity.level1: Manual error detection and correction without standardized escalation paths.
maturity.level2: Documented error handling processes with automated detection, escalation matrix, and root cause analysis.
maturity.level3: Automated error handling with self-healing mechanisms, proactive error prevention, and continuous process improvement cycle.

piQ3.title: How do you ensure traceability of data changes (audit trail)?
piQ3.tooltip: Relates to PI1.4, PI1.5: Comprehensive logging of all data changes.
piQ3.help: Assess your ability to traceably document and verify all data changes.

maturity.level0: No audit trails or change logs for critical data.
maturity.level1: Basic logs in individual systems, but no unified audit trail strategy.
maturity.level2: Centralized audit logging with immutable records, defined retention periods, and regular reviews.
maturity.level3: Tamper-proof audit trail with blockchain/WORM storage, automated anomaly detection, and real-time compliance monitoring.

confQ1.title: How do you identify and classify confidential information?
confQ1.tooltip: Relates to C1.1: Identification and protection of confidential information.
confQ1.help: Assess whether your organization systematically identifies, classifies, and appropriately protects confidential data.

maturity.level0: No data classification. Confidential information is not identified.
maturity.level1: Informal classification at department level, but no enterprise-wide scheme.
maturity.level2: Documented data classification scheme with handling guidelines for each level, regular reviews, and basic DLP capabilities.
maturity.level3: Automated data classification with AI-powered detection, DLP enforcement, data flow mapping, and continuous classification audit.

confQ2.title: How do you protect confidential data throughout its lifecycle?
confQ2.tooltip: Relates to C1.2: Disposal of confidential information and lifecycle management.
confQ2.help: Assess the protection of confidential data from creation through secure destruction.

maturity.level0: No defined data lifecycle. Data is retained without secure deletion procedures.
maturity.level1: Basic deletion policies exist but no systematic implementation or tracking.
maturity.level2: Documented data lifecycle management process with retention schedules, secure deletion (NIST 800-88), and regular reviews.
maturity.level3: Fully automated data lifecycle management with policy engine, automatic archival/deletion, cryptographic erasure, and compliance evidence.

confQ3.title: How do you control third-party access to confidential information?
confQ3.tooltip: Relates to C1.1, C1.2: Confidentiality protection when sharing with third parties.
confQ3.help: Assess your contractual and technical controls for protecting confidential data when sharing with partners and service providers.

maturity.level0: No contractual confidentiality agreements or technical controls for third parties.
maturity.level1: Standard NDAs in place, but no technical controls or monitoring of third-party access.
maturity.level2: NDAs with specific data protection clauses, technical access restrictions for third parties, and regular vendor assessments.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive third-party risk management with automated compliance monitoring, data room controls, real-time logging, and contractual audit rights.

privQ1.title: How do you inform data subjects about the collection and use of their data?
privQ1.tooltip: Relates to P1.1, P2.1: Privacy notices and consent management.
privQ1.help: Assess your transparency toward data subjects regarding data collection, use, and sharing.

maturity.level0: No privacy notices. Data subjects are not informed about data processing.
maturity.level1: Basic privacy policy on the website, but not current or incomplete.
maturity.level2: Comprehensive, up-to-date privacy notice with just-in-time notices, cookie consent management, and documented consent process.
maturity.level3: Dynamic privacy notices with granular consent management, preference center, automated consent lifecycle management, and multi-language support.

privQ2.title: How do you manage consent and data collection for personal data?
privQ2.tooltip: Relates to P3.1, P3.2: Consent management and purpose limitation.
privQ2.help: Assess your processes for lawful collection of personal data with regard to purpose limitation.

maturity.level0: No consent processes. Data is collected without a clear legal basis.
maturity.level1: Basic consent forms available, but no systematic management or tracking.
maturity.level2: Consent management platform with opt-in/opt-out functionality, purpose limitation checks, and retention of consent evidence.
maturity.level3: Fully automated consent lifecycle management with granular purpose controls, automatic consent expiration, API integration, and real-time compliance dashboard.

privQ3.title: How do you fulfill data subject rights (access, deletion, rectification)?
privQ3.tooltip: Relates to P4.1, P4.2, P4.3: Rights of data subjects.
privQ3.help: Assess your ability to process data subject requests in a timely and complete manner.

maturity.level0: No process for handling data subject requests.
maturity.level1: Requests are handled ad hoc via email without standardized timelines or documentation.
maturity.level2: Documented DSR (Data Subject Request) process with self-service portal, SLA monitoring, and escalation procedures.
maturity.level3: Automated DSR workflow with self-service portal, automatic data discovery across all systems, deadline monitoring, and compliance reporting.

privQ4.title: How do you ensure secure retention and disposal of personal data?
privQ4.tooltip: Relates to P6.1, P6.7, P8.1: Retention, quality, and disposal of personal data.
privQ4.help: Assess your policies for retention, quality assurance, and secure deletion of personal data.

maturity.level0: No retention periods defined. Personal data is stored indefinitely.
maturity.level1: Basic retention policy in place, but no automated enforcement.
maturity.level2: Defined retention periods per data category with automated deletion, data quality checks, and documented disposal records.
maturity.level3: Policy-driven automatic data deletion with cryptographic erasure, data quality monitoring, and comprehensive disposal evidence.

monQ1.title: How do you monitor your systems for security events?
monQ1.tooltip: Relates to CC7.1, CC7.2: Monitoring of infrastructure and software.
monQ1.help: Assess your ability to detect and process security-relevant events in real time.

maturity.level0: No systematic security monitoring. Incidents are only noticed after damage has occurred.
maturity.level1: Basic log management with manual analysis, but no real-time monitoring.
maturity.level2: Centralized SIEM with defined correlation rules, automated alerts, and regular rule updates.
maturity.level3: SOAR platform with AI-powered anomaly detection, automated triage, threat intelligence integration, and 24/7 SOC.

monQ2.title: How do you analyze and respond to detected security incidents?
monQ2.tooltip: Relates to CC7.3, CC7.4: Assessment and response to anomalies and incidents.
monQ2.help: Assess your incident response process from detection through remediation.

maturity.level0: No incident response process. Incidents are not systematically addressed.
maturity.level1: Ad-hoc response to incidents without a standardized process or documentation.
maturity.level2: Documented incident response plan with escalation matrix, runbooks, post-incident review, and regular exercises.
maturity.level3: Automated incident response process with SOAR playbooks, ML-powered prioritization, automatic containment actions, and real-time forensics.

monQ3.title: How do you document and improve your monitoring and response processes?
monQ3.tooltip: Relates to CC7.5, CC8.1: Remediation and change management after incidents.
monQ3.help: Assess how you learn from incidents and continuously improve your monitoring processes.

maturity.level0: No lessons-learned processes or documentation of past incidents.
maturity.level1: Incidents are documented, but no systematic follow-up or process improvement.
maturity.level2: Structured post-incident reviews with documented lessons learned, KPI tracking, and regular revision of monitoring rules.
maturity.level3: Continuous improvement cycle with automated KPI collection, benchmark comparisons, threat modeling updates, and resilience metrics.

govQ1.title: How is the governance structure for information security organized in your company?
govQ1.tooltip: Relates to CC1.1, CC1.2: COSO control environment and management responsibility.
govQ1.help: Assess the organizational anchoring of information security including roles, responsibilities, and reporting lines.

maturity.level0: No formal governance structure for information security.
maturity.level1: IT department handles security, but no formal governance or management accountability.
maturity.level2: Defined security organization with CISO/ISO, security committee, documented policies, and regular management reporting.
maturity.level3: Board-level governance with integrated GRC framework, real-time security dashboards, strategic security planning, and external audit readiness.

govQ2.title: How do you communicate security policies and responsibilities internally?
govQ2.tooltip: Relates to CC2.1, CC2.2, CC2.3: Internal and external communication.
govQ2.help: Assess the effectiveness of your internal communication on security topics, policies, and responsibilities.

maturity.level0: No formal communication of security policies to employees.
maturity.level1: Policies exist on the intranet but are not actively communicated or updated.
maturity.level2: Structured communication program with regular awareness campaigns, policy acknowledgment process, and defined communication channels.
maturity.level3: Comprehensive security culture program with gamified training, real-time communication, phishing simulations, and measurable behavioral change.

govQ3.title: How do you systematically identify and assess IT risks?
govQ3.tooltip: Relates to CC3.1, CC3.2: Risk assessment and identification of changes.
govQ3.help: Assess your risk management process including risk identification, assessment, and prioritization.

maturity.level0: No formal IT risk assessment. Risks are not systematically identified.
maturity.level1: Occasional risk assessments, but no standardized process or risk inventory.
maturity.level2: Structured risk management process with risk inventory, regular assessments, risk owner assignments, and documented risk acceptance.
maturity.level3: Integrated enterprise risk management with real-time risk monitoring, quantitative risk assessment, scenario analysis, and automated risk reporting.

govQ4.title: How do you manage changes and their impact on your control environment?
govQ4.tooltip: Relates to CC3.3, CC3.4: Change management and impact analysis.
govQ4.help: Assess how changes to systems, processes, and the organization are evaluated for their security implications.

maturity.level0: No change management process. Changes are made without risk assessment.
maturity.level1: Informal change process without standardized security impact evaluation.
maturity.level2: Documented change management with security impact analysis, approval workflow, rollback planning, and post-change review.
maturity.level3: Automated change management with CI/CD security gates, automated compliance checks, impact scoring, and continuous drift detection.

sec1.title: Implement Identity & Access Management
sec1.description: Implement centralized Identity & Access Management (IAM) with role-based access control, multi-factor authentication, and automated user lifecycle management. This is the foundation for all SOC 2 security controls.
sec1.firstStep: Create a complete inventory of all systems and their access accounts. Identify accounts not associated with active employees and disable them immediately.

sec2.title: Implement encryption strategy
sec2.description: Develop and implement a comprehensive encryption strategy for data in transit (TLS 1.2+) and at rest (AES-256). Establish documented key management with regular rotation and secure key storage.
sec2.firstStep: Inventory all data flows and storage locations. Identify unencrypted transmissions and storage, prioritize by data classification, and begin encrypting the most critical data.

sec3.title: Build network security architecture
sec3.description: Implement a multi-layered network security architecture with network segmentation, firewall rules, IDS/IPS, and zero-trust principles. Document all network zones and data flows.
sec3.firstStep: Create a current network diagram showing all zones, connections, and data flows. Identify missing segmentation and plan implementation in phases.
sec3.checklist: Network diagram created and current|Network segmentation implemented|Firewall rules documented and reviewed|IDS/IPS active and rules updated|DMZ set up for external services|VPN configured for remote access|Network monitoring active

avl1.title: Establish business continuity and backup strategy
avl1.description: Implement a comprehensive backup strategy following the 3-2-1 rule with defined RPO/RTO targets. Conduct regular restore tests and document the results.
avl1.firstStep: Define RPO and RTO targets for all critical systems together with business units. Verify whether your current backup solution meets these targets.

avl2.title: Create and test disaster recovery plan
avl2.description: Create a detailed disaster recovery plan with recovery priorities, contact lists, runbooks, and defined escalation paths. Test the plan at least annually.
avl2.firstStep: Create a prioritized list of all business-critical applications and systems. Define the recovery target and responsible contact person for each system.

avl3.title: Implement high-availability architecture
avl3.description: Implement high availability for business-critical systems with redundancy, automatic failover, load balancing, and geo-redundancy. Establish SLA monitoring with proactive alerting.
avl3.firstStep: Assess the current availability of your critical systems based on outage statistics. Identify single points of failure and plan redundancy measures.
avl3.checklist: Single points of failure identified|Redundancy for critical systems implemented|Automatic failover configured|Load balancing set up|SLA monitoring active|Geo-redundancy for Tier 1 systems|Annual DR test conducted

pi1.title: Introduce data validation and integrity controls
pi1.description: Implement systematic input validation, processing controls, and output reconciliation for all critical data processing operations. Establish automated integrity checks.
pi1.firstStep: Identify your top 10 critical data processing workflows. Document the expected inputs, processing rules, and outputs for each as a basis for validation rules.

pi2.title: Implement error handling and audit trail concept
pi2.description: Implement standardized error handling processes with automated detection, escalation, and documentation. Establish comprehensive audit trails for all critical data changes.
pi2.firstStep: Implement centralized audit logging for your three most important business applications. Ensure that at minimum user, timestamp, action, and affected data are logged.

conf1.title: Introduce data classification scheme
conf1.description: Define and implement an enterprise-wide data classification scheme with clear handling guidelines for each confidentiality level. Train all employees on its application.
conf1.firstStep: Define 3–4 confidentiality levels (e.g., Public, Internal, Confidential, Strictly Confidential) with clear handling rules each and communicate them to all employees.

conf2.title: Implement data lifecycle management
conf2.description: Implement systematic data lifecycle management with defined retention periods, automated archiving, and secure data deletion in accordance with NIST SP 800-88.
conf2.firstStep: Create a data inventory with classification, storage location, and current retention duration. Identify data stored beyond its intended retention period.

priv1.title: Build privacy notices and consent management
priv1.description: Create transparent, easy-to-understand privacy notices and implement structured consent management with opt-in/opt-out mechanisms and evidence retention.
priv1.firstStep: Review your current privacy notice for completeness and clarity. Ensure all data processing purposes, legal bases, and data subject rights are listed.

priv2.title: Establish data subject request process
priv2.description: Implement a documented process for handling data subject requests (access, deletion, rectification, portability) with defined SLAs and escalation procedures.
priv2.firstStep: Create a request form and internal workflow for data subject requests. Define processing timelines (max. 30 days) and responsibilities for each request type.

priv3.title: Build comprehensive privacy program
priv3.description: Establish a holistic privacy program with data protection impact assessments, privacy-by-design principles, vendor privacy assessments, and regular privacy audits.
priv3.firstStep: Create a record of processing activities for all personal data processing operations. Identify high-risk processing that requires a data protection impact assessment.
priv3.checklist: Record of processing activities complete|Data protection impact assessments for high-risk processing|Privacy-by-design embedded in development processes|Vendor privacy assessments conducted|Privacy training for all employees|Annual privacy audit conducted|Deletion concept implemented and automated

mon1.title: Introduce centralized log management and SIEM
mon1.description: Implement centralized log management with a SIEM solution for collection, correlation, and analysis of security-relevant events from all critical systems.
mon1.firstStep: Identify your 10 most important log sources (firewalls, servers, applications, identity provider). Forward these logs to a central platform and define initial correlation rules.

mon2.title: Develop and practice incident response plan
mon2.description: Create a documented incident response plan covering detection, analysis, containment, eradication, and recovery. Conduct regular tabletop exercises.
mon2.firstStep: Create an incident response plan with at minimum: contact list (internal/external), escalation matrix, classification scheme, and runbooks for the three most common incident types.

mon3.title: Build or outsource Security Operations Center (SOC)
mon3.description: Establish a Security Operations Center — in-house or as a managed SOC — for continuous monitoring, threat detection, incident response, and threat intelligence.
mon3.firstStep: Assess your need for 24/7 monitoring and compare build-vs-buy options. Obtain proposals from at least three managed SOC providers.
mon3.checklist: Build-vs-buy analysis completed|SOC operating model defined|Threat intelligence feeds integrated|Playbooks for top 10 incident types created|Escalation paths documented|KPIs defined (MTTD, MTTR)|Quarterly SOC effectiveness review

gov1.title: Establish security governance structure
gov1.description: Establish a formal security governance structure with defined roles (CISO/ISO), security committee, documented policies, and regular reporting to executive management.
gov1.firstStep: Appoint a responsible Information Security Officer (ISO/CISO) and establish a monthly security committee meeting with representatives from all business units.

gov2.title: Build integrated risk management framework
gov2.description: Implement a structured risk management framework with risk inventory, regular assessments, risk owner assignments, documented risk acceptance, and integration into corporate governance.
gov2.firstStep: Create an IT risk inventory with the top 20 risks. Assess each risk by likelihood and impact, and assign a responsible risk owner for each.
gov2.checklist: Risk management framework documented|Risk inventory with top 20 risks created|Risk owners assigned for all risks|Risk acceptance criteria approved by management|Quarterly risk assessment conducted|Risk management reporting to board|Change management process with security assessment

q1.title: Do you have centralized access management with multi-factor authentication?
q1.description: Includes Identity & Access Management, role-based access control, and MFA for all critical systems.

q2.title: Is data encrypted in transit and at rest?
q2.description: TLS/HTTPS for all data transfers and encryption of stored data (data-at-rest) using current standards.

q3.title: Is there a tested backup and disaster recovery plan?
q3.description: Regular backups with defined RPO/RTO targets and a recovery plan tested at least annually.

q4.title: Is data processing checked for accuracy and completeness?
q4.description: Systematic input validation, processing controls, and output reconciliation for critical business processes.

q5.title: Do you have a data classification scheme with handling guidelines?
q5.description: Enterprise-wide classification of confidential data with defined protection measures per confidentiality level.

q6.title: Are privacy notices current and is consent documented?
q6.description: Transparent privacy notices, documented consent management, and processes for data subject rights.

q7.title: Do you operate centralized log management or a SIEM?
q7.description: Central collection and correlation of security-relevant logs with automated alerting on anomalies.

q8.title: Is there a formal governance structure for information security?
q8.description: Defined security roles (CISO/ISO), security committee, documented policies, and management reporting.

q9.title: Do you have a documented incident response plan?
q9.description: Formal plan with escalation matrix, runbooks, contact lists, and regularly practiced scenarios.

q10.title: Are security events regularly analyzed and lessons learned documented?
q10.description: Structured post-incident reviews, KPI tracking, and continuous improvement of monitoring processes.

pciDss.name: PCI DSS
pciDss.fullName: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard v4.0
pciDss.description: Security standard for payment card data

networkSecurity.name: Network Security
networkSecurity.description: Build and maintain secure networks and systems to protect cardholder data (Req. 1-2)

dataProtection.name: Account Data Protection
dataProtection.description: Protect stored cardholder data and secure transmission over open, public networks (Req. 3-4)

vulnerabilityMgmt.name: Vulnerability Management
vulnerabilityMgmt.description: Protect against malware and securely develop and maintain systems and software (Req. 5-6)

accessControl.name: Access Control
accessControl.description: Restrict access to cardholder data based on need-to-know principle (Req. 7)

authentication.name: Authentication
authentication.description: Identify users and authenticate access to system components (Req. 8)

physicalSecurity.name: Physical Security
physicalSecurity.description: Restrict and monitor physical access to cardholder data (Req. 9)

monitoringTesting.name: Monitoring & Testing
monitoringTesting.description: Log and monitor all access to network resources and cardholder data, and regularly test security systems (Req. 10-11)

securityPolicy.name: Security Policies
securityPolicy.description: Maintain an information security policy for all personnel and contractors (Req. 12)

nsQ1.title: Are network security controls (NSCs) installed and configured to control access to the cardholder data environment (CDE)?
nsQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 1.2 requires network security controls (e.g., firewalls, segmentation solutions) to be installed and configured to control traffic between trusted and untrusted networks. All inbound and outbound connections must be documented and authorized.
nsQ1.help: Network security controls are the first line of defense protecting your cardholder data environment. You must deploy firewalls or equivalent technologies to restrict access to the CDE. Every rule must be documented with a business justification. Ensure that only necessary traffic is allowed and all other connections are blocked by default.

maturity.level0: No network security controls in place or configuration unknown; no overview of the cardholder data environment
maturity.level1: Firewalls present but rulesets not fully documented; CDE boundaries not clearly defined
maturity.level2: NSCs installed and configured with documented rulesets; CDE clearly delineated, but semi-annual rule review not yet established
maturity.level3: Comprehensive NSC architecture with fully documented and approved rulesets, clear CDE segmentation, semi-annual rule review, and automated detection of unauthorized connections

nsQ2.title: Is network access between the CDE and all other networks restricted?
nsQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 1.3 requires that network access between the CDE and all other networks — including internal networks and the internet — is restricted. Segmentation must prevent systems outside the CDE from directly accessing cardholder data.
nsQ2.help: Network segmentation is a core principle of PCI DSS. Your CDE must be isolated from all other networks. This means only systems that process or transmit cardholder data should reside within the CDE. All other systems must connect through controlled access points. Document all network flows and regularly verify that segmentation is effective.

maturity.level0: No network segmentation; CDE is on the same network as all other systems
maturity.level1: Basic segmentation present but not all transitions controlled; some non-CDE systems have direct access
maturity.level2: CDE segmented from other networks with controlled access points; network flow documentation present but penetration tests to validate segmentation still pending
maturity.level3: Complete network segmentation with documented and tested controls at all transition points, regular penetration tests to validate segmentation, and automated monitoring

nsQ3.title: Are system components securely configured to reduce known vulnerabilities?
nsQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 2.2 requires that secure configuration standards are developed and applied to all system components. Vendor-supplied default passwords and accounts must be changed or disabled. Unnecessary services, protocols, and functions must be removed or disabled.
nsQ3.help: Every system in your CDE must be configured according to documented hardening standards. This includes: changing all default passwords, disabling unnecessary services and protocols, configuring security parameters, and documenting the baseline configuration. Use recognized hardening guidelines such as CIS Benchmarks or DISA STIGs as a foundation.

maturity.level0: No hardening standards in place; systems deployed with default configurations
maturity.level1: Individual systems hardened but no consistent standard; default passwords partially still active
maturity.level2: Documented hardening standards for most system types present and applied; regular review planned
maturity.level3: Comprehensive hardening standards based on CIS Benchmarks or comparable frameworks, automated compliance checking, change management process for configuration changes, and regular audits

nsQ4.title: Are network security controls implemented for connections between trusted and untrusted networks?
nsQ4.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 1.4 requires that network traffic between trusted and untrusted networks is controlled. This includes both inbound and outbound traffic, with particular focus on securing wireless networks connected to the CDE.
nsQ4.help: Untrusted networks include the internet, guest networks, and uncontrolled wireless networks. Every connection between such networks and your CDE must be protected by NSCs. Wireless networks pose a particular risk — ensure that WPA3 or at minimum WPA2 with strong passwords is used and wireless networks do not reach directly into the CDE.

maturity.level0: No differentiated treatment of trusted and untrusted networks; WLAN without adequate security
maturity.level1: Basic separation present but wireless networks not fully secured; outbound traffic not controlled
maturity.level2: NSCs configured for all transitions, WLAN secured with WPA2/WPA3, but comprehensive logging and regular testing not yet established
maturity.level3: Complete NSC implementation for all network transitions, wireless networks isolated and encrypted, inbound/outbound traffic controlled and logged, regular wireless scans and penetration tests

dpQ1.title: Is storage of cardholder data limited to what is strictly necessary for business purposes?
dpQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 3.1-3.3 requires that storage of cardholder data is limited to the minimum needed for business, legal, or regulatory requirements. A data retention policy must define what data is stored, for how long, and when it is securely deleted.
dpQ1.help: The fundamental principle is: do not store cardholder data unless absolutely necessary. PCI DSS completely prohibits storage of sensitive authentication data (SAD) after authorization. For the primary account number (PAN), you must have a clear retention policy. Implement automated deletion processes and verify quarterly whether stored data is still needed.

maturity.level0: No overview of stored cardholder data; no retention policy in place
maturity.level1: Basic knowledge of storage locations but no formal retention policy; SAD may still be stored after authorization
maturity.level2: Data retention policy defined, storage locations documented, SAD storage eliminated, but automated deletion processes not yet fully implemented
maturity.level3: Complete data minimization with documented retention policy, automated data deletion after retention period expiry, quarterly review, and verifiably no storage of SAD after authorization

dpQ2.title: Is the primary account number (PAN) rendered unreadable by strong cryptography wherever it is stored?
dpQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 3.5 requires that the PAN is rendered unreadable everywhere it is stored — through one-way hashing, truncation, index tokens, or strong cryptography with associated key management processes.
dpQ2.help: If you must store the PAN, it must be protected. Accepted methods are: one-way hashing (e.g., SHA-256 with salt), truncation (display only first 6 and last 4 digits), index tokens and tokenization, or strong encryption (e.g., AES-256). Important: the encryption key must be stored separately from the encrypted data and managed according to a documented key management process.

maturity.level0: PAN stored in plaintext; no cryptography concept in place
maturity.level1: Partial encryption or masking of PAN but not at all storage locations; key management undocumented
maturity.level2: PAN encrypted or tokenized at most storage locations; key management process documented but rotation not yet automated
maturity.level3: PAN protected by strong cryptography at all storage locations, complete key management with automated rotation, split knowledge and dual control, regular cryptography audits

dpQ3.title: Is the PAN protected by strong cryptography during transmission over open, public networks?
dpQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 4.2 requires that the PAN is protected by strong cryptography during transmission over open, public networks. Only trusted keys and certificates may be used. TLS 1.2 or higher is required for all transmissions.
dpQ3.help: Every transmission of cardholder data over the internet, WLAN, or other public networks must be encrypted. Use TLS 1.2 or higher for all web-based transmissions. Ensure that only trusted certificates are used and weak encryption algorithms are disabled. Email transmission of PAN must also be encrypted (e.g., S/MIME or PGP).

maturity.level0: No encryption for cardholder data transmissions; PAN sent in plaintext over the network
maturity.level1: TLS partially implemented but older protocol versions (TLS 1.0/1.1) still active; not all transmission paths encrypted
maturity.level2: TLS 1.2+ configured for most transmission paths, weak cipher suites largely disabled, but end-to-end verification pending
maturity.level3: Consistent strong encryption (TLS 1.2+) for all cardholder data transmissions, exclusively strong cipher suites, automated certificate management, and regular cryptography scans

dpQ4.title: Is access to displays of the full PAN and the ability to copy cardholder data restricted?
dpQ4.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 3.4 requires that technical controls are implemented to ensure the full PAN is displayed only to users with a documented business need. All other users should see at most the masked PAN (e.g., first 6 and last 4 digits).
dpQ4.help: Not every employee needs to see the full PAN. Implement masking as the default — display only the first 6 and last 4 digits. Only users with a documented business need (e.g., fraud investigation) should be able to see the full PAN. Also restrict the ability to copy cardholder data (e.g., copy/paste, screenshots, downloads).

maturity.level0: Full PAN visible to all users; no masking implemented
maturity.level1: Masking implemented in some applications but not consistently; copy protection not present
maturity.level2: PAN masking as default in most systems, documented exceptions for authorized users, but technical copy restrictions not yet comprehensive
maturity.level3: Consistent PAN masking with role-based display of full PAN only with documented need, technical copy restrictions, and audit trail for all PAN access

vmQ1.title: Is malware protection installed, active, and regularly updated on all systems?
vmQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 5.2-5.3 requires that anti-malware solutions are installed, active, and current on all systems commonly affected by malware. Solutions must perform regular scans, provide real-time protection, and generate audit logs.
vmQ1.help: Every system in your CDE must have up-to-date malware protection. Ensure that automatic updates are enabled, regular scans are executed, and real-time protection cannot be disabled. For systems where conventional anti-malware is not suitable (e.g., Linux servers), you must perform a documented risk analysis and implement alternative protective measures.

maturity.level0: No malware protection installed on CDE systems or outdated
maturity.level1: Anti-malware installed on some systems but not consistently; automatic updates not enabled everywhere
maturity.level2: Anti-malware installed on all relevant systems with automatic updates and regular scans, but centralized management and monitoring still incomplete
maturity.level3: Centrally managed malware protection on all CDE systems with automatic updates, real-time protection, regular scans, documented exceptions, and centralized alerting for detected threats

vmQ2.title: Is custom and bespoke software developed securely?
vmQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 6.2 requires that custom software is developed securely. Developers must be trained in secure coding, and the development process must include security requirements, code reviews, and vulnerability testing.
vmQ2.help: If you develop or customize software that handles cardholder data, the development process must integrate security. This includes: training developers in secure coding (OWASP Top 10), code reviews before production deployment, separation of development/test and production environments, and automated security tests in the CI/CD pipeline.

maturity.level0: No secure development practices; no separation of development and production environments
maturity.level1: Basic environment separation but no formal secure development guidelines; ad-hoc code reviews
maturity.level2: Secure development guidelines documented, developers trained, code reviews established, but automated security tests not yet integrated into CI/CD
maturity.level3: Fully integrated secure development process (SDLC) with OWASP-based guidelines, automated SAST/DAST tests, mandatory code reviews, and documented developer training

vmQ3.title: Are known security vulnerabilities addressed by installing vendor-supplied security patches?
vmQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 6.3 requires that security vulnerabilities are identified and addressed. Critical security patches must be installed within one month of release. A formal patch management process must be established.
vmQ3.help: Patch management is one of the most important measures against known vulnerabilities. PCI DSS requires that you install critical and high-risk patches within one month of release. For all other patches, a risk-based schedule should apply. Maintain an inventory of all systems and actively monitor vulnerability databases (CVE, NVD) for your deployed technologies.

maturity.level0: No patch management process; systems with known unpatched vulnerabilities in use
maturity.level1: Ad-hoc patching without formal process; no systematic vulnerability monitoring
maturity.level2: Documented patch management process with regular patching, but 30-day deadline for critical patches not consistently met
maturity.level3: Comprehensive patch management process with automated vulnerability detection, CVSS-based prioritization, adherence to 30-day deadline for critical patches, documented exception process, and regular reporting

vmQ4.title: Are public-facing web applications protected against known attacks?
vmQ4.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 6.4-6.5 requires that public-facing web applications are protected against known attacks — either through a Web Application Firewall (WAF) or through regular application vulnerability assessments. All inputs must be validated.
vmQ4.help: Public-facing web applications that process cardholder data are a preferred attack target. PCI DSS offers two options: (1) Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) in front of all public web applications, or (2) at least annual vulnerability assessment by specialized security experts.
