The WAF option is recommended as it provides continuous protection.

maturity.level0: No protective measures for public-facing web applications; no input validation
maturity.level1: Basic input validation but no WAF and no regular vulnerability assessments
maturity.level2: WAF implemented or annual vulnerability assessment performed, but not all applications covered; OWASP Top 10 partially addressed
maturity.level3: WAF in front of all public-facing web applications with updated rulesets, additional regular penetration tests, complete coverage of OWASP Top 10, and automated vulnerability scans

acQ1.title: Is access to system components and cardholder data restricted to individuals with a business need?
acQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 7.1-7.2 requires that access to system components and cardholder data is restricted to those individuals whose jobs require such access. An access control system must be in place based on the need-to-know and least-privilege principles.
acQ1.help: The need-to-know principle means: each user receives only the access rights required for their specific role. Implement a role-based access control system (RBAC) where roles are defined and mapped to business requirements. Every access grant must be documented and approved by an authorized person.

maturity.level0: No formal access control; broad access to cardholder data without restrictions
maturity.level1: Basic user management present but no role-based access control; need-to-know not consistently enforced
maturity.level2: Role-based access control implemented with documented roles and permissions, but semi-annual access rights review not yet established
maturity.level3: Comprehensive RBAC system with documented roles, formal approval process for access grants, semi-annual review of all access rights, and automated revocation upon role changes or departure

acQ2.title: Is an access control system configured for system components that restricts access based on a user's need-to-know?
acQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 7.2 requires that access control systems are configured to restrict access based on roles and responsibilities. The default must be 'deny all' unless access is explicitly permitted.
acQ2.help: Your access control system must be configured on a deny-all basis — meaning all access is denied by default and only explicitly approved access is allowed. Ensure that every access rule is documented, regularly reviewed, and promptly adjusted when employees change roles or leave the organization.

maturity.level0: No configured access control system; default is 'allow all'
maturity.level1: Access control system present but not configured with deny-all; many generic or shared accounts
maturity.level2: Access control system with deny-all default rule, role-based assignments, but shared accounts not yet fully eliminated
maturity.level3: Fully configured access control system with deny-all default, individual user accounts, role-based assignments, automated provisioning/deprovisioning, and regular access audits

acQ3.title: Are access rights regularly reviewed and adjusted as needed?
acQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 7.3 requires that all access rights are reviewed at least every six months to ensure they remain appropriate. Access that is no longer needed must be promptly revoked.
acQ3.help: Access rights can become stale over time — through job changes, project changes, or employee departures. PCI DSS requires a semi-annual review of all access rights to cardholder data and system components. Ensure there is a formal process to revoke access that is no longer needed, and that the review is documented.

maturity.level0: No review of access rights; rights are never revoked
maturity.level1: Occasional review on request but no systematic process; stale accounts present
maturity.level2: Semi-annual access rights review established and documented, but automation for role changes not yet implemented
maturity.level3: Systematic semi-annual review of all access rights with documented review process, automated revocation upon departure, alerting for unusual access patterns, and complete audit trail

auQ1.title: Are all users identified with a unique ID before access to system components or cardholder data is granted?
auQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 8.2-8.3 requires that each user is assigned a unique ID and their identity is verified before access to system components is granted. Generic, shared, or group accounts may only be used in exceptional cases with documented justification.
auQ1.help: Unique user IDs are the foundation for accountability and traceability. Every action in your CDE must be attributable to an individual user. Eliminate shared accounts and generic IDs (e.g., 'admin', 'user1'). For exceptions (e.g., emergency accounts), documented justification and enhanced monitoring must be in place.

maturity.level0: Shared accounts and generic IDs are the norm; no individual accountability
maturity.level1: Most users have individual accounts but some shared accounts still exist; exceptions not documented
maturity.level2: All regular users have unique IDs, shared accounts documented and limited to exceptions, but enhanced monitoring for exceptions not yet implemented
maturity.level3: Consistent individual user IDs for all accounts, no shared accounts except documented and approved exceptions with enhanced monitoring, automated identity lifecycle management

auQ2.title: Are strong password/passphrase requirements enforced for all user and system accounts?
auQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 8.3.6 defines minimum password requirements: at least 12 characters (or 8 if the system does not support 12), with numeric and alphabetic characters. Passwords must be changed every 90 days or alternatively dynamic security analysis of accounts must be performed.
auQ2.help: PCI DSS v4.0 increased the minimum password length to 12 characters (previously 7). Passwords must contain a combination of numeric and alphabetic characters. You can choose between two approaches: (1) Password rotation every 90 days, or (2) dynamic security analysis of accounts that detects unusual activity. Lock accounts after a maximum of 10 failed login attempts for at least 30 minutes.

maturity.level0: No password policy; default passwords in use; no account lockout
maturity.level1: Basic password policy present but minimum length below 12 characters; password rotation not enforced
maturity.level2: Password policy with 12+ characters, complexity requirements and account lockout implemented, but not enforced on all systems
maturity.level3: Consistent password policy with 12+ characters on all systems, automated enforcement, account lockout after 10 attempts, password history (last 4), and supplementary dynamic security analysis

auQ3.title: Is multi-factor authentication (MFA) implemented for all access to the CDE?
auQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 8.4 requires MFA for all non-console administrative access to the CDE and for all remote access from outside the corporate network to the CDE.
auQ3.help: MFA means that at least two of the following authentication factors are required: knowledge (password, PIN), possession (token, smartphone), and inherence (biometrics). PCI DSS v4.0 requires MFA for: (1) all non-console administrative access to the CDE, and (2) all remote access from outside the network. The MFA implementation must be tamper-resistant and must not be bypassable.

maturity.level0: No MFA implemented; CDE access with password only
maturity.level1: MFA implemented for some administrative access but not for all remote access; bypass possibilities exist
maturity.level2: MFA implemented for administrative and remote access to the CDE, but not all authentication factors are independent of each other
maturity.level3: Complete MFA implementation for all non-console administrative and remote access to the CDE with independent authentication factors, tamper-resistant configuration, and documented emergency access process

auQ4.title: Are system and application accounts and associated authentication factors securely managed?
auQ4.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 8.5-8.6 requires that the use of system and application accounts (service accounts) is managed and controlled. Interactive logins with such accounts must be restricted and monitored. Authentication factors must be stored and transmitted securely.
auQ4.help: System and application accounts (service accounts) pose a particular risk as they often have elevated privileges and are not tied to individual users. PCI DSS requires: documentation of all service accounts with justification, restriction of interactive logins, secure storage of authentication factors (no plaintext passwords in scripts or code), and regular review and rotation of credentials.

maturity.level0: Service accounts uncontrolled; passwords in scripts in plaintext; no overview of existing service accounts
maturity.level1: Basic overview of service accounts but passwords partially in scripts; no regular rotation
maturity.level2: Service accounts documented, plaintext passwords largely eliminated, rotation established, but interactive use not fully restricted
maturity.level3: Fully managed service accounts with Privileged Access Management (PAM), automated password rotation, no plaintext credentials, restricted interactive use, and comprehensive logging of all activities

psQ1.title: Are appropriate physical access controls implemented to restrict access to systems in the CDE?
psQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 9.1-9.2 requires physical access controls to restrict access to systems in the CDE to authorized personnel. This includes access control systems, surveillance cameras, visitor management, and visitor identification.
psQ1.help: Physical security complements technical controls. Your CDE areas (e.g., server rooms, data centers) must be protected by access control systems. Use access cards, biometric systems, or similar mechanisms. All access must be logged. Visitors must be escorted and visibly identified as visitors. Surveillance cameras should be installed at all entry and exit points.

maturity.level0: No physical access controls; CDE areas freely accessible
maturity.level1: Basic access controls (e.g., key lock) present but no logging and no visitor management
maturity.level2: Access control system with logging installed, visitor process defined, but video surveillance and regular review of access lists pending
maturity.level3: Comprehensive physical access control with electronic access control system, video surveillance at all CDE access points, formal visitor management, minimum 3-month retention of records, and regular review of access lists

psQ2.title: Is physical access to wireless access points, gateways, network/communication lines, and portable devices within the CDE restricted?
psQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 9.4 requires that physical access to wireless access points, gateways, network devices, and portable media within the facility is restricted. Portable media with cardholder data must be physically secured.
psQ2.help: Network devices and wireless access points within your CDE must be physically secured — in locked rooms, cabinets, or enclosures. Portable media (USB drives, hard drives, tapes) with cardholder data must be stored in secure areas. Maintain an inventory of all portable media and implement a process for secure destruction of media no longer needed.

maturity.level0: Network devices freely accessible; no portable media inventory; no secure storage
maturity.level1: Network devices partially secured but WLAN access points or communication lines accessible; media inventory incomplete
maturity.level2: Network devices in secured areas, media inventory maintained and media securely stored, but destruction process not yet formalized
maturity.level3: Complete physical security of all network devices and access points, complete media inventory with tracking, secure storage, and documented destruction process with evidence

psQ3.title: Are point-of-interaction (POI) devices (e.g., card terminals) protected against tampering and unauthorized substitution?
psQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 9.5 requires protection of point-of-interaction (POI) devices such as card terminals against tampering, unauthorized substitution, and skimming. An inventory of all POI devices must be maintained and regularly reviewed.
psQ3.help: Card terminals and other POI devices are a frequent target for skimming attacks. PCI DSS requires: maintain an inventory of all POI devices with serial number and location. Regularly inspect devices for tampering (e.g., additional overlays, broken seals). Train employees to recognize tampering. Implement a reporting process for suspicious behavior around devices.

maturity.level0: No POI device inventory; no inspection for tampering; no employee training
maturity.level1: Basic inventory present but no regular physical inspection of devices; employees not trained
maturity.level2: POI inventory maintained, periodic tampering inspections established, employees basically trained, but reporting process not yet formalized
maturity.level3: Complete POI inventory with regular physical inspections, trained personnel with documented tamper detection procedures, formal reporting process, and logging of all inspection results

mtQ1.title: Are audit logs maintained for all access to system components and cardholder data?
mtQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 10.1-10.3 requires that audit logs are implemented and enabled to track all individual user access to cardholder data. Logs must capture specific events, including all actions by users with root or administrator privileges, all access to audit logs, and all failed login attempts.
mtQ1.help: Audit logging is critical for detection and investigation of security incidents. PCI DSS requires the following events to be logged: individual user access to cardholder data, actions with root/admin privileges, access to audit logs, failed login attempts, changes to identification mechanisms, initialization and stopping of logs, and creation and deletion of system objects. Logs must be protected from tampering and retained for at least 12 months.

maturity.level0: No audit logging implemented; no traceability of access
maturity.level1: Basic logging on some systems but not all required events captured; no central storage
maturity.level2: Audit logging enabled on all CDE systems capturing most required events, central storage established, but retention below 12 months
maturity.level3: Comprehensive audit logging of all required events on all CDE systems, tamper-proof central log storage with minimum 12-month retention, automated log integrity verification, and time synchronization (NTP)

mtQ2.title: Are external and internal vulnerability scans performed regularly?
mtQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 11.3 requires that internal and external vulnerability scans are performed at least quarterly and after significant changes. External scans must be performed by a PCI Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV).
mtQ2.help: Vulnerability scans help identify security gaps before they are exploited. PCI DSS requires: quarterly internal scans (can be performed internally) and quarterly external scans by a PCI ASV. Additional scans must be performed after significant infrastructure changes. External scans must achieve a 'passing' result. Found vulnerabilities must be prioritized and remediated.

maturity.level0: No vulnerability scans; no knowledge of existing vulnerabilities
maturity.level1: Occasional internal scans but not quarterly; no external ASV scans
maturity.level2: Quarterly internal and external ASV scans established, but remediation of found vulnerabilities not consistently within deadlines
maturity.level3: Quarterly internal and external ASV scans with documented remediation process, re-scans after changes, timely remediation of all critical vulnerabilities, and complete scan archive

mtQ3.title: Are regular penetration tests performed?
mtQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 11.4 requires that external and internal penetration tests are performed at least annually and after significant changes. Tests must apply recognized methodologies (e.g., NIST SP 800-115, OWASP, PTES) and cover both network and application layers.
mtQ3.help: Penetration tests go beyond vulnerability scans — they attempt to actually exploit found vulnerabilities and demonstrate the impact. PCI DSS requires annual penetration tests from inside and outside, as well as tests of network segmentation. Tests must be performed by qualified professionals (internal or external). All found vulnerabilities must be remediated and re-tested.

maturity.level0: No penetration tests performed; no knowledge of exploitable vulnerabilities
maturity.level1: Occasional or informal penetration tests but not annually; no standardized methodology
maturity.level2: Annual penetration tests by qualified testers with recognized methodology, but segmentation tests not yet regular
maturity.level3: Annual internal and external penetration tests with recognized methodology, network segmentation tests, documented remediation of all findings, re-tests for verification, and tests after significant changes

mtQ4.title: Can failures of critical security control systems be detected and responded to?
mtQ4.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 10.7 requires that failures of critical security control systems are promptly detected, reported, and addressed. These include firewalls, IDS/IPS, anti-malware, access controls, audit logging, and segmentation controls.
mtQ4.help: When a security control fails — e.g., a firewall rule is deleted or the anti-malware system stops — security gaps arise that can be quickly exploited. PCI DSS requires you to implement mechanisms that immediately detect and report such failures. Define escalation processes and maximum timeframes for restoration.

maturity.level0: No monitoring of security control systems; failures not detected
maturity.level1: Partial monitoring of individual systems but no comprehensive detection of control failures; no escalation process
maturity.level2: Monitoring of most critical security controls with alerting, but response processes and timeframes not consistently defined
maturity.level3: Comprehensive real-time monitoring of all critical security control systems with automated alerting, defined escalation process, documented restoration timeframes, and regular tests of detection capability

spQ1.title: Is a comprehensive information security policy established, published, maintained, and known to all relevant personnel?
spQ1.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 12.1 requires that a comprehensive information security policy is established, published, and updated at least annually and after environmental changes. The policy must address all PCI DSS requirements and define information security roles and responsibilities.
spQ1.help: The information security policy is the foundation of your PCI DSS compliance program. It must address all 12 PCI DSS requirement areas and clearly define who is responsible for what. The policy must be approved by management and communicated to all employees. An annual review and update is mandatory.

maturity.level0: No information security policy in place; no defined roles and responsibilities
maturity.level1: Basic IT security policy present but not all PCI DSS areas covered; policy not known to all employees
maturity.level2: Comprehensive information security policy covering PCI DSS, approved by management and published, but annual review not yet systematic
maturity.level3: Complete information security policy addressing all PCI DSS requirements, approved by management, known to all employees, reviewed and updated annually, with clearly defined roles, responsibilities, and escalation paths

spQ2.title: Is a security awareness program conducted for all personnel?
spQ2.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 12.6 requires a formal security awareness program that educates all personnel about the importance of cardholder data security. Training must be conducted upon hire and at least annually thereafter.
spQ2.help: Employees are a central factor in cardholder data security. PCI DSS requires a formal awareness program that includes at minimum: training upon hire and at least annually thereafter, coverage of current threats (phishing, social engineering), employee acknowledgments that they have read and understood the policy, and specific training for roles with access to cardholder data.

maturity.level0: No security awareness program; no employee training on card data security
maturity.level1: Informal IT security hints but no structured program; no participation documentation
maturity.level2: Annual awareness program with training upon hire and annually thereafter, participation documented, but content not adapted to current threats
maturity.level3: Comprehensive security awareness program with onboarding and annual training, current threat scenarios, documented participation and acknowledgments, role-specific deep dives, and regular phishing simulations

spQ3.title: Is an incident response plan implemented that can be immediately activated upon a suspected or confirmed security incident?
spQ3.tooltip: PCI DSS v4.0 Req. 12.10 requires an incident response plan that is immediately activated upon suspicion of a security incident. The plan must define roles and responsibilities, communication channels, notification requirements (e.g., to card brands), and evidence preservation procedures.
spQ3.help: A security incident involving cardholder data can cause significant financial and reputational damage. Your incident response plan must clearly define: Who is responsible? Who is notified (internal, card brands, acquirer, authorities)? How is evidence preserved? How is the incident contained? The plan must be tested at least annually and personnel must be trained.

maturity.level0: No incident response plan in place; no defined response processes for security incidents
maturity.level1: Basic plan present but not all required elements included; plan never tested
maturity.level2: Incident response plan with defined roles, communication channels, and notification requirements, annual testing planned, but evidence preservation processes not yet complete
maturity.level3: Comprehensive incident response plan with all PCI DSS requirements, annual tests (tabletop or simulation), trained incident response team, defined evidence preservation processes, and lessons-learned process after every incident or test

ns1.title: Implement network segmentation and firewall hardening
ns1.description: Implement clear network segmentation that isolates your cardholder data environment (CDE) from all other networks. Configure network security controls (firewalls) with documented rulesets based on the deny-all principle and review them semi-annually.
ns1.firstStep: Create an up-to-date network diagram showing all cardholder data flows and identify the boundaries of your CDE.

ns2.title: Perform system hardening based on recognized standards
ns2.description: Develop and implement configuration standards for all system types in your CDE based on recognized hardening guidelines (CIS Benchmarks, DISA STIGs). Change all vendor-supplied default passwords and disable unnecessary services and protocols.
ns2.firstStep: Create an inventory of all system components in the CDE and check whether vendor-supplied default passwords are still active.

ns3.title: Establish comprehensive network monitoring and control
ns3.description: Implement comprehensive control of network traffic between trusted and untrusted networks. Secure wireless networks with WPA3/WPA2, control inbound and outbound traffic, and conduct regular wireless scans.
ns3.firstStep: Perform a complete wireless scan of your locations to identify unauthorized access points.
ns3.checklist:
- Create and update network diagram with all CDE boundaries
- Document firewall rulesets and review semi-annually
- Upgrade WLAN security to WPA3/WPA2 Enterprise
- Restrict outbound traffic from CDE to necessary connections
- Schedule and perform quarterly wireless scans
- Commission annual segmentation penetration tests

dp1.title: Implement data minimization and retention policy
dp1.description: Implement a strict data minimization strategy for cardholder data. Create a retention policy defining which data may be stored, for how long, and when it must be securely deleted. Completely eliminate storage of sensitive authentication data (SAD) after authorization.
dp1.firstStep: Conduct a data discovery scan to identify all storage locations for cardholder data (including databases, file systems, logs, and backups).

dp2.title: Implement PAN encryption and key management
dp2.description: Render the PAN unreadable at all storage locations through strong cryptography. Implement complete key management with documented processes for generation, distribution, storage, rotation, and destruction of cryptographic keys.
dp2.firstStep: Identify all PAN storage locations and check the current encryption status — start with databases and file systems.

dp3.title: Ensure encryption during transmission
dp3.description: Ensure all transmissions of cardholder data over open, public networks are protected by TLS 1.2 or higher. Disable weak cipher suites and implement automated certificate management.
dp3.firstStep: Perform a TLS scan of all publicly reachable endpoints to identify outdated protocol versions and weak cipher suites.

vm1.title: Deploy anti-malware solution comprehensively
vm1.description: Install and configure a centrally managed anti-malware solution on all CDE systems. Enable automatic signature updates, real-time protection, and regular full system scans. Implement centralized alerting for detected threats.
vm1.firstStep: Create an inventory of all systems in the CDE and check the current anti-malware status — address missing or outdated installations first.

vm2.title: Establish patch management process
vm2.description: Implement a formal patch management process ensuring critical security patches are installed within 30 days of release. Use automated vulnerability detection and CVSS-based prioritization.
vm2.firstStep: Set up a vulnerability scanning tool and perform an initial scan of all CDE systems to determine the current patch status.

vm3.title: Implement secure software development and web application protection
vm3.description: Establish a secure software development process (Secure SDLC) with OWASP-based guidelines, mandatory code reviews, and automated security tests. Protect public-facing web applications with a Web Application Firewall (WAF).
vm3.firstStep: Identify all public-facing web applications and check whether a WAF is deployed in front of them.
vm3.checklist:
- Create secure development guidelines based on OWASP
- Train developers in secure coding (annually)
- Establish code review process before each production deployment
- Integrate SAST/DAST tools into the CI/CD pipeline
- Deploy WAF in front of all public web applications
- Strictly separate development, test, and production environments
- Anonymize test data — no real PANs in test environments

ac1.title: Implement role-based access control (RBAC)
ac1.description: Implement a role-based access control system based on need-to-know and least-privilege principles. Document all roles and their permissions, establish a formal approval process, and conduct semi-annual access reviews.
ac1.firstStep: Create a matrix of all roles with access to the CDE and document the business justification for each role's access.

ac2.title: Establish automated access rights management
ac2.description: Implement automated processes for granting, modifying, and revoking access rights. Ensure access rights are promptly adjusted upon role changes and departures. Conduct regular access audits.
ac2.firstStep: Check whether orphaned accounts (from former employees) or accounts with excessive privileges exist in your CDE.
ac2.checklist:
- Document access control policy (need-to-know, least privilege)
- Create and maintain role matrix with permissions
- Introduce formal approval process for access grants
- Implement automated deprovisioning upon departure
- Conduct and document semi-annual access reviews
- Ensure audit trail for all access changes

au1.title: Enforce strong password policy
au1.description: Implement and enforce password policies per PCI DSS v4.0: minimum 12 characters, numeric and alphabetic characters, account lockout after 10 failed attempts, password history (last 4). Supplement with dynamic security analysis or 90-day rotation.
au1.firstStep: Check the current password settings on all CDE systems and adjust the minimum length to 12 characters.

au2.title: Set up multi-factor authentication (MFA) for CDE access
au2.description: Implement MFA for all non-console administrative access and all remote access to the CDE. Ensure authentication factors are independent of each other and the MFA solution cannot be bypassed.
au2.firstStep: Identify all administrative and remote access paths to the CDE and prioritize MFA implementation for administrator accounts.

au3.title: Establish service account management and privileged access management
au3.description: Implement comprehensive management for system and application accounts (service accounts). Eliminate plaintext credentials in scripts and code, implement automated password rotation, and restrict interactive logins.
au3.firstStep: Create an inventory of all service accounts in the CDE with purpose and current authentication method.
au3.checklist:
- Create inventory of all service accounts with justification
- Eliminate plaintext passwords in scripts and configuration files
- Evaluate and deploy Privileged Access Management (PAM) solution
- Enable automated password rotation for service accounts
- Technically restrict interactive login with service accounts
- Log and monitor all service account activities

ps1.title: Implement physical access controls for the CDE
ps1.description: Implement electronic access control systems for all CDE areas, install video surveillance at entry and exit points, and establish formal visitor management. Retain records for at least 3 months.
ps1.firstStep: Identify all physical locations with CDE systems and review the existing access controls.

ps2.title: Ensure protection of media and POI devices
ps2.description: Maintain an inventory of all portable media with cardholder data and all POI devices. Implement secure storage, regular tamper inspections, and documented destruction processes. Train employees in tamper recognition.
ps2.firstStep: Create an inventory of all POI devices (card terminals) with serial number, model, and location, and schedule regular physical inspections.

mt1.title: Implement comprehensive audit logging and log management
mt1.description: Implement audit logging on all CDE systems for all required events per PCI DSS Req. 10. Set up centralized, tamper-proof log storage with at least 12 months retention, of which 3 months immediately available.
mt1.firstStep: Check whether audit logging is enabled on all CDE systems and whether logs are centrally stored.

mt2.title: Establish regular vulnerability scans and penetration tests
mt2.description: Establish quarterly internal and external (ASV) vulnerability scans as well as annual penetration tests. Implement a documented process for remediation of found vulnerabilities and validation through re-testing.
mt2.firstStep: Engage a PCI-approved Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV) for the next quarterly external scan.

sp1.title: Create and maintain comprehensive information security policy
sp1.description: Create a comprehensive information security policy that addresses all 12 PCI DSS requirement areas. Define clear roles and responsibilities, have the policy approved by management, and make it accessible to all employees.
sp1.firstStep: Review your existing IT security policy against the 12 PCI DSS requirements and identify gaps.

sp2.title: Establish security awareness program and incident response plan
sp2.description: Implement a formal security awareness program with training upon hire and annual refreshers. Create and test an incident response plan that can be immediately activated upon suspicion of a security incident.
sp2.firstStep: Create or update your incident response plan and schedule an initial tabletop test with the incident response team.
sp2.checklist:
- Create security awareness program with annual training plan
- Conduct training upon hire and at least annually thereafter
- Document participation and acknowledgments
- Perform quarterly phishing simulations
- Create incident response plan with roles, communication channels, and notification requirements
- Record card brand notification contact details
- Conduct annual tabletop or simulation test of IR plan
- Establish lessons-learned process after every incident or test

q1.title: Is your cardholder data environment (CDE) segmented from the rest of the network by firewalls?
q1.description: PCI DSS requires network security controls (e.g., firewalls) that control access to the CDE. Every firewall rule must be documented and justified.

q2.title: Is the PAN rendered unreadable during storage through strong encryption, tokenization, or hashing?
q2.description: Cardholder data (PAN) must be protected by strong cryptography at all storage locations. Sensitive authentication data must not be stored after authorization.

q3.title: Are malware protection and patch management implemented for all CDE systems?
q3.description: Anti-malware must be installed and current on all relevant systems. Critical security patches must be installed within 30 days.

q4.title: Is access to cardholder data restricted to authorized individuals with a documented need?
q4.description: Access to the CDE must be restricted based on the need-to-know principle. Every user requires a unique ID and only the minimum necessary privileges.

q5.title: Is multi-factor authentication (MFA) used for all administrative and remote access to the CDE?
q5.description: MFA is mandatory for all non-console admin access and remote access. Strong passwords (12+ characters) must be enforced on all systems.

q6.title: Are physical access controls for CDE areas and protection of POI devices implemented?
q6.description: Physical access to CDE systems must be secured through access control systems, video surveillance, and visitor management. POI devices must be protected against tampering.

q7.title: Are audit logs maintained for all access to network resources and cardholder data?
q7.description: All access to cardholder data must be logged. Logs must be centralized, tamper-proof, and retained for at least 12 months.

q8.title: Does a comprehensive information security policy with an incident response plan exist?
q8.description: A security policy must cover all PCI DSS areas and be updated annually. An incident response plan must be in place and tested.

q9.title: Are all transmissions of cardholder data over public networks encrypted (TLS 1.2+)?
q9.description: PCI DSS requires strong cryptography (TLS 1.2 or higher) for all transmissions of the PAN over open, public networks.

q10.title: Are quarterly vulnerability scans and annual penetration tests performed?
q10.description: Internal and external (ASV) vulnerability scans must be quarterly, penetration tests at least annually and after significant changes.

c5.name: BSI C5
c5.description: BSI criteria catalogue for secure cloud computing

organisation.name: Organisation & Compliance
organisation.description: Information security organisation, security policies and personnel management (OIS, SP, HR)

assetManagement.name: Asset Management & Classification
assetManagement.description: Inventory, classification and handling of cloud assets and customer data (AM)

physicalSecurity.name: Physical Security
physicalSecurity.description: Protection of data centres, security zones and infrastructure components (PS)

identityAccess.name: Identity & Access Management
identityAccess.description: User registration, authentication, authorisation and access control (IDM)

operations.name: Operations & Communication
operations.description: Operational processes, change management, network security and communication protection (OPS, COS)

cryptography.name: Cryptography & Key Management
cryptography.description: Encryption policies, key lifecycle and cryptographic procedures (KRY)

incidentBcm.name: Incident Management & BCM
incidentBcm.description: Security incident handling, business continuity management and emergency planning (SIM, BCM)

developmentAudit.name: Development & Audit
developmentAudit.description: Secure software development, compliance evidence and independent audits (DEV, SSO, PI)

orgQ1.title: Does your organisation have a documented information security policy for cloud operations?
orgQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 OIS-01 and OIS-02 require a comprehensive information security policy that is approved by management, published and regularly reviewed. The policy must explicitly cover cloud operations and clearly assign responsibilities.
orgQ1.help: An information security policy forms the foundation of your C5 compliance framework. It must be approved by management, communicated to all relevant employees and reviewed regularly — at least annually. The policy should define the scope of the cloud service, responsibilities, risk acceptance criteria and overarching protection objectives.

maturity.level0: No documented information security policy; cloud security is not systematically addressed
maturity.level1: General IT security policy exists but no specific reference to cloud operations; not regularly updated
maturity.level2: Documented information security policy with cloud references, approved and published by management, but review cycle not consistently maintained
maturity.level3: Comprehensive management-approved information security policy per C5:2020 OIS-01/02 covering all cloud operations, regularly reviewed and communicated to all employees

orgQ2.title: Are subordinate security policies for the cloud service defined and implemented?
orgQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 SP-01 and SP-02 require topic-specific security policies that detail the overarching information security policy. These must cover areas such as access control, cryptography, physical security, operations and communications.
orgQ2.help: Beyond the overarching policy, C5 requires topic-specific security policies that define concrete requirements for individual areas. Typical topics include: access management, cryptography, data backup, network security, incident handling and physical security. Each policy must have a designated owner and be regularly updated.

maturity.level0: No topic-specific security policies; individual areas are handled on an ad-hoc basis
maturity.level1: Some security policies exist (e.g. password policy) but not all C5-relevant areas are covered
maturity.level2: Topic-specific security policies created for most C5 areas, owners designated, but implementation controls still incomplete
maturity.level3: Complete set of topic-specific security policies per C5:2020 SP-01/02 with designated owners, regular review and demonstrable implementation across all relevant areas

orgQ3.title: Are employees in cloud operations screened and trained on information security?
orgQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 HR-01 and HR-03 require background checks for employees with access to cloud systems and regular information security training. The scope of screening must be proportionate to the risk of the respective role.
orgQ3.help: C5 requires that all employees with access to cloud systems and customer data are screened before hiring (identity verification, qualification proof, criminal record check where applicable). Additionally, regular information security training must be provided, tailored to the specific tasks and risks of each role. Training attendance must be documented.

maturity.level0: No systematic background checks or security training for cloud personnel
maturity.level1: Basic identity verification at hiring but no role-specific security training
maturity.level2: Background checks at hiring and regular general security training, but not tailored to specific cloud roles
maturity.level3: Risk-proportionate background checks per C5:2020 HR-01, role-specific security training per HR-03, documented attendance and annual refresher courses

orgQ4.title: Is compliance with information security policies regularly checked through independent audits?
orgQ4.tooltip: C5:2020 OIS-05 and OIS-07 require regular independent review of the information security organisation and compliance with defined policies. Results must be documented and deviations tracked.
orgQ4.help: C5 requires that the effectiveness of your information security measures and compliance with your policies are regularly validated through independent audits — internal or external. Audit results must be reported to management. Identified deviations require corrective actions with defined deadlines and responsibilities.

maturity.level0: No independent audits of information security; compliance is not systematically monitored
maturity.level1: Occasional ad-hoc reviews by IT staff but no structured independent controls
maturity.level2: Regular internal information security audits with documented results but not fully covering all C5 areas
maturity.level3: Structured independent audit programme per C5:2020 OIS-05/07 with full coverage, documented results, deviation tracking and management reporting

amQ1.title: Do you maintain a current inventory of all cloud assets including customer data?
amQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 AM-01 and AM-02 require a complete inventory of all assets relevant to the cloud service delivery. This includes hardware, software, data and network components. Each asset must have a designated owner.
amQ1.help: A complete asset inventory is a prerequisite for effective security management. C5 requires all cloud-relevant assets to be recorded: servers, storage media, network components, software licences, databases and especially customer data. Each asset must have a designated owner responsible for its protection.

maturity.level0: No asset inventory; no overview of deployed hardware, software or stored customer data
maturity.level1: Partial inventory (e.g. hardware only) but customer data and software not fully recorded; no designated owners
maturity.level2: Comprehensive asset inventory covering hardware, software and data, owners assigned, but updates not fully automated
maturity.level3: Complete, current asset inventory per C5:2020 AM-01/02 with designated owners, automated discovery, regular updates and integration into risk management

amQ2.title: Are cloud assets and customer data classified by protection requirements and handled accordingly?
amQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 AM-03 and AM-04 require classification of all assets by protection requirements and derived handling rules. The classification must consider confidentiality, integrity and availability.
amQ2.help: C5 requires a classification scheme with at least three protection levels applied to all cloud assets. Concrete handling rules must be derived from the classification — e.g. what encryption is required at each level, who may access data and how data is to be deleted. Correct classification of customer data is particularly important.

maturity.level0: No classification of assets or data by protection requirements
maturity.level1: Informal understanding of different protection needs but no formal classification scheme
maturity.level2: Classification scheme defined and applied to most assets, handling rules created, but implementation not consistently monitored
maturity.level3: Comprehensive classification scheme per C5:2020 AM-03/04 with defined protection levels, derived handling rules, consistent application to all assets and regular review

amQ3.title: Is secure return and deletion of customer data at contract end ensured?
amQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 AM-05 and AM-06 regulate the return of customer data and secure deletion after contract end. The cloud provider must ensure customer data is returned completely in a usable format and subsequently demonstrably deleted.
amQ3.help: At contract end or termination, the cloud provider must be able to return all customer data in an agreed, usable format. After successful return, the data — including all copies and backups — must be securely and demonstrably deleted. Deletion must comply with recognised standards (e.g. BSI recommendations for secure data deletion). Deadlines for return and deletion should be contractually agreed.

maturity.level0: No processes for data return or secure deletion at contract end
maturity.level1: Basic willingness to return data but no defined process; deletion not demonstrable
maturity.level2: Documented process for data return and deletion, but evidence and completeness of deletion not fully assured
maturity.level3: Fully documented process per C5:2020 AM-05/06 with contractual deadlines, return in agreed format, demonstrably secure deletion of all copies and independent verification

psQ1.title: Are data centre locations protected by appropriate physical security measures?
psQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 PS-01 and PS-02 require defined security zones with graduated physical protection. Data centres must be secured by perimeter protection, access control systems and surveillance.
psQ1.help: C5 requires a multi-layered physical security concept for data centres: outer perimeter protection (fencing, lighting), building access (airlock, badge control), server rooms (biometric access control, surveillance cameras). Each zone must have defined access authorisations. Visitors must be registered and escorted.

maturity.level0: No defined security zones; uncontrolled access to server rooms possible
maturity.level1: Basic building protection (locked rooms) but no multi-layered zone concept and no systematic access control
maturity.level2: Defined security zones with electronic access control and surveillance, visitor registration, but gaps in perimeter protection or zone transitions
maturity.level3: Complete multi-layered physical security concept per C5:2020 PS-01/02 with perimeter protection, graduated security zones, biometric access control, video surveillance, visitor management and regular vulnerability assessments

psQ2.title: Is the data centre protected against environmental risks (fire, water, power)?
psQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 PS-05 and PS-06 require protective measures against environmental risks such as fire, water damage, power failure and air conditioning failure. Redundant systems and early warning systems must be installed.
psQ2.help: C5 requires comprehensive protection of data centre infrastructure against environmental risks: fire detection and suppression system (preferably gas suppression), water detection (leak sensors under raised floor), uninterruptible power supply (UPS) with standby generator, redundant air conditioning with temperature and humidity monitoring. All systems must be regularly maintained and tested.

maturity.level0: No or minimal protective measures against environmental risks; no redundancy for power or cooling
maturity.level1: Basic measures in place (smoke detectors, UPS) but no redundancy and no early warning systems
maturity.level2: Fire detection and suppression, UPS with standby generator, air conditioning with monitoring, but redundancy not comprehensive or tests not regular
maturity.level3: Complete environmental protection per C5:2020 PS-05/06 with redundant power supply (UPS + generator), gas suppression and fire detection, water detection, redundant air conditioning, regular testing and documented maintenance

psQ3.title: Are maintenance and disposal processes for IT equipment carried out securely?
psQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 PS-07 and PS-09 require secure maintenance processes and demonstrably secure disposal or reuse of IT equipment. Storage media must be securely erased or physically destroyed before disposal.
psQ3.help: C5 requires documented processes for secure maintenance and disposal of IT equipment. During maintenance by external service providers, it must be ensured that no unauthorised access to customer data is possible. When disposing of or reusing equipment, all storage media must be securely erased (per recognised standards) or physically destroyed. Destruction must be documented and verifiable.

maturity.level0: No defined processes for secure maintenance or disposal; storage media disposed of without erasure
maturity.level1: Basic awareness but no documented processes; erasure of storage media not standardised
maturity.level2: Documented maintenance and disposal processes with secure data erasure, but evidence and external maintenance oversight still incomplete
maturity.level3: Fully documented processes per C5:2020 PS-07/09 with secure data erasure to BSI standards, physical destruction where required, documented evidence and controlled external maintenance

idmQ1.title: Is there a formal process for user registration and deregistration in the cloud service?
idmQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 IDM-01 and IDM-02 require a formal process for user account registration and deregistration. Each user must be uniquely identifiable. On departure or role change, access rights must be promptly revoked or adjusted.
idmQ1.help: C5 requires a documented process for the entire user account lifecycle: creation with unique identification, approval by the responsible person, assignment of role-based rights and timely deactivation on departure. Importantly, shared accounts must be minimised and technically privileged accounts managed separately. The process must be audit-trail documented.

maturity.level0: No formal process; user accounts created without approval and not deactivated on departure
maturity.level1: Informal processes in place but no consistent approval and no timely deactivation on departure
maturity.level2: Formal registration process with approval and role-based rights assignment, deregistration documented, but delays in role changes
maturity.level3: Fully automated lifecycle process per C5:2020 IDM-01/02 with unique identification, approval workflow, role-based rights assignment, automatic deactivation and complete audit trail

idmQ2.title: Are access rights granted on a least-privilege basis and regularly reviewed?
idmQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 IDM-03 and IDM-06 require access rights to be granted on a least-privilege basis and regularly reviewed (access review). Privileged access rights must be particularly restrictively granted.
idmQ2.help: C5 requires that each user only receives the access rights necessary for their current task. Privileged rights (administrator, root) must be particularly restrictively granted and separately monitored. All access rights must be reviewed regularly — at least semi-annually (access review). During review, unnecessary rights must be revoked and deviations documented.

maturity.level0: No systematic rights management; users frequently receive excessively broad rights
maturity.level1: Basic awareness of minimal rights but no formal process and no regular access reviews
maturity.level2: Role-based access control implemented, access reviews performed but not regularly or without consistent follow-up
maturity.level3: Consistent implementation of least-privilege per C5:2020 IDM-03/06 with role-based access control, regular access reviews, documented follow-up and separate management of privileged accounts

idmQ3.title: Do you use strong authentication mechanisms for access to cloud systems?
idmQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 IDM-07 and IDM-08 require the use of appropriate authentication mechanisms, particularly multi-factor authentication (MFA) for privileged access and administrative interfaces. Passwords must meet defined complexity requirements.
idmQ3.help: C5 requires appropriate authentication mechanisms for all access to the cloud service. For privileged access and administrative interfaces, multi-factor authentication (MFA) is required. Passwords must meet defined complexity requirements (minimum length, complexity, change history). Session management must include timeouts and automatic lockout on inactivity.

maturity.level0: Only simple password authentication without complexity requirements; no MFA
maturity.level1: Password policy with minimum requirements in place but no MFA, even for privileged access
maturity.level2: MFA for privileged access and administrative interfaces implemented, password policy defined, but not enforced for all access types
maturity.level3: Comprehensive authentication strategy per C5:2020 IDM-07/08 with MFA for all privileged and administrative access, strong password policy, automatic session management and logging of all authentication attempts

opsQ1.title: Are operational processes for the cloud service documented and is compliance monitored?
opsQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 OPS-01 and OPS-03 require documented operational processes for the cloud service, including change management, capacity management and separation of development, test and production environments.
opsQ1.help: C5 requires documented standard operating procedures for all essential aspects of cloud operations: change management, capacity planning, environment separation (dev/test/prod), patch management and system hardening. These procedures must be known to employees and their compliance must be monitored.

maturity.level0: No documented operational processes; cloud operations run without standardised procedures
maturity.level1: Some operational processes informally defined but not comprehensively documented or monitored
maturity.level2: Documented operational processes for key areas (change management, patch management) but gaps in capacity planning or environment separation
maturity.level3: Fully documented operational processes per C5:2020 OPS-01/03 for all relevant areas, regular review, demonstrable compliance and automated controls where possible

opsQ2.title: Are security events and system activities centrally logged and monitored?
opsQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 OPS-07 and OPS-08 require logging of security-relevant events and timely analysis. Log data must be protected against tampering and retained for defined periods.
opsQ2.help: C5 requires comprehensive logging of all security-relevant events: login attempts, access attempts, system configuration changes, privileged actions and security events. Logs must be centrally collected, protected against unauthorised access and tampering, and analysed in a timely manner. Retention periods must be defined and comply with regulatory requirements.

maturity.level0: No systematic logging or monitoring; security events are not captured
maturity.level1: Basic system logging in place but not centrally collected and not regularly analysed
maturity.level2: Central logging (SIEM) implemented, key security events captured and alerts responded to, but coverage not complete
maturity.level3: Comprehensive logging and monitoring per C5:2020 OPS-07/08 with central SIEM, tamper-proof storage, automated alerting, defined retention periods and regular review of logging policies

opsQ3.title: Are networks and communication links of the cloud service adequately secured?
opsQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 COS-01 and COS-05 require the protection of networks and communication links through segmentation, encryption and monitoring. Data traffic between cloud service and customers must be encrypted.
opsQ3.help: C5 requires comprehensive network security: segmentation of the cloud network to ensure tenant isolation, encryption of data in transit (TLS/IPsec), firewalls and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS), monitoring of network traffic for anomalies. The network architecture must be documented and regularly tested for vulnerabilities.

maturity.level0: No network segmentation or encryption of data traffic; no monitoring
maturity.level1: Basic firewall rules and TLS for external connections but no network segmentation or monitoring of internal communication
maturity.level2: Network segmentation implemented, TLS for all external connections, IDS/IPS deployed, but internal communication not consistently encrypted
maturity.level3: Complete network security per C5:2020 COS-01/05 with segmentation, tenant isolation, end-to-end encryption, IDS/IPS, anomaly detection and regular vulnerability scans

kryQ1.title: Is there a documented cryptography policy with current encryption standards?
kryQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 KRY-01 and KRY-02 require a cryptography policy governing the use of cryptographic algorithms and key lengths. Only recognised, current algorithms (e.g. per BSI TR-02102) may be used.
kryQ1.help: C5 requires a documented cryptography policy that specifies which cryptographic algorithms, key lengths and protocols may be used. The policy must align with current recommendations (e.g. BSI TR-02102 or NIST SP 800-131A). Outdated or insecure algorithms (e.g. MD5, SHA-1, DES, RC4) must be explicitly excluded. The policy must be regularly updated.

maturity.level0: No cryptography policy; encryption is used ad hoc without uniform standards
maturity.level1: Basic awareness of encryption but no documented policy and no uniform standards
maturity.level2: Documented cryptography policy with defined algorithms and key lengths, but not all systems comply with the policy
maturity.level3: Comprehensive cryptography policy per C5:2020 KRY-01/02 aligned with BSI TR-02102, with defined algorithms, key lengths and protocols, consistently implemented and regularly updated

kryQ2.title: Are cryptographic keys securely managed throughout their entire lifecycle?
kryQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 KRY-03 requires key management covering the entire lifecycle of cryptographic keys: generation, distribution, storage, rotation, archiving and destruction.
kryQ2.help: C5 requires documented key management for all cryptographic keys used. The process must cover all phases: secure generation (e.g. with hardware security modules), protected storage, controlled distribution, regular rotation (e.g. annually for symmetric keys), secure archiving and demonstrable destruction. Key compromise must trigger immediate action.

maturity.level0: No defined key management; keys stored insecurely or never rotated
maturity.level1: Basic key management in place but no formal processes for rotation, archiving or destruction
maturity.level2: Documented key management with defined processes for generation, storage and rotation, but no HSM use and gaps in destruction
maturity.level3: Comprehensive key management per C5:2020 KRY-03 with HSM-backed generation and storage, automated rotation, secure archiving, demonstrable destruction and defined emergency procedures for key compromise

kryQ3.title: Is customer data encrypted both in transit and at rest?
kryQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 KRY-04 requires encryption of customer data in transit and at rest. The methods used must comply with the cryptography policy and meet the current state of the art.
kryQ3.help: C5 requires that customer data is consistently encrypted: in transit through current TLS versions and at rest through strong encryption (e.g. AES-256). Encryption of backups, database entries and temporary files is particularly important. Customers should be informed about the methods used and ideally have the option to use their own keys (BYOK/HYOK).

maturity.level0: Customer data is encrypted neither in transit nor at rest
maturity.level1: TLS for external connections but no encryption at rest and no consistent encryption of internal communication
maturity.level2: Encryption in transit and at rest for most customer data, but gaps in backups, temporary files or internal transfers
maturity.level3: End-to-end encryption per C5:2020 KRY-04 for all customer data in transit and at rest, including backups and temporary files, using current methods, customer information and optional BYOK capability

simQ1.title: Is there a defined process for detecting, reporting and handling security incidents?
simQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 SIM-01 and SIM-02 require a documented security incident management process covering detection, reporting, analysis, response and follow-up. Responsibilities and escalation paths must be clearly defined.
simQ1.help: C5 requires a complete incident response process: from detection through initial response and analysis to follow-up and lessons learned. The process must define clear escalation paths, assign roles (incident manager, analysis team) and ensure affected customers are informed promptly. The process must be regularly tested — e.g. through tabletop exercises.

maturity.level0: No defined incident response process; incidents are handled on an ad-hoc basis
maturity.level1: Basic responsibilities known but no documented process and no defined escalation paths
maturity.level2: Documented incident response process with roles, escalation paths and customer notification, but not regularly tested
maturity.level3: Comprehensive incident response process per C5:2020 SIM-01/02 with defined roles, escalation paths, automated detection, timely customer notification, follow-up and regular exercises

simQ2.title: Do you have documented business continuity plans for the cloud service?
simQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 BCM-01 and BCM-03 require business continuity plans (BCP) ensuring the maintenance or recovery of the cloud service during disruptions. Plans must define Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO).
simQ2.help: C5 requires documented business continuity plans specifying how the cloud service is maintained or recovered during various disruption scenarios. Plans must define RTO (maximum recovery time) and RPO (maximum data loss) for different scenarios, describe redundant infrastructure and failover mechanisms, and be regularly validated through tests (e.g. failover tests, disaster recovery exercises).

maturity.level0: No business continuity plans for the cloud service; no defined RTO/RPO
maturity.level1: Basic backup strategy in place but no comprehensive BCP and no defined RTO/RPO
maturity.level2: Documented BCP with defined RTO/RPO and redundant infrastructure, but tests not regular or scenarios not fully covered
maturity.level3: Comprehensive business continuity plans per C5:2020 BCM-01/03 with defined RTO/RPO, redundant infrastructure, documented failover mechanisms, regular testing and demonstrable updates after changes

simQ3.title: Are security incidents systematically analysed and do findings feed into improvements?
simQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 SIM-04 and SIM-05 require systematic analysis of security incidents and derivation of improvement measures (lessons learned). Incidents must be classified, documented and trends analysed.
simQ3.help: C5 requires that every security incident is systematically analysed after immediate measures are completed: What was the root cause? Could the incident have been detected earlier? What measures prevent recurrence? The results must feed into a continuous improvement process. Incidents must be classified (by severity, type, affected area) and trends analysed over time.

maturity.level0: No systematic incident analysis; same incident types occur repeatedly
maturity.level1: Occasional debriefs after severe incidents but no structured lessons-learned analysis
maturity.level2: Systematic post-incident analysis with documented findings and improvement measures, but no overarching trend analysis
maturity.level3: Comprehensive lessons-learned process per C5:2020 SIM-04/05 with structured incident analysis, classification, trend analysis, documented improvement measures and demonstrable implementation

devQ1.title: Are cloud applications developed following a secure software development lifecycle (SDLC)?
devQ1.tooltip: C5:2020 DEV-01 and DEV-02 require a secure software development process incorporating security requirements, code reviews, security testing and separation of development, test and production environments.
devQ1.help: C5 requires a documented Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC) integrating security into all phases of software development: security requirements in the design phase (Security by Design), secure coding guidelines, code reviews (ideally automated), static and dynamic security testing (SAST/DAST), strict separation of development, test and production environments and controlled release processes.

maturity.level0: No defined secure development process; security only considered after development (if at all)
maturity.level1: Basic coding guidelines in place but no systematic security testing or code reviews
maturity.level2: Documented SDLC with security requirements, code reviews and security testing, but not consistently applied across all projects or environment separation incomplete
maturity.level3: Complete Secure SDLC per C5:2020 DEV-01/02 with Security by Design, automated code reviews, SAST/DAST, strict environment separation and controlled release management

devQ2.title: Is procurement and deployment of cloud service components governed by security criteria?
devQ2.tooltip: C5:2020 SSO-01 and SSO-03 require security requirements for procurement and deployment of IT components for the cloud service. Security properties of third-party components must be assessed and their vulnerabilities monitored.
devQ2.help: C5 requires that all components used for the cloud service — whether software libraries, operating systems or hardware — are assessed for security properties before deployment. For third-party components, vulnerability notifications must be monitored and patches applied promptly (vulnerability management). Supply chain security must be considered.

maturity.level0: No security assessment for component procurement; no vulnerability monitoring for third-party components
maturity.level1: Basic security consideration for major procurements but no systematic process and no vulnerability monitoring
maturity.level2: Defined security criteria for procurement, vulnerability monitoring for critical components, but gaps in supply chain security
maturity.level3: Comprehensive procurement and component management process per C5:2020 SSO-01/03 with defined security criteria, systematic vulnerability monitoring, patch management and supply chain security

devQ3.title: Are independent audits (audits/penetration tests) of the cloud service regularly conducted?
devQ3.tooltip: C5:2020 PI-01 and PI-03 require regular independent reviews of the cloud service's information security. This includes both compliance audits and technical reviews such as penetration tests.
devQ3.help: C5 is an attestation-based standard: compliance with the criteria must be attested by independent auditors (similar to SOC 2). In addition to formal C5 audits, C5 requires regular technical security reviews (penetration tests, vulnerability scans). Results must be documented and identified vulnerabilities remediated promptly.

maturity.level0: No independent audits or penetration tests; no statement on the security status of the cloud service possible
maturity.level1: Occasional internal security reviews but no independent audits or professional penetration tests
maturity.level2: Regular penetration tests by external providers and vulnerability scans, but no formal C5 audit
maturity.level3: Comprehensive audit programme per C5:2020 PI-01/03 with formal C5 attestation by independent auditor, regular penetration tests, vulnerability scans and documented tracking of all findings

org1.title: Create an information security policy for cloud operations
org1.description: Create an overarching information security policy that explicitly addresses cloud operations. Have it approved by management and communicate it to all relevant employees. Define protection objectives, responsibilities and scope.
org1.firstStep: Download a cloud security policy template and adapt it to your organisation. Have the policy signed by senior management.

org2.title: Derive and implement topic-specific security policies
org2.description: Derive topic-specific security policies from the overarching policy for: access management, cryptography, physical security, operations, incident handling and personnel management. Each policy needs a designated owner and a review cycle.
org2.firstStep: Create an overview of all C5-relevant policy topics and prioritise creation by risk. Start with access control and cryptography.
org2.checklist:
- Access management policy
- Cryptography policy
- Physical security policy
- Operations manual
- Incident handling policy
- Personnel management policy
- Owners designated for each policy
- Review cycle defined

org3.title: Establish security training programme and personnel screening process
org3.description: Establish risk-proportionate background checks for cloud personnel and a role-specific information security training programme. Document attendance and effectiveness. Ensure training covers C5-specific topics.
org3.firstStep: Define roles with elevated security requirements in cloud operations and specify the required screening and training content for each role.
org3.checklist:
- Roles with elevated security requirements identified
- Background screening process documented
- Role-specific training content created
- Training schedule (at least annually)
- Attendance documentation
- Effectiveness verification (e.g. tests)

am1.title: Build a complete cloud asset inventory
am1.description: Create a complete inventory of all cloud-relevant assets: hardware, software, data and network components. Assign a responsible owner to each asset. Use automated discovery tools where possible.
am1.firstStep: Start by recording all production servers, storage systems and network components. Then expand to include software licences and data holdings.

am2.title: Introduce data classification scheme and derive handling rules
am2.description: Define a classification scheme with at least three protection levels (e.g. internal, confidential, strictly confidential) and derive concrete handling rules: encryption, access control, storage, transfer and deletion per protection level.
am2.firstStep: Define three to four protection levels and assign each type of customer data and cloud asset to a level. Start with the most sensitive data.
am2.checklist:
- Protection levels defined
- All data types classified
- Handling rules per level documented
- Encryption requirements derived
- Access rules derived
- Deletion procedures per level
- Employees trained

ps1.title: Implement physical security concept with zone model
ps1.description: Implement a multi-layered physical security concept for your data centre locations with defined security zones, electronic access control, video surveillance and visitor management. Conduct a gap analysis against C5 PS requirements.
ps1.firstStep: Document the current physical security status of all data centre locations and identify gaps against C5 requirements PS-01 to PS-05.

ps2.title: Environmental protection and secure disposal to C5 standard
ps2.description: Ensure comprehensive environmental protection for your data centres: redundant power supply, fire protection, water detection and climate control. Establish secure disposal processes for IT equipment with demonstrable data erasure.
ps2.firstStep: Conduct a stock-take of your infrastructure redundancies (power, cooling, suppression system) and compare with C5 PS-05 to PS-09.
ps2.checklist:
- UPS and standby generator present and tested
- Fire detection and suppression system installed
- Water detection under raised floor
- Redundant air conditioning
- Temperature and humidity monitoring
- Maintenance contracts current
- Disposal process documented
- Secure erasure to BSI standard
- Destruction records archived

idm1.title: Formalise user lifecycle management
idm1.description: Formalise the entire user lifecycle: registration with unique identification, approval workflow, role-based rights assignment and automated deactivation on departure. Eliminate shared accounts and log all changes.
idm1.firstStep: Record all existing user accounts and identify shared accounts, orphaned accounts and accounts without an assigned owner.

idm2.title: Introduce least-privilege principle and regular access reviews
idm2.description: Consistently implement the least-privilege principle for rights assignment. Introduce semi-annual access reviews where all access rights are reviewed by responsible persons and unnecessary rights are revoked.
idm2.firstStep: Conduct an initial access review of all privileged accounts (admin, root, database admin) and revoke rights no longer needed.

idm3.title: Implement strong authentication (MFA) and session management
idm3.description: Implement multi-factor authentication for all privileged and administrative access. Define a password policy with minimum requirements. Establish session management with timeouts and automatic lockout.
idm3.firstStep: Enable MFA for all administrative and privileged accounts as a first step. Then gradually extend to all user accounts.
idm3.checklist:
- MFA enabled for all admin accounts
- MFA enabled for all privileged accounts
- Password policy defined and enforced
- Session timeout configured
- Automatic lockout on inactivity
- Logging of all authentication attempts
- MFA rollout plan for all users

ops1.title: Document operational processes and build logging/monitoring
ops1.description: Document all key operational processes (change management, patch management, capacity planning) and build central logging and monitoring. Implement a SIEM system for detecting security-relevant events.
ops1.firstStep: Create an overview of all critical operational processes and prioritise their documentation. Start evaluating SIEM solutions in parallel.

ops2.title: Harden network security with segmentation and tenant isolation
ops2.description: Harden network security through consistent segmentation, tenant isolation, end-to-end encryption and monitoring. Implement IDS/IPS systems and conduct regular vulnerability scans.
ops2.firstStep: Document the current network architecture and identify missing segmentation and unencrypted communication paths.

kry1.title: Create cryptography policy aligned with BSI TR-02102
kry1.description: Create a cryptography policy aligned with BSI TR-02102. Define approved algorithms, minimum key lengths and protocols. Explicitly exclude outdated methods and plan a migration path for existing systems.
kry1.firstStep: Inventory all currently used cryptographic methods and compare them with BSI TR-02102 recommendations.

kry2.title: Build key management process with HSM support
kry2.description: Establish a complete key management process covering the entire lifecycle. Evaluate the use of Hardware Security Modules (HSM) for secure key generation and storage. Define rotation intervals and emergency procedures.
kry2.firstStep: Record all currently used cryptographic keys, their deployment location and last rotation. Identify keys without a designated owner.
kry2.checklist:
- Key inventory created
- Generation process defined
- HSM evaluated/implemented
- Rotation intervals set
- Archiving process
- Destruction process
- Emergency procedure for compromise
- BYOK option for customers evaluated

sim1.title: Define incident response process with escalation paths
sim1.description: Define a complete incident response process with clear roles, escalation paths and customer notification obligations. Conduct regular tabletop exercises to test effectiveness and identify weaknesses.
sim1.firstStep: Create an incident response playbook for the 5 most common incident scenarios (e.g. ransomware, data breach, DDoS, insider threat, supply chain attack).

sim2.title: Build business continuity management with RTO/RPO
sim2.description: Establish business continuity management for the cloud service with defined RTO/RPO, redundant infrastructure and documented failover mechanisms. Test plans regularly through disaster recovery exercises.
sim2.firstStep: Conduct a business impact analysis (BIA) for the cloud service and define RTO and RPO for each critical function.
sim2.checklist:
- Business impact analysis completed
- RTO/RPO per critical function defined
- Redundant infrastructure documented
- Failover mechanisms implemented
- Backup strategy documented
- Disaster recovery plan created
- DR test conducted
- Results documented and gaps remediated

dev1.title: Implement Secure Development Lifecycle (SDLC)
dev1.description: Implement a Secure Development Lifecycle with Security by Design, secure coding guidelines, automated code reviews (SAST/DAST), strict environment separation and controlled release management. Train developers in secure programming.
dev1.firstStep: Introduce SAST tools (Static Application Security Testing) into your CI/CD pipeline and define secure coding guidelines for the most commonly used programming languages.

dev2.title: Prepare C5 audit programme with independent review
dev2.description: Prepare for formal C5 attestation by an independent auditor. Conduct regular internal audits and penetration tests. Establish a process for tracking and promptly remediating findings.
dev2.firstStep: Conduct a C5 self-assessment gap analysis to identify and prioritise the biggest gaps before a formal audit.
dev2.checklist:
- C5 self-assessment completed
- Gap analysis documented
- Remediation plan created
- Penetration test commissioned
- Vulnerability scans regular
- Finding tracking process
- Auditor for C5 audit selected
- Type 1 report planned

q1.title: Do you have a documented information security policy for your cloud service?
q1.description: A management-approved policy defining protection objectives, responsibilities and the scope of the cloud service (C5 OIS-01/02).

q2.title: Do you maintain a complete inventory of all cloud assets and customer data?
q2.description: A current register of all hardware, software, data and network components with assigned owners (C5 AM-01/02).

q3.title: Are your data centres protected by multi-layered physical security measures?
q3.description: Security zones with access control, video surveillance, environmental protection (fire, water, power) and visitor management (C5 PS-01/05).

q4.title: Is there a formal process for user registration and rights revocation?
q4.description: Documented lifecycle process with approval, role-based rights assignment and timely deactivation on departure (C5 IDM-01/02).

q5.title: Is multi-factor authentication enabled for privileged access?
q5.description: MFA for all administrative and privileged cloud access plus a defined password policy (C5 IDM-07/08).

q6.title: Are security events centrally logged and monitored?
q6.description: Central logging of all security-relevant events with tamper-proof storage and timely analysis (C5 OPS-07/08).

q7.title: Do you use current encryption standards for customer data (transit + at rest)?
q7.description: Encryption of all customer data in transit and at rest using current algorithms per BSI recommendations (C5 KRY-01/04).

q8.title: Is there a documented incident response process with escalation paths?
q8.description: Defined process for detecting, reporting, analysing and responding to security incidents with clear responsibilities (C5 SIM-01/02).

q9.title: Do you have business continuity plans with defined RTO/RPO?
q9.description: Documented plans for maintaining/recovering the cloud service with tested failover mechanisms (C5 BCM-01/03).

q10.title: Are independent security audits or penetration tests regularly conducted?
q10.description: Regular external audits, penetration tests and vulnerability scans with documented tracking of results (C5 PI-01/03).
