notfallKontakte.title: Emergency Contacts IT Security
notfallKontakte.subtitle: Key contacts for IT security incidents in Germany

immediate.title: Immediate Contacts (24/7)
immediate.bsiDesc: Central contact point for critical infrastructure operators and NIS2-regulated companies. Mandatory reports go here.
immediate.certDesc: National CERT for federal authorities and critical infrastructure. Technical emergency assistance for cyberattacks.
immediate.polizeiDesc: Every German state has a specialized ZAC unit for cybercrime. File a report for ransomware, data theft, or digital extortion.

reporting.title: Reporting Obligations by Regulation
reporting.nis2Deadline: 24 hours early warning, 72 hours full report, 1 month final report
reporting.dsgvoDeadline: 72 hours to supervisory authority, immediately to affected persons if high risk
reporting.doraDeadline: Immediate initial report, 72h follow-up, 1 month final report

forensics.title: Forensics & Incident Response
forensics.allianzTitle: Alliance for Cyber Security — Service Provider Directory
forensics.allianzDesc: The BSI maintains a list of qualified IT security service providers for incident response and forensics.
forensics.tip1: Do NOT shut down affected systems — preserve evidence!
forensics.tip2: Isolate network segments, do not delete
forensics.tip4: Communicate through separate channels (attackers may be monitoring)
forensics.tip5: Do not pay ransom — contact police

datenschutz.title: State Data Protection Authorities
datenschutz.desc: For GDPR reports, contact the supervisory authority of your federal state.
datenschutz.bfdiTitle: BfDI — Federal Commissioner for Data Protection
datenschutz.bfdiDesc: Responsible for federal authorities and telecommunications companies.
datenschutz.landesDesc: For private sector companies: Contact the authority of the state where your company is headquartered.

checklist.title: Emergency Checklist
checklist.step1: Detect and document the incident (What, When, How, Who?)
checklist.step3: Isolate affected systems (do NOT shut down)
checklist.step4: Contact BSI reporting office (if NIS2/KRITIS obligation)
checklist.step6: Inform data protection authority (if personal data affected, 72h deadline)
checklist.step8: Notify affected persons (GDPR Art. 34, if high risk)
checklist.step9: Create final report and document lessons learned

anlaufstellen.title: Advisory & Support Organizations

bsi.services: IT-Grundschutz Compendium, BSI Standards 200-1/2/3, Threat Alerts, Certification

acs.title: Alliance for Cyber Security (ACS)

foerdermittel.title: Funding for IT Security
foerdermittel.subtitle: Financial support for your IT security measures — from federal, state, and EU programs

examples.hessen: Hesse: Digi-Zuschuss — up to EUR 10,000 (50% funding)

eu.enisa: ENISA Initiatives: Support for national cybersecurity strategies

mythenFaq.title: IT Security: Myths & Facts
mythenFaq.subtitle: The most common misconceptions about IT security — and what's really true
mythenFaq.intro: Many companies have a false sense of security because they believe widespread myths. Here we debunk the most common misconceptions.

m1.myth: We're too small — hackers aren't interested in us
m1.fact: 43% of all cyberattacks target SMEs. Small companies are attractive targets precisely because they are often poorly protected. Automated attacks don't distinguish by company size.

m2.fact: A firewall is important, but only ONE layer. Most successful attacks use social engineering (phishing), stolen credentials, or software vulnerabilities. IT security needs multiple protection layers (Defense in Depth).

m3.myth: We have nothing valuable for attackers
m3.fact: Every company has valuable data: customer data, bank details, trade secrets, access to partner systems. Ransomware simply encrypts everything — the damage comes from business interruption.

m4.myth: Cloud is insecure — our data belongs on our own servers
m4.fact: Professional cloud providers invest millions in security, have 24/7 teams and certified data centers. For most SMEs, the cloud is MORE SECURE than the server in the basement — when properly configured.

m5.myth: Our IT service provider handles everything
m5.fact: IT service providers are important, but responsibility for IT security remains with the company. Many service contracts don't cover security incidents. Check your contract and SLAs.

m6.myth: IT security is too expensive for us
m6.fact: The most important measures cost little or nothing: Enable MFA, regular backups, software updates, employee training. A ransomware incident costs on average EUR 255,000 — prevention is cheaper.

m7.myth: We use Apple/Mac — those are secure
m7.fact: No operating system is immune. macOS malware tripled in 2023. Social engineering and phishing work regardless of operating system. Apple devices also need updates, MFA, and backups.

m8.myth: We have a backup — nothing can happen to us
m8.fact: A backup is essential, but: Is it regularly tested? Is it stored offline/air-gapped? Modern ransomware specifically searches for backups and encrypts them too. The 3-2-1 rule is the minimum.

m9.myth: Data protection and IT security are the same thing
m9.fact: Data protection (GDPR) protects personal data. IT security protects ALL data and systems. They overlap, but IT security goes further — it also covers availability, trade secrets, and OT systems.

m10.fact: NIS2 affects companies with 50+ employees OR EUR 10M+ revenue in regulated sectors. In Germany, that's an estimated 30,000 companies — including many mid-sized businesses. Suppliers can also be affected.

q1.question: What's the difference between NIS2 and GDPR?
q1.answer: GDPR protects personal data and applies to ALL companies. NIS2 protects critical IT infrastructure and only applies to regulated sectors. Both can apply simultaneously and have different reporting obligations.

q2.question: Do I need to appoint a CISO (Chief Information Security Officer)?
q2.answer: NIS2 doesn't require a formal CISO, but management must take responsibility for and oversee IT security. In practice, a CISO or external consultant is almost indispensable for implementation.

q3.question: What happens if I don't implement NIS2?
q3.answer: Fines up to EUR 10 million or 2% of global annual revenue. Additionally: Personal liability of management (§38 BSIG-E), BSI enforcement orders, and potential reputational damage.

q4.question: What's the best way to start with IT security?
q4.answer: Three immediate measures: 1) Enable MFA everywhere, 2) Regular backups (3-2-1 rule), 3) Keep software up to date. Then: Do our quick check and work through the quick wins.

q5.question: Do I need ISO 27001 certification?
q5.answer: Not necessarily. ISO 27001 is a voluntary standard but can facilitate NIS2 compliance. For many SMEs, the BSI IT-Grundschutz check or a structured risk analysis is sufficient as a starting point.

q6.question: How long does NIS2 implementation take?
q6.answer: Depending on the starting point, 6-18 months. The most important quick wins (MFA, backup, awareness) can be implemented in days. Building a complete ISMS typically takes 12+ months.

toolStack.title: Recommended IT Security Tools
toolStack.subtitle: Field-tested tools for SMEs — from free to enterprise
toolStack.intro: The right tool selection is critical for effective IT security. Here you'll find rated recommendations in every category — with free alternatives for getting started.
toolStack.disclaimer: This list does not constitute advertising. All recommendations are based on practical experience and publicly available reviews. We receive no commissions.

passwords.title: Password Management
passwords.why: 80% of data breaches trace back to weak or reused passwords.

t1.name: Bitwarden
t1.desc: Cross-platform, self-hosting possible, GDPR-compliant. Best choice for SMEs.

t2.name: KeePass / KeePassXC
t2.desc: Local database, no cloud required. Ideal for offline requirements and high security demands.

t3.name: 1Password Business
t3.desc: Easy team management, SSO integration, compliance reports.

mfa.title: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
mfa.why: MFA blocks 99.9% of all automated account attacks.

t1.name: Microsoft Authenticator
t1.desc: Integrated with Microsoft 365, push notifications, backup function.

t2.name: Yubico YubiKey
t2.desc: FIDO2/WebAuthn hardware key. Highest security, phishing-resistant.

t3.name: Duo Security (Cisco)
t3.desc: Central MFA management for all applications, easy rollout.

backup.title: Backup & Recovery
backup.why: Without a working backup, a ransomware attack is existentially threatening.

t1.name: Veeam Backup Free
t1.desc: Standard for VM backups, also physical servers. Community Edition free up to 10 workloads.

t2.name: Duplicati
t2.desc: Encrypted backups to any cloud (S3, Azure, SFTP). Automation by schedule.

t3.name: Acronis Cyber Protect
t3.desc: Backup + anti-malware in one. GDPR-compliant data center in Germany.

endpoint.title: Endpoint Protection / Antivirus
endpoint.why: Endpoint protection is the last line of defense on every device.

t2.name: ClamAV

t3.name: ESET PROTECT
t3.desc: Lightweight, good detection rate, central management for SMEs.

firewall.title: Firewall & Network Security
firewall.why: The firewall controls data traffic between your network and the internet.

vulnerability.title: Vulnerability Scanners

freelancerBasics.title: IT Security for Freelancers
freelancerBasics.subtitle: Essential measures for self-employed and solo entrepreneurs
freelancerBasics.intro: As a freelancer, you're the CEO, IT department, and data protection officer all in one. The good news: A few targeted measures protect you effectively — while meeting your legal obligations.

why.title: Why IT Security Matters for Freelancers
why.reason1: You process client data — GDPR applies to individuals too
why.reason2: Data loss can be existentially threatening (no backup = no business)
why.reason4: Cyber insurance policies check minimum standards before enrollment

i1.title: Strong Passwords + Password Manager
i1.desc: Use a password manager (e.g., Bitwarden) and unique passwords for every service. Never reuse a password.

i2.title: Enable MFA Everywhere
i2.desc: Multi-factor authentication for email, cloud, banking, and all business-critical services. Preferably via authenticator app, not SMS.

i3.title: Regular Backups (3-2-1)
i3.desc: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 offsite/offline. Test recovery regularly. Cloud backup + external drive = minimum.

i4.title: Keep Software Up to Date
i4.desc: Enable automatic updates for operating system, browser, and applications. Outdated software is an invitation for attackers.

i5.title: Device Encryption
i5.desc: Enable BitLocker (Windows) or FileVault (Mac). Your data is protected in case of theft. Also encrypt external drives.

i6.title: Secure WiFi and VPN
i6.desc: Never use open WiFi without VPN. Own WiFi with WPA3 and strong password. VPN for client access and public networks.

i7.title: Email Security
i7.desc: Phishing is attack vector #1. Critically check links and attachments. No sensitive data via unencrypted email. When in doubt, verify with the sender.

i8.title: Implement GDPR Basics
i8.desc: Maintain processing records, conclude data processing agreements (DPA) with service providers, update privacy policy on website.

i9.title: Create an Emergency Plan
i9.desc: What to do in case of data loss, ransomware, or laptop theft? Write it down before it happens. Contacts, credentials, recovery steps.

i10.title: Check Professional Liability
i10.desc: Many professional liability insurance policies don't cover cyber incidents. Check your coverage and consider separate cyber insurance.

items.i1: Maintain processing records per Art. 30 GDPR
items.i2: Data processing agreements (DPA) with cloud services and subcontractors
items.i3: Privacy policy on website and in proposals
items.i4: Document technical and organizational measures (TOMs)
items.i5: Be able to respond to access and deletion requests from clients
items.i6: Report data breaches to supervisory authority within 72 hours

costs.title: What Does It Cost?
costs.freeItems: Password manager (Bitwarden Free), MFA (Authenticator apps), Updates, Encryption (BitLocker/FileVault), GDPR templates
costs.lowItems: Cloud backup (e.g., EUR 2/month), VPN service (EUR 3-5/month), external backup drive (EUR 50-80 one-time)
costs.mediumItems: Password manager premium, cyber insurance (from EUR 100/year), professional email service

soloCheck.title: Solo Security Check
soloCheck.subtitle: 10 questions for self-employed and solo entrepreneurs — in 3 minutes
soloCheck.intro: Quickly and easily check how well you're set up in terms of IT security as a self-employed person. Honest answers give a realistic picture.

q1.title: Do you use a password manager for all business credentials?
q1.tip: Bitwarden or KeePass are free and secure.

q2.title: Is multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled for email and cloud?
q2.tip: MFA blocks 99.9% of automated account takeovers.

q3.title: Do you have a working backup following the 3-2-1 rule?
q3.tip: 3 copies, 2 media, 1 offsite. Test your recovery!

q4.title: Are all devices (laptop, phone) running current software with automatic updates?
q4.tip: 90% of attacks exploit known, already-patched vulnerabilities.

q5.title: Is your hard drive encrypted (BitLocker/FileVault)?
q5.tip: In case of theft, encryption prevents data access.

q6.title: Do you use a VPN on public networks?
q6.tip: Public WiFi without VPN = open postcard.

q7.title: Do you have a processing records directory (GDPR Art. 30)?
q7.tip: Mandatory for EVERYONE who processes personal data.

q8.title: Do you have DPA contracts with your cloud service providers?
q8.tip: Data processing agreement — most providers offer them.

q9.title: Do you know what to do in case of data loss (emergency plan)?

q10.title: Does your insurance cover cyber incidents?
q10.tip: Many professional liability policies explicitly exclude cyber.

excellent.title: Exemplary (9-10 points)
excellent.desc: You've covered the basics excellently. Stay on track and review regularly.

good.title: Well positioned (7-8 points)
good.desc: Solid foundation in place. Close the remaining gaps promptly.

needsWork.title: Action needed (4-6 points)
needsWork.desc: Some important basics are missing. Prioritize MFA, backup, and updates.

critical.title: Urgent action needed (0-3 points)
critical.desc: Your business is significantly at risk. Start immediately with our quick wins.

homeOffice.title: IT Security for Remote Work
homeOffice.subtitle: Protect your data outside the office
homeOffice.intro: Remote work is the new standard — but IT security often lags behind. Here you'll find concrete measures to protect your company and employees when working from home.

i1.title: Mandatory VPN
i1.desc: All access to company resources exclusively via VPN. Avoid split tunneling. For cloud services: use Conditional Access Policies.

i2.title: Secure WiFi
i2.desc: Home network with WPA3 (minimum WPA2), strong password, and current router firmware. Separate guest network for IoT devices and personal use.

i3.title: No Public WiFi
i3.desc: Only use public hotspots with active VPN. Better: Use mobile hotspot from company phone.

i1.title: Prefer Company Devices
i1.desc: Ideally the company provides laptop and phone. BYOD only with clear policy, MDM solution, and private/business separation.

i2.title: Disk Encryption
i2.desc: BitLocker (Windows) or FileVault (Mac) is mandatory on all devices with company data. Also encrypt USB drives and external hard drives.

i3.title: Automatic Updates
i3.desc: Set OS, browser, Office, and all applications to automatic updates. No delay longer than 48 hours.

i4.title: Screen Lock
i4.desc: Automatic lock after 5 minutes of inactivity. Windows: Win+L, Mac: Ctrl+Cmd+Q. Lock even for short absences.

i1.title: No Local Storage
i1.desc: Company data belongs in the cloud/on the server — not on the local desktop. In case of loss/theft, local data is gone.

i2.title: Clean Desk Policy
i2.desc: At home too: Keep confidential printouts in locked drawers, use a shredder (min. P-4), position screen so roommates can't see.

i3.title: Printers & Scanners
i3.desc: Secure home network printers with password. Don't leave print jobs unattended. Don't leave scanned documents on the device.

i1.title: Secure Messengers
i1.desc: Only use company-approved communication tools. Never send company data via WhatsApp, Telegram, or personal email.

i2.title: Secure Video Conferences
i2.desc: Don't share meeting links publicly, enable waiting rooms, restrict screen sharing. For confidential topics: change rooms, use headphones.

i3.title: Phishing Vigilance
i3.desc: Phishing risk increases in home office — no colleague to ask in person. When in doubt: don't click, ask IT. Check sender address carefully.

i1.title: Secure Workspace
i1.desc: Never leave laptop visible in car. When traveling: devices in carry-on. At home: lockable office or store devices securely.

i2.title: Kensington Lock
i2.desc: For coworking spaces and shared rooms: use a physical laptop lock.

items.i1: VPN usage is mandatory for all company access
items.i2: Only authorized devices and software may be used
items.i3: Company data must not be stored locally or on personal devices
items.i4: Screen lock when leaving the workspace is mandatory
items.i5: Report suspicious emails to IT immediately, do not forward
items.i6: Do not discuss confidential matters in public spaces
items.i7: Report security incidents to CISO/IT immediately — also from home office

legal.title: Legal Basis
legal.dsgvo: GDPR Art. 32: Appropriate technical and organizational measures — also applies at the home workplace
legal.nis2: NIS2 Art. 21: Cyber hygiene and training encompass remote work scenarios
legal.arbeitsrecht: Employers are liable for data protection violations by employees — also in home office

hinschg.title: Whistleblower Protection Act (HinSchG)
hinschg.subtitle: Whistleblowing obligations for companies — what you need to know
hinschg.intro: Since July 2023, companies with 50+ employees must establish internal reporting channels. The Whistleblower Protection Act protects persons who report misconduct — including IT security incidents.

items.i1: Companies with 50+ employees: Obligation to establish internal reporting channel
items.i2: Companies with 250+ employees: In effect since 02.07.2023
items.i3: Companies with 50-249 employees: In effect since 17.12.2023
items.i4: Financial sector, anti-money laundering obligated: Regardless of size

items.i1: Violations of EU law (data protection, IT security, consumer protection, environment)
items.i2: Violations of national law (criminal law, administrative offenses)
items.i3: IT security incidents that are being covered up
items.i4: Data protection breaches (GDPR violations)

i1.title: Establish Internal Reporting Channel
i1.desc: Written, verbal, and upon request in person. Can be staffed internally or outsourced to an external service provider.

i2.title: Ensure Confidentiality
i2.desc: The identity of the whistleblower must be protected. Only authorized persons may access reports.

i3.title: Respond Within Deadlines
i3.desc: Acknowledgment of receipt within 7 days. Feedback to the whistleblower within 3 months.

i4.title: Prohibition of Retaliation
i4.desc: Whistleblowers must not be disadvantaged: No termination, no warning, no transfer because of a report.

i5.title: Documentation
i5.desc: All reports must be documented and retained for 3 years after closure. GDPR-compliant.

itSecurity.title: Connection to IT Security
itSecurity.desc: The HinSchG is directly relevant to IT security:

items.i1: IT security incidents can be reported through the internal reporting channel
items.i2: Employees who discover vulnerabilities or violations are protected
items.i3: NIS2 and GDPR violations fall within the scope of application
items.i4: The reporting channel itself must be operated securely (encryption, access control)

items.i1: No/inadequate reporting channel: up to EUR 20,000
items.i2: Obstruction of reports: up to EUR 50,000
items.i3: Retaliation against whistleblowers: up to EUR 50,000
items.i4: Breach of confidentiality: up to EUR 50,000

internal.title: Internal Solution
internal.desc: Own trusted person or compliance department. Advantage: proximity to the company. Disadvantage: potentially less trust from employees.

external.title: External Service Provider
external.desc: Specialized provider operates the reporting channel. Advantage: independence, professional processing. Disadvantage: costs, less company proximity.

digital.title: Digital Reporting Systems
digital.desc: Web-based platforms for anonymous reports. Advantage: low threshold, 24/7 available, traceable. Examples: Hintbox, BKMS, EQS Integrity Line.

externalChannel.title: External Reporting Channel
externalChannel.desc: In addition to internal reporting, whistleblowers can also contact the federal external reporting office directly:
externalChannel.name: Federal Office of Justice — External Reporting Office

checklisten.title: IT Security Checklists
checklisten.subtitle: Ready-to-use checklists for your daily operations
checklisten.intro: Print these checklists or save them digitally. Every checklist is field-tested and tailored to SMEs.

incident.title: Incident Response Checklist
incident.desc: What to do during an IT security incident — step by step

items.i1: Detect incident and determine type (Ransomware, Phishing, Data Leak, DDoS?)
items.i2: Document timestamp and note first reporter
items.i3: Inform crisis team / CISO / IT management
items.i4: Identify and isolate affected systems
items.i5: Preserve evidence: Logs, screenshots, network traffic
items.i6: Check reporting obligations (NIS2: 24h, GDPR: 72h, KRITIS: immediately)
items.i9: Inform data protection authority (if personal data affected)
items.i13: Create final report and document lessons learned

onboarding.title: IT Onboarding Checklist
onboarding.desc: Secure onboarding of new employees — IT security from day 1

items.i1: Set up individual user accounts (no shared accounts)
items.i2: Assign permissions by least privilege principle
items.i3: Enable MFA for all systems
items.i4: Hand over company device with current software
items.i5: Activate and verify disk encryption
items.i6: Set up and test VPN access
items.i7: Provide password manager and explain usage
items.i8: Issue IT security policy and have it signed
items.i9: Conduct security awareness training (phishing, social engineering)
items.i11: Explain emergency contacts and reporting channels

offboarding.title: IT Offboarding Checklist
offboarding.desc: Secure offboarding — no access after the last working day

items.i1: Revoke all access and permissions on the departure date
items.i2: Deactivate email account, set up forwarding
items.i3: Remove VPN access
items.i4: Reset MFA tokens/authenticator app
items.i5: Collect company-owned devices
items.i6: Perform remote wipe on BYOD devices
items.i8: Check cloud services (Dropbox, Google Drive, etc.)

patchManagement.title: Patch Management Checklist
patchManagement.desc: Structured update management — close vulnerabilities in time

items.i1: Keep inventory of all systems and software up to date
items.i2: Define patch sources (vendors, CERT-Bund, NVD)
items.i3: Apply critical patches within 24-48 hours
items.i4: Apply normal patches monthly in maintenance window
items.i5: Test patches in staging environment first (if possible)
items.i6: Have rollback plan ready for failed patches
items.i8: Identify end-of-life software and create replacement plan
items.i9: Regularly audit and document patch status

backup.title: Backup Verification Checklist
backup.desc: Backups are only as good as their last successful recovery

items.i1: Follow the 3-2-1 rule (3 copies, 2 media, 1 offsite)
items.i2: Keep at least one backup offline/air-gapped
items.i3: Enable backup encryption and store keys securely
items.i4: Perform monthly recovery test (sample)
items.i5: Perform quarterly full restore test
items.i6: RTO and RPO defined and documented?
items.i7: Backup monitoring: automatically alert on failed jobs
items.i8: Backup target protected from ransomware (immutable storage)?
items.i9: Backup documentation current (What, Where, How often, Who)?

selbsterklaerung.title: IT Security Self-Declaration
selbsterklaerung.subtitle: How to demonstrate your IT security to clients and partners
selbsterklaerung.intro: More and more clients require their suppliers to provide proof of IT security. A structured self-declaration is often the first step — and sufficient for many SMEs.

items.i1: Clients require security evidence in tenders and supplier audits
items.i2: NIS2 Art. 21(3): Supply chain security — YOU as a supplier are affected too
items.i3: TISAX: Virtually mandatory for all suppliers in the automotive industry
items.i4: Cyber insurance policies require documented security measures
items.i5: A good self-declaration is a competitive advantage over competitors without proof

basic.title: Level 1: Self-Declaration
basic.desc: You document your own IT security measures. No external auditor needed. The right entry point for most SMEs.

standard.title: Level 2: Light Certification
standard.desc: External review against a defined standard (e.g., DIN SPEC 27076, BSI-Grundschutz-Check). Medium effort, high credibility.

advanced.title: Level 3: Full Certification
advanced.desc: ISO 27001, TISAX, or C5. Comprehensive audit by accredited body. Highest level, for large clients or regulated industries.

s1.title: 1. Company Data
s1.desc: Name, industry, number of employees, IT contact person, date

s2.title: 2. Organizational Measures
s2.desc: IT security policy in place? CISO appointed? Regular training? Roles and responsibilities defined?

s3.title: 3. Technical Measures
s3.desc: Firewall, antivirus, encryption, MFA, patch management, backup (3-2-1), network segmentation

s4.title: 4. Incident Response
s4.desc: Emergency plan in place? Reporting channels defined? Forensics partner named? Last drill conducted?

s5.title: 5. Data Protection
s5.desc: GDPR compliance, processing records, DPA with service providers, TOMs documented

s6.title: 6. Supply Chain
s6.desc: Own suppliers/service providers evaluated? Security requirements included in contracts?

s7.title: 7. Certificates & Evidence
s7.desc: Existing certificates (ISO 27001, TISAX, etc.), latest audit results, penetration tests

s8.title: 8. Management Declaration
s8.desc: Signature of management with date and commitment to continuous improvement

i1.name: DIN SPEC 27076
i1.desc: IT security standard developed specifically for SMEs. 27 requirements in 6 categories. Good entry point.

i2.name: BSI IT-Grundschutz-Check
i2.desc: Self-assessment against BSI standards. Free, recognized, comprehensive.

i3.name: VdS 10000
i3.desc: Guideline for information security in SMEs. Practical, recognized as basis for cyber insurance.

i4.name: TISAX
i4.desc: Automotive industry standard. Mandatory for suppliers of VW, BMW, Mercedes etc.

i5.name: ISO 27001
i5.desc: International gold standard. Comprehensive but demanding. For larger companies or international business relationships.

items.i2: Use our quick check as a starting point for your self-declaration

items.i5: Keep evidence (training records, test results, policy versions)

kiCheck.title: AI Compliance Check
kiCheck.subtitle: Using artificial intelligence compliantly — EU AI Act, GDPR and practical guidance
kiCheck.intro: Using AI systems offers enormous potential but also comes with regulatory obligations. Since August 2024, the EU AI Act applies. Here's what your company needs to know.

aiAct.title: EU AI Act Overview
aiAct.desc: The world's first comprehensive AI regulation has been in effect since August 2024 with staggered deadlines.

timeline.title: Timeline
timeline.t1: February 2025: Ban on unacceptable AI practices (social scoring, real-time biometrics)
timeline.t2: August 2025: Rules for general-purpose AI models (GPAI) including ChatGPT, Gemini etc.
timeline.t3: August 2026: Full application — all obligations for high-risk AI systems
timeline.t4: August 2027: Review and possible adjustment by EU Commission

unacceptable.desc: Prohibited: Social scoring, manipulative AI, indiscriminate biometric surveillance
unacceptable.label: PROHIBITED

high.title: High Risk
high.desc: Strict requirements: AI in recruitment, credit scoring, critical infrastructure, medical devices
high.label: Strict Requirements

limited.title: Limited Risk
limited.desc: Transparency obligation: Chatbots must be labeled as AI, deepfakes must be marked
limited.label: Transparency Required

minimal.title: Minimal Risk

minimal.label: No Requirements

items.i1: Review all AI tools you use — ChatGPT, Copilot, image generators, automations
items.i2: Document the purpose of each AI system (transparency obligation)

items.i4: AI-generated content must be labeled
items.i5: Train employees in responsible AI use
items.i6: Fines for violations: up to EUR 35 million or 7% of annual turnover

dsgvo.title: AI and Data Protection (GDPR)

i1.title: Check legal basis
i1.desc: Processing personal data through AI requires a legal basis (Art. 6 GDPR)

i2.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)

i3.title: Data Processing Agreement
i3.desc: Cloud AI services (OpenAI, Google, Microsoft) require DPA under Art. 28 GDPR

i4.title: Data subject rights
i4.desc: Automated individual decisions (Art. 22 GDPR) — individuals have the right to human review

i5.title: Third-country transfer
i5.desc: US cloud AI services: Verification of adequate data protection level required

items.i1: Inventory of all AI systems in use created
items.i2: Risk level of each system classified per AI Act
items.i3: GDPR compliance verified (legal basis, DPA, DPIA)
items.i4: Transparency obligations implemented (AI labeling)
items.i5: Employee training on AI usage conducted
items.i6: Responsible person for AI governance appointed
items.i8: Regular review of AI systems scheduled

items.i2: Create an internal AI policy (what's allowed, what's not)
items.i3: Prohibit entering confidential data into public AI services
items.i4: Use European/German AI alternatives where possible
items.i5: Budget for AI training — competence is the best protection

fortschritt.title: Measuring & Improving IT Security
fortschritt.subtitle: Maturity models, KPIs and continuous improvement for your IT security

maturity.title: BSI Maturity Model
maturity.desc: The BSI defines 6 maturity levels for building an Information Security Management System (ISMS).

l0.title: Level 0 — Non-existent
l0.desc: No conscious approach to IT security, no measures defined

l1.title: Level 1 — Started
l1.desc: Initial measures initiated but not yet systematically implemented

l2.title: Level 2 — Implemented
l2.desc: Essential measures are implemented, documentation exists

l3.title: Level 3 — Managed
l3.desc: Processes are defined, actively managed and measured

l4.title: Level 4 — Optimized
l4.desc: Continuous improvement, regular audits and adjustments

l5.title: Level 5 — Excellent
l5.desc: Best practice, proactive security culture, certification-ready

i1.title: Patch Rate

i2.title: MFA Coverage

i6.title: Vulnerability Scan Coverage

pdca.title: PDCA Cycle for IT Security

plan.title: Plan
plan.desc: Identify risks, set objectives, plan measures, allocate resources

do.desc: Implement measures, train employees, introduce processes

check.title: Check

q1.title: Quarter 1 — Build Foundation
q1.items: Assessment, Asset inventory, Password policy, Backup strategy, First training

q3.title: Quarter 3 — Deepen
q3.items: Risk assessment, RoPA, Access management, Supplier evaluation, Emergency handbook

items.i3: Involve management — IT security is a leadership responsibility
items.i4: Document EVERYTHING — what isn't documented doesn't exist

awarenessQuiz.title: Security Awareness Quiz
awarenessQuiz.subtitle: Test your IT security knowledge — 15 questions for everyday work
awarenessQuiz.intro: How well are you and your employees prepared for cyberattacks? This quiz covers the most common attack scenarios and provides immediate feedback with explanations.

result.title: Your Result
result.excellent: Excellent! You are very well prepared for cyber threats.
result.good: Good! Solid basic knowledge, but there's room for improvement.
result.needsWork: Needs work. Regular training sessions would help here.
result.critical: Critical. Strong recommendation: Conduct security awareness training.

q1.question: You receive an email from your bank asking you to update your credentials. The link leads to a page that looks like your bank. What do you do?
q1.a: Click the link and enter data
q1.b: Ignore the email and go directly to the bank's website
q1.c: Forward the email to a colleague
q1.explanation: Banks never ask for credentials via email. Always go directly to the official website or call to verify.

q2.question: Which password is most secure?
q2.explanation: A secure password is long, random and contains upper/lowercase letters, numbers and special characters. Dictionary attacks crack simple passwords in seconds.

q3.question: A USB stick is found on the company parking lot. What's the correct response?
q3.a: Plug it in and check who it belongs to
q3.b: Hand it to the IT department
q3.c: Take it home and check there
q3.explanation: Unknown USB sticks can contain malware (USB drop attack). Always hand them to IT, who can safely analyze the device.

q4.question: You're working on confidential documents in a cafe. Which measure is most important?
q4.a: Talking on the phone loudly is OK as long as no one reads along
q4.b: Use a privacy screen filter and VPN
q4.c: Public WiFi without VPN is secure enough
q4.d: Leave documents openly on the table
q4.explanation: Privacy screen filters prevent visual hacking, VPN encrypts data traffic. Public WiFi networks are fundamentally insecure.

q5.question: What is Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)?
q5.b: Login with at least two different factors
q5.explanation: MFA combines something you know (password) with something you have (phone/token) or something you are (fingerprint). This protects even when a password is stolen.

q6.question: Your computer suddenly shows: 'Your files have been encrypted. Pay 5 Bitcoin.' What do you do?
q6.a: Pay immediately so the files come back
q6.b: Disconnect from network and inform IT
q6.d: Click away the message and continue working
q6.explanation: For ransomware, immediately unplug the network cable/disable WiFi to prevent spreading. Inform IT/CERT. NEVER pay ransom — no guarantee of decryption.

q7.question: A caller claims to be Microsoft support and wants remote access to your PC. What do you do?
q7.b: Hang up — Microsoft never calls unsolicited
q7.d: Note the phone number and call back later
q7.explanation: Tech support scam is a common fraud. Microsoft, Apple & Co. NEVER call unsolicited. Hang up immediately and report the incident.

q8.question: How often should backups of your most important data be created at minimum?
q8.explanation: The 3-2-1 rule recommends: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 copy offsite. Daily for business-critical data, weekly as minimum.

q9.question: What does 'Social Engineering' mean?
q9.explanation: Social engineering exploits human psychology (trust, fear, urgency) to bypass security measures. Humans are often the weakest link.

q10.question: You notice a colleague has their password on a sticky note on their monitor. What do you do?
q10.a: Nothing, it's none of my business
q10.b: Kindly point out the risk to the colleague
q10.d: Tell the entire department about it
q10.explanation: Security is teamwork. Kindly point out risks to colleagues. Password managers are the secure alternative to sticky notes.

q11.question: Which file extension is particularly dangerous in email attachments?
q11.explanation: .exe files are executable programs and can contain malware. Also .scr, .bat, .cmd, .vbs and Office files with macros (.docm, .xlsm) are risky.

q12.question: What is the most important step after an IT security incident?
q12.d: Wait and see if it happens again
q12.explanation: Documentation and reporting are essential — for forensic analysis, reporting obligations (NIS2, GDPR) and preventing future incidents.

q13.question: Your smartphone is lost. What's the most important first step?
q13.b: Remote wipe device and change all passwords
q13.c: Wait for it to turn up
q13.d: Do nothing, the phone is locked
q13.explanation: Immediately remote wipe (Find My iPhone/Google Find My Device), change all passwords, inform IT department, have SIM blocked.

q14.question: What is a firewall?
q14.b: A security barrier that filters network traffic
q14.explanation: A firewall monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic according to defined rules. It's the first line of defense.

q15.question: Why are regular software updates important?
q15.a: For new features and better design
q15.explanation: Security updates patch known vulnerabilities. Attackers specifically target unpatched systems (exploits). Enable automatic updates where possible.

schulungsnachweis.title: Training Documentation & Awareness Program
schulungsnachweis.subtitle: Plan, document and verify employee security training

angriffspfade.title: Common Attack Paths
angriffspfade.subtitle: How cybercriminals operate — and how to protect yourself
angriffspfade.intro: When you understand how attackers think and operate, you can protect your company more effectively. Here we show the most common attack vectors with concrete defense measures.

phishing.title: Phishing Attack
phishing.desc: Impersonates trusted senders to steal credentials

steps.s1: Attacker researches target (LinkedIn, website, org chart)
steps.s2: Creates convincingly real email (spoofed sender, copied logo)
steps.s3: Victim clicks link or opens attachment
steps.s5: Attacker uses stolen data for further access

phishing.defense: Email filters, Security awareness training, MFA, DMARC/SPF/DKIM

ransomware.title: Ransomware Attack
ransomware.desc: Encrypts company data and demands ransom

steps.s1: Initial access via phishing email or unpatched vulnerability
steps.s5: Encryption of all reachable systems and backups

ransomware.defense: Network segmentation, Offline backups, EDR, Patch management, Least privilege

supplyChain.title: Supply Chain Attack
supplyChain.desc: Attack via trusted suppliers or software updates

steps.s1: Attacker compromises software vendor or IT service provider
steps.s2: Malicious code embedded in regular software update
steps.s3: Update automatically distributed to all customers
steps.s4: Backdoor enables access to customer networks

supplyChain.defense: Supplier assessment, Software Composition Analysis, Network monitoring, Zero Trust

insider.title: Insider Threat
insider.desc: Threat from current or former employees with access rights

steps.s1: Employee with elevated access (admin, developer, executive)
steps.s3: Data exfiltration via USB, cloud, email or screenshot
steps.s4: Sabotage: Deletion of data or configuration changes
steps.s5: Detection only after weeks or months

insider.defense: Least privilege principle, Offboarding process, DLP, Logging, Four-eyes principle

bruteForce.title: Brute Force & Credential Stuffing

steps.s1: Attacker obtains leaked credentials (darknet, data breaches)
steps.s2: Automated tools test combinations against login pages
steps.s3: Password reuse leads to successful logins
steps.s4: Attacker gains access to email, VPN or cloud services

bruteForce.defense: MFA, Account lockout, Strong passwords, Credential monitoring, Rate limiting

killchain.title: Cyber Kill Chain
killchain.desc: Every attack follows a pattern. The earlier you detect it, the less damage occurs.

p1.title: Reconnaissance
p1.desc: Attacker gathers information about the target

p2.title: Weaponization
p2.desc: Malicious code is created or adapted

items.i1: Defense in Depth: Multiple defense layers instead of a single measure
items.i2: Zero Trust: Trust no one, verify everything — even within the internal network
items.i3: Patch fast: 60% of successful attacks exploit known, unpatched vulnerabilities
items.i4: MFA everywhere: Prevents 99.9% of all account-based attacks according to Microsoft
items.i5: Train, train, train: Humans remain the most important security factor

bedrohungen.title: Current Threat Landscape
bedrohungen.subtitle: The most important cyber threats for German companies — based on BSI situation report
bedrohungen.intro: The threat level in cyberspace has never been higher. Here you'll find an overview of current dangers, trends and what this specifically means for your company.

t1.title: Ransomware
t1.desc: Still the #1 threat for businesses. Double extortion (encryption + data theft) is standard.
t1.impact: Business disruption, Data loss, Ransom, Reputation damage

t2.title: Phishing & Spear Phishing
t2.desc: Increasingly sophisticated through AI-generated text. CEO fraud and business email compromise (BEC) are rising.
t2.impact: Identity theft, Financial losses, Data breaches
t2.trend: Rising — AI makes attacks more personal and convincing

t3.title: Supply Chain Attacks
t3.desc: Attacks via suppliers and IT service providers. One compromised provider affects hundreds of customers.
t3.impact: Broad damage impact, Hard to detect, Loss of trust
t3.trend: Strongly rising — increasing digitalization of supply chains

t4.title: DDoS Attacks
t4.desc: Flooding services with requests to disrupt availability. Often politically motivated or as a diversion.
t4.trend: Stable — but attacks are getting larger and more complex

t5.title: Software Vulnerabilities
t5.desc: Zero-days and known vulnerabilities in widely used software. Log4Shell and MOVEit showed the scale.
t5.impact: Unauthorized access, Data leak, System compromise
t5.trend: Permanently high — increasing software landscape complexity

t6.title: Insider Threats
t6.desc: Deliberate or accidental damage by own employees. Remote work increases the risk.
t6.impact: Data leakage, Sabotage, Hard to prove
t6.trend: Rising — Remote work and skills shortage increase risk

i1.desc: Annual damage from cyberattacks in Germany (Bitkom)

i2.desc: Of German companies have already been affected by cyberattacks

i3.desc: Vulnerabilities discovered daily on average (BSI 2024)

i4.desc: Average time until an attack is detected (IBM)

items.i1: Lower IT budgets = fewer protective measures
items.i2: No dedicated security team (often 'IT does everything')
items.i3: Valuable data: Customer data, design plans, patents
items.i4: Gateway to larger companies (supply chain attack)
items.i5: Lower resilience — one attack can be existentially threatening

items.i1: Take inventory: What systems, data and access points exist?
items.i2: Enable MFA for all accounts — now, not 'next week'
items.i3: Check your backup strategy: Does the restore actually work?
items.i4: Train your employees: People are both the strongest AND weakest defense
items.i5: Patch promptly: Automatic updates where possible, everything else within 72h

dsfa.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)
dsfa.subtitle: When a DPIA is required and how to conduct one step by step
dsfa.intro: The DPIA under Art. 35 GDPR is mandatory for processing with high risk to data subjects. Neglecting it risks fines up to EUR 10 million. Here's everything you need to know.

when.title: When is a DPIA required?
when.desc: A DPIA is mandatory when processing is likely to result in high risk:

items.i1: Systematic evaluation of personal aspects (profiling, scoring)
items.i2: Large-scale processing of special categories (health, biometrics)
items.i3: Systematic video surveillance of public areas
items.i4: Use of new technologies (AI, IoT, Big Data)
items.i5: Automated decisions with legal effect
items.i6: Processing data of vulnerable groups (children, employees)

s1.title: Processing Description
s1.desc: Document purpose, nature, scope, context and purposes of processing

s2.title: Necessity & Proportionality
s2.desc: Is processing necessary for the purpose? Are there less intrusive means?

s3.title: Identify Risks
s3.desc: What dangers exist for rights and freedoms of data subjects?

s4.title: Assess Risks
s4.desc: Likelihood and severity for each identified risk

s5.title: Define Measures
s5.desc: Technical and organizational measures for risk mitigation

s6.title: Evaluate Residual Risk
s6.desc: Is remaining risk acceptable? If not: consult supervisory authority

s7.title: Documentation & Review
s7.desc: Document DPIA, review regularly, update when changes occur

blacklist.title: Must-Do DPIA List
blacklist.desc: The Data Protection Conference defined processing that always requires a DPIA:

items.i1: Scoring by credit agencies or financial service providers
items.i2: Operation of rating portals
items.i3: GPS tracking of employees or vehicles
items.i4: Use of big data analysis for customer profiles
items.i5: Whistle-blowing systems
items.i6: Use of AI for recruitment

items.i1: Maintain a DPIA register — keep an overview of all assessments
items.i2: Involve the DPO early, not just at the end
items.i3: Use the BfDI PIA tool or CNIL tool as a template
items.i4: A DPIA is a living document — update regularly
items.i5: Also document the decision NOT to conduct a DPIA

vvt.title: Record of Processing Activities (RoPA)
vvt.subtitle: The mandatory GDPR document — create it step by step
vvt.intro: The RoPA under Art. 30 GDPR is mandatory for almost every company. It's the foundation of your data protection management and is the first thing requested during audits.

items.i1: All companies with more than 250 employees — always
items.i2: Companies under 250 employees, if: regular processing of personal data
items.i3: Processing of special categories (health, religion, trade union)
items.i4: Processing with risk to rights and freedoms of data subjects
items.i5: In practice: EVERY company needs a RoPA

i1.title: Name and Contact Details
i1.desc: Of the controller, representative if applicable, and DPO

i2.title: Purpose of Processing
i2.desc: Why is data processed? (e.g. payroll, marketing)

i3.title: Categories of Data Subjects
i3.desc: Customers, employees, suppliers, applicants etc.

i4.title: Categories of Personal Data
i4.desc: Name, address, email, bank details, health data etc.

i5.title: Recipient Categories
i5.desc: Who receives data? (Tax office, accountant, cloud provider)

i6.title: Third Country Transfers
i6.desc: Transfer to countries outside EU/EEA (e.g. USA)

i7.title: Deletion Deadlines
i7.desc: When is data deleted? (statutory retention periods)

items.i1: Payroll processing
items.i2: Customer management / CRM
items.i3: Email communication
items.i4: Website operation (cookies, analytics)
items.i5: Applicant management
items.i6: Video surveillance

items.i1: Start with obvious processing (payroll, CRM, email)
items.i2: Ask every department — IT often doesn't know all processing activities
items.i3: Use an Excel spreadsheet or specialized software
items.i4: Update with every new software or process change
items.i5: The RoPA is not a one-time project — it lives and grows with your company

avv.title: Data Processing Agreement (DPA)
avv.subtitle: When you need a DPA and what it must contain
avv.intro: When you have service providers process personal data (cloud, IT support, hosting), you need a DPA under Art. 28 GDPR. Without a DPA, you risk fines.

when.title: When do you need a DPA?

items.i1: Cloud services (Microsoft 365, Google Workspace, AWS, Azure)
items.i2: Hosting providers (web hosting, email hosting)
items.i3: IT service providers with remote access to your systems
items.i4: Payroll accountant / tax advisor (if processing data on your behalf)
items.i5: Newsletter services (Mailchimp, CleverReach)
items.i6: Document destruction & disposal companies

i1.title: Subject and Duration
i1.desc: What is processed? How long does the contract run?

i2.title: Nature and Purpose
i2.desc: Hosting, analysis, support — clearly define the purpose

i3.title: Type of Data
i3.desc: Which data categories are processed?

i4.title: Data Subject Categories
i4.desc: Customers, employees, website visitors?

i5.title: Instruction Binding
i5.desc: The processor acts only on your instructions

i6.title: Confidentiality
i6.desc: Processor employees must be bound to confidentiality

i7.title: TOM
i7.desc: Technical and organizational measures of the processor

i8.title: Sub-processors
i8.desc: List of all sub-processors, approval requirement

i9.title: Audit Rights
i9.desc: You must be able to verify compliance

i10.title: Deletion/Return
i10.desc: What happens to data at contract end?

items.i1: Tax advisors (independently responsible, not instruction-bound)
items.i2: Lawyers (independently responsible, professional secrecy)
items.i3: Banks (payment processing in their own area of responsibility)
items.i4: Postal/parcel services (transport, not processing)

items.i1: Large providers (Microsoft, Google) have standard DPAs — review and accept
items.i2: Maintain a DPA list: Who processes what for you?
items.i3: Audit right = you MUST audit, not just can (at minimum a questionnaire)
items.i4: Without a DPA, YOU are responsible — not the service provider
items.i5: Update when changing providers or scope changes

cyberVersicherung.title: Cyber Insurance
cyberVersicherung.subtitle: Does your company need cyber insurance? Costs, coverage and exclusions
cyberVersicherung.intro: Cyber insurance can be vital in an emergency. But it doesn't replace IT security — it complements it. Here's what matters.

items.i1: Average damage per cyberattack for SMEs: EUR 95,000
items.i2: 30% of affected SMEs cannot operate normally after an attack
items.i3: GDPR fines, notification costs and forensic analyses are expensive
items.i4: Business interruptions can last weeks
items.i5: Customers and partners increasingly expect protection

i1.title: First-party Damage
i1.desc: Business interruption, data recovery, IT forensics

i2.title: Third-party Damage
i2.desc: Claims from third parties (customers, partners)

i3.title: Crisis Communication
i3.desc: PR consulting, notification of affected parties

i4.title: Legal Protection
i4.desc: Legal costs in GDPR proceedings

i5.title: Ransom
i5.desc: Coverage of ransomware payments (controversial, often capped)

items.i1: Intentional actions
items.i2: Known, unpatched vulnerabilities
items.i3: Missing basic security measures (no backup, no MFA)
items.i4: War and state-sponsored cyberattacks
items.i5: Damage from missing updates older than 30 days

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites for Coverage
prerequisites.desc: Insurers increasingly require minimum security standards:

items.i1: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) for external access
items.i2: Regular, tested backups (3-2-1 rule)
items.i3: Current patch management
items.i4: Employee training (at least annually)
items.i5: Network segmentation
items.i6: Incident response plan

items.i1: Insurance COMPLEMENTS IT security — it doesn't REPLACE it
items.i2: Compare at least 3 offers — coverage varies significantly
items.i3: Watch for sublimits (caps for individual damage types)
items.i4: Check obligations carefully — violations mean no coverage
items.i5: The better your IT security, the cheaper the premium

kostenrechner.title: IT Security Cost Calculator
kostenrechner.subtitle: What does IT security cost for your company? Reference values by company size
kostenrechner.intro: The most common question: What does IT security cost? The answer: Significantly less than a cyberattack. Here you'll find realistic cost frameworks and prioritization help.

s1.includes: Password manager, backup solution, antivirus, VPN if needed, basic training

s2.title: Micro Enterprises (1-10 employees)
s2.includes: Firewall, endpoint protection, backup, MFA, basic training, external DPO if needed

s3.title: Small Enterprises (10-50 employees)
s3.includes: Managed firewall, EDR, patch management, awareness training, external CISO, SIEM-light

s4.title: Medium Enterprises (50-250 employees)
s4.includes: SOC/MDR, SIEM, vulnerability management, CISO (internal), pentests, certification

i1.desc: Firewall, endpoint, backup, encryption, MFA

i2.desc: Awareness training, CISO, specialists, certifications

i3.desc: Policies, ISMS setup, audits, compliance

i4.desc: Pentests, consulting, managed security, forensics

i5.desc: Cyber insurance, legal protection

roi.title: Return on Security Investment
roi.conclusion: Bottom line: An investment of EUR 10,000/year in IT security can prevent damages of EUR 100,000+.

i1.title: Immediately (free/cheap)
i1.desc: Enable MFA, change passwords, install updates, check backup

i2.title: Short-term (under EUR 2,000)
i2.desc: Password manager, basic training, firewall check, antivirus

items.i1: Use funding: go-digital, Digital Jetzt, KfW (up to 50% funded)
items.i2: Open source tools: KeePass, pfSense, Wazuh, ClamAV — professional and free
items.i3: BSI Grundschutz instead of expensive consulting: Freely available, well documented
items.i4: Internal training: Videos, quizzes, micro-learning instead of expensive in-person training
items.i5: Use synergies: ISMS covers NIS2, ISO 27001 and TISAX simultaneously

scoreBadge.title: Share Your IT Security Score
scoreBadge.subtitle: Show customers and partners your IT security standard
scoreBadge.intro: A visible IT security score builds trust with customers, partners and suppliers. Learn how to use and communicate your score effectively.

items.i1: Build trust with business partners — especially in supply chains
items.i2: Competitive advantage: Customers prefer provably secure partners
items.i3: Demonstrate compliance without expensive certification
items.i4: Lower insurance premiums through documented security
items.i5: Motivate employees through visible progress

basic.title: Basic (0-40%)
basic.desc: Fundamental measures still missing. Urgent action needed.

developing.title: Developing (41-60%)
developing.desc: Initial measures implemented. Important gaps remain.

established.title: Established (61-80%)
established.desc: Solid foundation. Optimization potential in details.

i1.title: Website Badge
i1.desc: Embed on your website as a trust seal

i2.title: Email Signature
i2.desc: Link score badge in your email signature

i3.title: Proposal Documents
i3.desc: Demonstrate IT security standard in tenders

i4.title: Supplier Questionnaires
i4.desc: Use score as evidence in customer questionnaires

items.i1: Complete the full assessment first for a meaningful score
items.i2: Update your score regularly — at least quarterly
items.i3: A score is not a certificate — communicate honestly
items.i4: Use the score internally as a motivation tool for your team

lieferantenAmpel.title: Supplier Security Assessment
lieferantenAmpel.subtitle: Check and document IT security in your supply chain
lieferantenAmpel.intro: NIS2 and ISO 27001 require the assessment of suppliers and service providers. Here you'll learn how to systematically check IT security in your supply chain.

items.i1: NIS2 Section 30(2) No. 4: Supply chain security is mandatory
items.i2: 60% of cyberattacks come through the supply chain (Gartner)
items.i3: One compromised service provider endangers all customers
items.i4: Insurers increasingly require supplier assessment
items.i5: Customers actively ask about your supply chain security

i1.title: Certifications
i1.desc: ISO 27001, SOC 2, TISAX, BSI IT-Grundschutz available?

i2.title: Data Protection
i2.desc: DPA in place, GDPR-compliant, DPO appointed?

i3.title: Patch Management
i3.desc: Regular updates, SLA for critical patches?

i4.title: Access Control
i4.desc: MFA, Least Privilege, regular access reviews?

i5.title: Incident Response
i5.desc: Emergency plan in place, notification obligation to you agreed?

i8.title: Sub-contractors
i8.desc: Control over supplier's own supply chain?

green.title: Green — Uncritical
green.desc: All essential criteria met. Cooperation without restrictions.

yellow.title: Yellow — Conditional
yellow.desc: Partially met. Cooperation with conditions and action plan.

red.title: Red — Critical
red.desc: Essential criteria not met. Cooperation only under strict conditions or rejection.

items.i1: Create a standardized questionnaire for all suppliers
items.i2: Prioritize: Assess critical suppliers (IT, cloud, data) first
items.i3: Contractually agree on incident notification obligations
items.i4: Conduct assessment at least annually, semi-annually for critical suppliers
items.i5: Document EVERYTHING — auditors will ask for evidence

jahresbericht.title: IT Security Annual Report
jahresbericht.subtitle: Annual reporting for management and oversight
jahresbericht.intro: An annual IT security report is best practice and effectively mandatory for NIS2-regulated companies. Here you'll learn what belongs in it and how to structure it.

items.i1: NIS2: Management must actively oversee IT security
items.i2: ISO 27001: Management review is a mandatory component
items.i3: Liability protection: Documented duty of care by management
items.i4: Budget planning: Evidence-based argumentation for IT security budget
items.i5: Measure progress: Year-over-year comparison shows development

s1.title: Executive Summary
s1.desc: Key statements for management on one page

s2.title: Maturity Level & Score
s2.desc: Current status, comparison to previous year, target values

s3.title: Incidents & Reports
s3.desc: Number, type and handling of security incidents

s4.title: Implemented Measures
s4.desc: What was implemented during the reporting period?

s5.title: Open Risks
s5.desc: Known risks with assessment and action plan

s6.title: Training & Awareness
s6.desc: Conducted training, participation rate, phishing test results

s8.title: Budget & Resources
s8.desc: Expenditure, comparison to plan, budget request for next year

s9.title: Outlook & Recommendations
s9.desc: Planned measures, threat trends, strategic recommendations

items.i1: Maximum 15-20 pages — management won't read 100-page documents
items.i2: Visualize: Traffic lights, trend arrows, charts instead of tables
items.i3: Translate risks into money — 'Ransomware risk: EUR 200,000' is stronger than 'high risk'
items.i4: Show year-over-year comparison — progress motivates
items.i5: Concrete action recommendations with budget and timeline

digitalerNachlass.title: Digital Estate & Emergency Access
digitalerNachlass.subtitle: What happens to your IT systems if you become unavailable?
digitalerNachlass.intro: What happens when the IT manager or CEO suddenly becomes unavailable? Without emergency access, the company stops. Here's how to prepare.

items.i1: CEO passes away — no one knows the admin password
items.i2: IT manager has an accident — only they know the server credentials
items.i3: Freelancer becomes seriously ill — hosting and domain expire
items.i4: Employee is terminated — takes knowledge of configurations with them

i2.title: Access Documentation
i2.desc: List of all critical systems with access information (stored encrypted)

i3.title: Trusted Person

i4.desc: Store login credentials for domain provider

i5.title: Hosting Access

i6.title: Email Admin
i6.desc: Admin access to email infrastructure (Exchange, Google Workspace)

i7.title: Banking

i8.title: Contracts & Licenses
i8.desc: Overview of all IT contracts, notice periods, contacts

i9.title: Backup Access

i10.title: Testamentary Provisions

items.i1: The 'bus factor' principle: No critical knowledge should reside with only one person
items.i2: Update password envelopes regularly (at least semi-annually)
items.i3: Test emergency access: Can Person B actually reach everything?

items.i5: Four-eyes principle: No single person should have unrestricted access

items.i3: Network access restricted (IP whitelisting where possible)
items.i4: Automatic updates/patches enabled at provider
items.i5: Regular configuration reviews scheduled

saas.title: SaaS
saas.responsibility: Provider: Almost everything. You: Access + Data

paas.title: PaaS
paas.desc: Platform as a Service (Azure App Service, Heroku)
paas.responsibility: Provider: Infrastructure + Runtime. You: Application + Data

iaas.title: IaaS
iaas.desc: Infrastructure as a Service (AWS EC2, Azure VMs)
iaas.responsibility: Provider: Hardware + Network. You: OS + Application + Data

items.i1: Maintain a cloud inventory: What services do you actually use?
items.i2: Evaluate every new cloud service BEFORE it's introduced
items.i3: Prefer EU providers or providers with EU data centers
items.i4: Test the data export function — can you get your data back?
items.i5: Train employees on shadow IT risks

benchmark.title: IT Security Benchmark
benchmark.subtitle: Where does your company stand? Industry averages and reference values
benchmark.intro: How good is your IT security really? Compare yourself with industry averages and best practice values to identify strengths and weaknesses.

averages.title: Industry Averages IT Security
averages.desc: Based on BSI situation report, Bitkom studies and industry reports:

i1.desc: Heavily regulated (DORA, BaFin), high standards

i2.desc: KRITIS-regulated, but often underfunded

i3.desc: OT security often neglected, TISAX drives improvement

i4.desc: PCI DSS for card payments, otherwise heterogeneous

i5.desc: Self-interest + customer requirements drive standards

selfAssess.title: Quick Self-Assessment

items.i1: Do ALL employees have MFA enabled?
items.i2: Was a backup restore tested in the last 12 months?
items.i3: Is there a written IT security policy?
items.i4: Were all employees trained in the last 12 months?
items.i5: Does a documented emergency plan exist?

selfAssess.scoring: 0-1 Yes: Immediate action needed | 2-3 Yes: On the way | 4-5 Yes: Good foundation

items.i1: Don't compare with corporations — orient yourself to similarly sized companies
items.i2: Focus on KPIs with the greatest leverage: MFA, backup, training
items.i3: Measure quarterly and document progress
items.i4: Use IT-Sicherheitskompass as a benchmark tool for all regulations
items.i5: Share results with management — numbers make an impact

poster.title: IT Security Posters & Notices
poster.subtitle: Printable security rules for office, server room and break area
poster.intro: Simple, clearly visible rules work. Hang these posters and remind your team daily of the most important IT security rules.

rules.r3: Don't open suspicious emails — report them!
rules.r5: Never plug in unknown USB drives
rules.r6: Install updates immediately — not 'Remind me later'
rules.r9: Report security incidents immediately — never cover up
rules.r10: Clean desk: Lock away documents, clear the printer

rules.r1: Urgent request: 'Act now!' / 'Your account will be locked!'
rules.r2: Unknown sender or slightly altered domain (rnicrosoft.com)
rules.r4: Link leads somewhere different than displayed (hover to check!)

rules.r3: A unique password for EVERY service
rules.r5: Never on sticky notes on the monitor, never share via email

rules.r2: Disconnect device from network (pull cable / turn off WiFi)
rules.r4: DON'T delete or change anything (evidence preservation)
rules.r5: Document the incident (What? When? How noticed?)

items.i1: Hang posters at eye level next to printer, coffee machine and entrance area
items.i2: Change posters every 3 months — familiarity reduces effectiveness
items.i3: Use posters as conversation starters in team meetings
items.i4: Print on A3 for best readability

radar.title: Threat Radar
radar.subtitle: Current cyber threats at a glance — what you need to watch out for now
radar.intro: The threat landscape changes constantly. This radar shows you the currently most relevant threats for German SMEs with concrete recommendations.

i1.title: Ransomware Groups (LockBit, BlackCat, Cl0p)
i1.desc: Actively targeting German SMEs, double extortion standard

i2.title: AI-powered Phishing
i2.desc: Perfect language, personalized, almost undetectable

i3.title: Unpatched Exchange Servers
i3.desc: Still the #1 entry point for on-premise systems

i1.title: Supply Chain Attacks via SaaS
i1.desc: Compromise through cloud service providers increasing

i2.title: QR Code Phishing (Quishing)
i2.desc: Fake QR codes in emails and physically

i3.title: MFA Fatigue Attacks
i3.desc: Attackers bombard with MFA requests until victim accepts

i1.title: AI-generated Deepfakes
i1.desc: CEO fraud via video/audio becoming more realistic

i2.title: IoT Botnets
i2.desc: Smart devices in corporate network as entry points

i3.title: Post-Quantum Cryptography
i3.desc: Prepare encryption today for quantum computers tomorrow

i1.title: Social Engineering
i1.desc: Humans remain the primary target — training is mandatory

i2.title: Insider Threats
i2.desc: Remote work increases risk of uncontrolled data access

i3.title: Legacy Software Vulnerabilities
i3.desc: Old systems without updates are ticking time bombs

items.i1: Upgrade MFA with phishing-resistant methods (FIDO2/Passkeys)
items.i2: Strengthen email security: Configure DMARC, SPF, DKIM
items.i3: Verify offline backups — does the restore actually work?
items.i4: Train employees on AI phishing and quishing
items.i5: Check external attack surface: What's reachable from outside?

beraterModus.subtitle: Use IT-Sicherheitskompass professionally for your clients

s1.desc: Walk through the Navigator with the client to identify relevant regulations

items.i2: 15 regulations & standards in one platform — no tool chaos

items.i4: Progress measurement: Improvements are visible and provable
