hub.title: IT Security by Industry
hub.subtitle: Which regulations, risks, and measures are relevant for your industry? Find industry-specific guidance.
hub.intro: Every industry has its own IT security requirements. Whether legal obligations like NIS2 and GDPR or industry-specific standards like TISAX or PCI DSS — here you'll find a compact overview for your sector.

logistik.title: IT Security for Transport & Logistics
logistik.subtitle: Protect supply chains, meet NIS2 obligations, secure operations
logistik.metaDesc: IT security for freight forwarders, logistics companies, and transport providers. NIS2, GDPR, KRITIS — all requirements at a glance.
logistik.intro: The transport and logistics industry is increasingly digitalized — from telematics to warehouse management to route planning. At the same time, regulatory requirements through NIS2 are growing and IT dependency makes the industry vulnerable.

nis2.reason: Transport sector in NIS2 Annex I — all medium and large companies affected

dsgvo.reason: Driver data, customer data, GPS tracking — personal data in core business

kritis.reason: Large logistics companies may be classified as critical infrastructure operators

tisax.reason: Automotive suppliers in logistics need TISAX conformity

iso27001.reason: Major clients increasingly require ISO 27001 certification

items.i1: Ransomware paralyzes route planning and warehouse management — supply chain stops
items.i2: GPS spoofing and telematics manipulation endanger transport routes
items.i3: Phishing via forged freight documents and delivery notices
items.i4: Unsecured interfaces to customer systems (EDI, API)
items.i5: Driver data leaks through unsecured mobile devices
items.i6: Supply chain attacks via compromised subcontractors

i1.title: MFA for all IT systems
i1.desc: Telematics portal, TMS, WMS — enable two-factor authentication everywhere

i2.title: Backup strategy 3-2-1
i2.desc: Daily backups of route planning and customer master data, separate storage

i3.title: Network segmentation
i3.desc: Strictly separate office IT, telematics, and warehouse WiFi

i4.title: Employee training
i4.desc: Awareness for phishing via forged freight communication

i5.title: Mobile Device Management
i5.desc: Centrally manage and secure driver smartphones and tablets

i6.title: Supplier assessment
i6.desc: Include IT security requirements in subcontractor contracts

logistik.quickWin: Start with the NIS2 quick check — as a transport company, you are very likely affected.

gesundheit.title: IT Security in Healthcare
gesundheit.subtitle: Protect patient data, secure medical devices, ensure compliance
gesundheit.metaDesc: IT security for medical practices, clinics, laboratories, and healthcare providers. GDPR, NIS2, KRITIS — all obligations explained.
gesundheit.intro: Healthcare processes highly sensitive patient data and is increasingly targeted by cyberattacks. The combination of strict data protection requirements (GDPR Art. 9), NIS2 obligations, and the criticality of medical devices makes IT security a top priority.

nis2.reason: Healthcare sector in NIS2 Annex I — hospitals, laboratories, pharmaceutical companies affected

dsgvo.reason: Art. 9 GDPR — health data are special categories with enhanced protection requirements

kritis.reason: Hospitals with 30,000+ inpatient cases/year are critical infrastructure

iso27001.reason: Basis for industry-specific security standards (B3S Hospital)

items.i1: Ransomware attacks on hospitals — surgery cancellations and patient endangerment
items.i2: Patient data leaks with severe GDPR consequences (Art. 9 special categories)
items.i3: Connected medical devices (IoMT) as attack vectors
items.i4: Unencrypted communication between practices, laboratories, and insurers
items.i5: Social engineering against clinic staff with high success rate
items.i6: Outdated software on medical systems without patching options

i1.title: Encrypt all patient data
i1.desc: At-rest and in-transit — especially for transmissions to labs and insurers

i2.title: IoMT network segmentation
i2.desc: Isolate medical devices in dedicated VLANs, no direct internet access

i3.title: Role-based access control
i3.desc: Only treating physicians see patient records — principle of least privilege

i4.title: Regular privacy training
i4.desc: Mandatory training for all staff with patient contact

i5.title: Cyberattack emergency plan
i5.desc: Documented procedure for IT outage including analog fallback

i6.title: Medical device patch management
i6.desc: Coordinated with manufacturers, documented and monitored

gesundheit.quickWin: Start with the GDPR assessment — patient data requires the highest level of protection.

fertigung.title: IT Security for Manufacturing & Production
fertigung.subtitle: OT security, securing Industry 4.0, preventing production outages
fertigung.metaDesc: IT security for manufacturing companies. NIS2, CRA, TISAX — properly securing OT security and Industry 4.0.
fertigung.intro: The convergence of IT and OT (Operational Technology) in manufacturing creates new attack surfaces. Connected production systems, IoT sensors, and digital twins offer efficiency gains — but also entry points for cyberattacks.

nis2.reason: Manufacturing in NIS2 Annex II — critical product manufacturers affected

cra.reason: Cyber Resilience Act affects manufacturers of products with digital elements

tisax.reason: Automotive suppliers need TISAX for VDA business relationships

iso27001.reason: Major clients and OEMs increasingly require ISO 27001 certification

dsgvo.reason: Employee data, camera systems, access control — GDPR-relevant

items.i1: Ransomware stops production line — costs of 100,000+ EUR per day of downtime
items.i2: Outdated PLC/SCADA systems without security updates
items.i3: Unsecured OT networks with direct internet access
items.i4: Industrial espionage through compromised development computers
items.i5: Supply chain attacks via infected firmware updates
items.i6: USB-based malware distribution in the production environment

i1.title: OT/IT segmentation
i1.desc: Physically separate production network from office IT (Purdue Model)

i2.title: OT asset inventory
i2.desc: Catalog all PLCs, HMIs, SCADA systems and document firmware versions

i3.title: USB control
i3.desc: Lock USB ports in production or control via whitelist

i4.title: PLC program backup
i4.desc: Regular backup of all control programs and configurations

i5.title: Secure remote maintenance
i5.desc: VPN mandatory and MFA for all remote access to production systems

i6.title: OT incident response plan
i6.desc: Specific emergency plan for production outages due to cyberattacks

fertigung.quickWin: Start with the NIS2 quick check — most manufacturing companies fall under Annex II.

handel.title: IT Security for Retail & E-Commerce
handel.subtitle: Protect customer data, secure payment systems, harden online shops
handel.metaDesc: IT security for retail and online shops. PCI DSS, GDPR, NIS2 — all requirements for the retail sector.
handel.intro: Whether brick-and-mortar retail or e-commerce — customer data and payment information are processed everywhere. The combination of PCI DSS requirements, GDPR obligations, and growing cyber threats against online shops makes professional IT security essential.

pciDss.reason: Every merchant accepting card payments must comply with PCI DSS

dsgvo.reason: Customer data, newsletters, order history — extensive GDPR obligations

nis2.reason: Online marketplaces and large retail companies fall under NIS2

iso27001.reason: B2B customers and insurers increasingly require certifications

cra.reason: Private label electronics or IoT products are subject to the CRA

items.i1: Credit card data theft through compromised POS terminals
items.i2: Magecart attacks on online shop payment forms
items.i3: Customer data leaks through unsecured shop databases
items.i4: DDoS attacks on online shops during peak times (Black Friday, Christmas)
items.i5: Phishing against employees with access to payment systems
items.i6: Fake returns and fraud through compromised customer accounts

i1.title: PCI DSS compliance
i1.desc: Complete SAQ, process card data only through certified payment providers

i2.title: Web Application Firewall
i2.desc: Deploy WAF in front of online shop — protection against SQL injection and XSS

i3.title: Regular shop updates
i3.desc: Keep CMS, plugins, and payment modules always up to date

i4.title: Minimize customer data
i4.desc: Only collect necessary data, enforce deletion periods (GDPR Art. 5)

i5.title: DDoS protection
i5.desc: Use CDN with DDoS mitigation for the online shop

i6.title: Monitoring & alerting
i6.desc: Automatically detect and report unusual transaction patterns

handel.quickWin: Start with the PCI DSS check — if you accept card payments, it's mandatory.

itDienstleister.title: IT Security for IT Service Providers
itDienstleister.subtitle: Protect customer systems, build trust, demonstrate compliance
itDienstleister.metaDesc: IT security for IT service providers, MSPs, and system houses. ISO 27001, SOC 2, NIS2 — compliance as competitive advantage.
itDienstleister.intro: IT service providers are both multipliers and targets. A compromised MSP can endanger hundreds of clients. At the same time, certifications like ISO 27001 and SOC 2 are increasingly prerequisites for winning clients.

nis2.reason: ICT service providers fall directly under NIS2 — MSPs, cloud providers, data centers

iso27001.reason: Standard requirement from enterprise clients — competitive advantage

soc2.reason: International clients expect SOC 2 Type II reports

c5.reason: Cloud services for public sector clients require C5 attestation

dsgvo.reason: DPA obligation — IT service providers are almost always data processors

risks.title: Typical IT risks for IT service providers

items.i1: Supply chain attack via MSP — one compromised access endangers all clients
items.i2: Privileged access abuse by employees with admin rights at client sites
items.i3: Unsecured remote access to client systems
items.i4: Insufficient tenant separation in multi-tenant environments
items.i5: Outdated monitoring tools with known vulnerabilities
items.i6: Missing documentation and reporting obligations for security incidents

actions.title: Top measures for IT service providers

i1.title: Privileged Access Management
i1.desc: PAM solution for all client access — time-limited, logged, with MFA

i2.title: ISO 27001 certification
i2.desc: Build ISMS as a foundation of trust and competitive advantage

i3.title: Verify tenant separation
i3.desc: Strictly isolate network, data, and access between clients

i4.title: Client incident response
i4.desc: Documented process for security incidents at client sites

i5.title: DPA management
i5.desc: Conclude and maintain standardized DPAs with all clients

i6.title: Team security awareness
i6.desc: Your own employees are the first line of defense — train regularly

itDienstleister.quickWin: Start with the ISO 27001 assessment — the most important standard for IT service providers.

energie.title: IT Security for Energy Providers
energie.subtitle: Protect critical infrastructure, meet KRITIS obligations, ensure supply security
energie.metaDesc: IT security for energy providers and utilities. NIS2, KRITIS, BSI IT-Grundschutz — all obligations for the energy sector.
energie.intro: The energy sector is the backbone of society and thus a top target for cyberattacks. From grid operators to municipal utilities to wind farm operators — regulatory requirements are high and the consequences of outages are severe.

nis2.reason: Energy sector in NIS2 Annex I — essential entities with highest requirements

kritis.reason: Energy providers are classic critical infrastructure operators under BSI-KritisV

bsiGrundschutz.reason: BSI IT-Grundschutz is the de-facto standard for the industry

dsgvo.reason: Smart meter data and customer master data are personal data

risks.title: Typical IT risks in the energy sector

items.i1: State-sponsored attacks on energy infrastructure (APT groups)
items.i2: Compromise of SCADA/ICS systems in substations
items.i3: Ransomware against IT systems with spillover to OT networks
items.i4: Smart meter manipulation and billing fraud
items.i5: Attacks on wind farm remote control and PV inverters
items.i6: Insider threats from privileged technicians with remote access

i1.title: IT/OT segmentation per IEC 62443
i1.desc: Strict separation of office IT and control systems, DMZ in between

i2.title: Implement BSI-Grundschutz
i2.desc: Systematic ISMS buildup according to BSI Standard 200-x

i3.title: 24/7 monitoring
i3.desc: Security Operations Center (SOC) for real-time monitoring

i4.title: Set up KRITIS reporting
i4.desc: Establish reporting channels to BSI and test regularly

i5.title: Red team exercises
i5.desc: Regular attack simulations on critical systems

i6.title: Emergency exercises
i6.desc: Annual exercises for blackout scenarios with IT outage

energie.quickWin: Start with the KRITIS check — as an energy provider, you are subject to the strictest requirements.

automotive.title: IT Security for Automotive & Suppliers
automotive.subtitle: Meet TISAX requirements, protect production secrets, secure supply chain
automotive.metaDesc: IT security for automotive suppliers. TISAX, NIS2, CRA — all requirements for the automotive industry.
automotive.intro: The automotive industry places particularly high demands on information security. TISAX is the industry-specific standard required by all OEMs and Tier-1 suppliers. Additionally, NIS2 obligations and the Cyber Resilience Act apply to connected vehicle components.

tisax.reason: Mandatory standard for all VDA business relationships — OEMs and Tier-1 require TISAX

nis2.reason: Vehicle manufacturing in NIS2 Annex II — manufacturers and key suppliers affected

cra.reason: Connected vehicle components (V2X, OBD) fall under the CRA

iso27001.reason: TISAX is based on ISO 27001 — often pursued in parallel

dsgvo.reason: Connected cars generate personal data — GDPR-relevant

risks.title: Typical IT risks in the automotive industry

items.i1: Industrial espionage on development data (prototypes, CAD, BOMs)
items.i2: Ransomware in production — just-in-time supply chain collapses
items.i3: Compromised firmware in ECUs and connected vehicle components
items.i4: Supplier attacks via insecure interfaces to Tier-2/Tier-3 suppliers
items.i5: Data exfiltration through unprotected development environments
items.i6: Loss of TISAX certification due to security deficiencies — business loss

actions.title: Top measures for the automotive industry

i1.title: Prepare TISAX assessment
i1.desc: Systematically work through ISA catalog, perform gap analysis

i2.title: Prototype protection
i2.desc: Encrypt development data, strictly enforce need-to-know principle

i3.title: Supply chain security
i3.desc: Include IT security requirements in supplier contracts

i4.title: Secure development (SSDLC)
i4.desc: Security-by-design for all software components in vehicles

i5.title: Network segmentation
i5.desc: Strictly separate development, production, and administration

i6.title: Classified information handling
i6.desc: Protect prototype photos, BOMs, and CAD data according to VDA-ISA

automotive.quickWin: Start with the TISAX check — no TISAX label, no business with OEMs.

finanzen.title: IT Security for Financial Services
finanzen.subtitle: Ensure DORA compliance, protect customer data, meet regulatory obligations
finanzen.metaDesc: IT security for banks, insurers, and financial service providers. DORA, NIS2, PCI DSS — all regulations at a glance.
finanzen.intro: The financial sector is subject to the strictest IT security requirements of any industry. With DORA (Digital Operational Resilience Act) effective since 2025, an EU-wide regulation mandates IT risk management, incident reporting, and third-party risk management.

dora.reason: DORA has been mandatory since January 2025 — comprehensive IT resilience requirements

nis2.reason: Financial sector in NIS2 Annex I — in addition to sector-specific requirements

pciDss.reason: Card processing requires PCI DSS compliance — strictly audited

iso27001.reason: De-facto standard, often seen as minimum requirement by BaFin

dsgvo.reason: Financial data is among the most sensitive personal data

risks.title: Typical IT risks in the financial sector

items.i1: Targeted attacks on online banking and payment processing
items.i2: Insider trading through compromised analyst computers
items.i3: Third-party risks from cloud outsourcing and FinTech partners
items.i4: DDoS attacks on trading platforms and online banking
items.i5: Compliance violations due to inadequate IT security documentation
items.i6: Social engineering against employees with access to financial systems

actions.title: Top measures for financial service providers

i1.title: Build DORA compliance
i1.desc: Establish ICT Risk Management Framework, Incident Reporting, and Digital Resilience Testing

i2.title: Third-party risk management
i2.desc: Assess and monitor all IT service providers — DORA Articles 28-44

i3.title: Threat-led penetration testing
i3.desc: TLPT per DORA Article 26 — realistic attack simulations

i4.title: Business continuity management
i4.desc: Detailed recovery plans for all critical business processes

i5.title: End-to-end encryption
i5.desc: Consistently encrypt all financial transactions and customer data

i6.title: Regulatory reporting
i6.desc: Establish reporting processes to BaFin and BSI and practice regularly

finanzen.quickWin: Start with the DORA assessment — DORA has been mandatory since January 2025.

gv1.title: Cybersicherheitsstrategie entwickeln
gv1.description: Erstellen Sie eine dokumentierte Strategie, die Cybersicherheit mit Geschäftszielen verknüpft.
gv1.firstStep: Definieren Sie die Top-5-Cybersicherheitsziele im Einklang mit Ihrer Geschäftsstrategie.

gv2.title: Risiko-Governance etablieren
gv2.description: Implementieren Sie regelmäßiges Cybersicherheits-Risiko-Reporting an die Geschäftsleitung.
gv2.firstStep: Erstellen Sie ein monatliches Risiko-Dashboard für die Geschäftsleitung.

id1.title: Asset-Inventar aufbauen
id1.description: Erstellen Sie ein vollständiges Inventar aller IT-Assets inkl. Cloud-Dienste.
id1.firstStep: Beginnen Sie mit einer Inventarisierung aller Cloud-Dienste und SaaS-Anwendungen.

id2.title: Risikobewertung durchführen
id2.description: Bewerten Sie Cybersicherheitsrisiken systematisch nach Wahrscheinlichkeit und Auswirkung.
id2.firstStep: Führen Sie ein Risiko-Assessment für Ihre 10 kritischsten Systeme durch.

pr1.title: Zero-Trust-Ansatz einführen
pr1.description: Implementieren Sie das Prinzip "Never trust, always verify" für alle Zugänge.
pr1.firstStep: Beginnen Sie mit MFA für alle externen Zugänge und Cloud-Dienste.

pr2.title: Awareness-Programm etablieren
pr2.description: Starten Sie ein kontinuierliches Security-Awareness-Programm mit regelmäßigen Schulungen.
pr2.firstStep: Planen Sie eine initiale Awareness-Schulung für alle Mitarbeiter.

de1.title: Monitoring implementieren
de1.description: Implementieren Sie kontinuierliches Monitoring aller kritischen Systeme und Netzwerke.
de1.firstStep: Beginnen Sie mit der Überwachung Ihrer Firewall-Logs und Active-Directory-Ereignisse.

de2.title: SIEM/SOC aufbauen
de2.description: Implementieren Sie ein SIEM-System oder beauftragen Sie einen Managed SOC-Dienst.
de2.firstStep: Evaluieren Sie 2-3 Managed-SOC-Anbieter für Ihr Unternehmensprofil.

rs1.title: Incident-Response-Plan erstellen
rs1.description: Erstellen Sie einen umfassenden IR-Plan mit Rollen, Prozessen und Kommunikationsvorlagen.
rs1.firstStep: Definieren Sie das IR-Team und erstellen Sie einen Eskalationsplan.

rs2.title: IR-Übungen durchführen
rs2.description: Führen Sie regelmäßige Tabletop-Übungen und technische IR-Übungen durch.
rs2.firstStep: Planen Sie eine Ransomware-Tabletop-Übung mit dem Management.

rc1.title: Recovery-Pläne erstellen
rc1.description: Dokumentieren Sie Wiederherstellungspläne für alle kritischen Systeme.
rc1.firstStep: Erstellen Sie einen Wiederherstellungsplan für Ihr E-Mail-System als Pilot.

rc2.title: Recovery-Tests planen
rc2.description: Testen Sie die Wiederherstellung kritischer Systeme mindestens vierteljährlich.
rc2.firstStep: Planen Sie einen vollständigen Backup-Wiederherstellungstest für nächsten Monat.

au1.description: Implementieren Sie NIST-konforme Passwort-Richtlinien: Mindestlänge 12 Zeichen, Leak-Check, kein erzwungener Wechsel.

au2.title: MFA flächendeckend aktivieren
au2.description: Aktivieren Sie TOTP oder WebAuthn/FIDO2 für alle Benutzerkonten.
au2.firstStep: Beginnen Sie mit Admin-Konten und Entwickler-Zugängen.

sm1.title: Session-Security härten
sm1.description: Implementieren Sie sichere Session-Konfiguration: HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite-Cookies, angemessene Timeouts.
sm1.firstStep: Überprüfen Sie Ihre Cookie-Flags und setzen Sie HttpOnly und Secure.

ac1.title: RBAC implementieren
ac1.description: Führen Sie rollenbasierte Zugriffskontrolle mit Least-Privilege-Prinzip ein.
ac1.firstStep: Dokumentieren Sie alle Rollen und ihre benötigten Berechtigungen.

ac2.title: Serverseitige Validierung sicherstellen
ac2.description: Stellen Sie sicher, dass alle Zugriffskontrollen serverseitig durchgesetzt werden.
ac2.firstStep: Reviewen Sie 5 kritische Endpoints auf fehlende serverseitige Kontrollen.

iv1.title: Input-Validation Framework einführen
iv1.description: Implementieren Sie eine zentrale Input-Validation-Bibliothek für alle Benutzereingaben.
iv1.firstStep: Identifizieren Sie alle Eingabepunkte und implementieren Sie Whitelist-Validierung.

iv2.title: Prepared Statements durchsetzen
iv2.description: Ersetzen Sie alle dynamischen SQL-Queries durch parametrisierte Statements.
iv2.firstStep: Suchen Sie nach String-Konkatenation in SQL-Queries und ersetzen Sie diese.

cr1.title: Verschlüsselungsstrategie implementieren
cr1.description: Verschlüsseln Sie alle sensiblen Daten at-rest und in-transit mit aktuellen Algorithmen.
cr1.firstStep: Inventarisieren Sie alle Orte, an denen sensible Daten gespeichert werden.

cr2.title: Passwort-Hashing modernisieren
cr2.description: Migrieren Sie zu bcrypt/Argon2 mit angemessenen Kostenfaktoren.
cr2.firstStep: Prüfen Sie welchen Hashing-Algorithmus Ihre Anwendung aktuell verwendet.

el1.title: Sichere Fehlerbehandlung implementieren
el1.description: Zeigen Sie generische Fehlermeldungen an und loggen Sie Details nur serverseitig.
el1.firstStep: Suchen Sie nach Stack-Traces in Produktions-Responses und entfernen Sie diese.

el2.title: Security Logging aufbauen
el2.description: Loggen Sie alle sicherheitsrelevanten Ereignisse (Login, Fehler, Zugriffsverweigerungen).
el2.firstStep: Implementieren Sie Logging für fehlgeschlagene Login-Versuche und Berechtigungsfehler.

el3.title: API-Security implementieren
el3.description: Sichern Sie APIs mit Authentifizierung, Rate Limiting und Input-Validierung ab.
el3.firstStep: Implementieren Sie Rate Limiting auf allen öffentlichen API-Endpoints.
